column2: A drop last week averaging 35,500 barrels a day in the nation's crude oil production was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
The City Housing Authority announced a "get tough" policy yesterday to oust "unsalvageable" families unable to control their delinquent children.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A full-scale investigation of labor racketeering received approval of the Senate today, twenty-four hours after it was proposed.
Escalators were introduced to hockey fans at Madison Square Garden last night and the New York Rangers promptly took the first downard ride.
The Trudeau Sanatorium at Saranac Lake, N. Y., has been bought by the American Management Association for use as an educational and research center.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30-- Nineteen powerful building trades unions approved today a reorganization plan intended to increase their strength in a showdown fight with unions organized on industrial lines.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--Pakistan told the Security Council today that it was India's "responsibility and obligation" to comply with the Council's directives on disputed Kashmir.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Eisenhower renounced today any intention of seeking a third term even if the constitutional limit of two terms were repealed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Government stiffened its appeal today for industry and state authorities to increase the emergency flow of oil to Europe.
Sales of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will reach a record $430,000,000 in the twelve months ending Feb. 2, an increase of $40,000,000 over the similar period last year. Earnings from

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--King Saud of Saudi Arabia was welcomed to Washington today with an official fervor fit for potentates of yore. In an honor accorded no other foreign ruler or statesman in the last four years, President Eisenhower greeted the King at National Airport and rode with him in an open limousine
Intervention efforts have failed to alter the course of most of the port's tugboats and oil craft toward a strike at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Atomic Energy Commission painted an encouraging picture today of safety factors in the growing nuclear industry.
Ski Sketch: Charles Minot (Minnie) Dole, founder of the National Ski Patrol System, has just completed his fiftieth year as a skier. He started as a 7-yearold.
Twelve locations have been picked for satellite-tracking cameras whose pictures will make possible precise measurement of bulges in the earth's anatomy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 --The Columbia Broadcasting System is going into the amusement park business, following in the footsteps of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres and Walt Disney.
An eastbound Long Island Rail Road train struck a milk truck on a grade crossing in Queens early yesterday, killing a milkman and his 17-year-old assistant.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 30-- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes tonight announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Two of the most vigorous opponents of public development of Niagara power moved today to insure that such a project would not decrease state or local tax revenue.

Here's what happens when an advertising idea goes over: Swift Co., Chicago meat packer, took large space in Life's Jan. 28 issue, in Look dated Feb. 5 and in the February Ladies' Home Journal to offer $1.45 worth of coupons.
Further efforts by the Communist party to overcome dissensions before a national convention here Feb. 9 to 12 were made known yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--The New York Knickerbockers capitalized on Rochester's poor shooting and erratic floor play for a 92-20 victory tonight in a National Basketball Association game at the Boston Garden.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)--Jerry Moss, a University of Miami senior, eliminated first-seeded Mervyn Rose of Australia from the South Florida tennis tournament today.
The city's health problems involving radiation are increasing steadily, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner declared yesterday.

A call to service has gone out from the New York Heart Association, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York 17, for 35,000 volunteers to assist the 1957 Heart Fund Campaign. These volunteers will serve as telephone callers, solicitors, campaign leaders and miscellaneous helpers in in the drive.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Four Nassau County residents asked the state Education Commissioner today to prohibit the New Hyde Park school board from displaying an "interdenomina tional" version of the Ten Commandments in classrooms.
IN the 1881 edition of her famous "Common Sense in The Household: A Manual of Practical Housewifery," Mrs. Marion Harland remarked to her "fellow-housekeepers," to whom she dedicated her American ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Commandant of the Marine Corps told a House group today he doubted that abuse of authority by drill instructors could be eliminated.

LONDON, Jan. 30--An agreed diagnosis by the State Department and the Foreign Office of the Middle East problem is a prerequisite, the British believe, to any productive meeting between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan threatened yesterday to terminate operations of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway unless $250,000 was raised today. Judge

LONDON, Jan. 30--Industrial shares joined British Government funds in a fresh advance at the start of a new bookkeeping account period today. But demand appeared less vigorous than at the start of other recent account periods.
The nation's third largest steel producer, the Republic Steel Corporation, reported yesterday a record high net income of $90,406,665 for last year.
The New York Board of Rabbis appealed yesterday to President Eisenhower to invite Israeli and Arab leaders to Washington to seek a peace settlement for the Middle East.

Two top officials of the Federal Reserve System have passed along to the public in recent days the benefit of their thinking on the current policy of so-called monetary restraint. The chairman of the Reserve Board, William McChesney Martin, confined himself for the ...
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 30 (AP) --Guy Rodgers led Temple's basketball team to a 70-58 victory over Navy today after the Owls had spotted the middies a 9-0 lead in the first three minutes of play.
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it would spend about $710,000,000 this year for plant expansion and tooling.

At Corlears Hook, in lower Manhattan, 1,672 families of moderate income live in spacious comfort in four tall apartment buildings. Some of the balconies overlook a park and the East River, others face lawns within the development.

Grim battles are going on around the perimeter of the Antarctic Continent these days. On the one hand is a relative handful of men and ships equipped with the stoutest and most effective instruments of modern technology. Opposing them is the ice, which, even now in the Antarctic summer, is a terrible foe indeed.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP)--A bad cold failed to keep Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt from marking her husband's birthday by placing a bouquet of carnations on his grave.

PARIS, Jan. 30--Today was the heaviest day of this week of fashion shows. It opened four collections, of which two really made news: Lanvin for originality and color and Gres for classic style and beauty. The other showings were those of Madame Fath and Jean Dresses.
The majority conclusions of the Senate subcommittee on the status of United States air power protest too much.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Howard C. Sheperd, chairman of the First National City Bank of New York, said today that the New Yort State curb on bank holding companies posed a "grave constitutional question."
A prominent educator recommended yesterday that every public school in the United States be equipped with closedcircuit television.

The Hercules Powder Company in 1956 achieved record net sales and operating revenues of $235,902,914, a gain of 4 per cent over the $226,651,058 volume for 1955. Earnings, however, dipped 6.9 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The House of Representatives overwhelmingly authorized President Eisenhower today to commit the military forces of the United States against any open Communist aggression in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Eisenhower said today that the North Atlantic Treaty alliance was sturdier than appeared on the surface.
The sale of Mrs. John E. Rovensky's collection, the most spectacular auction in decades, ended yesterday with the highest total for a single sale-- $2,438,980.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 30-- A panel of six high school pupils agreed tonight that community programs for classroom desegregation could be enhanced by a clear policy of "let youth alone so that they can have a chance to work it out."

HENRY JAMES took a couple of disconsolate whirls in his grave last evening. But there was no use in being vexed. For Tallulah Bankhead was on the premises at the Ambassador Theatre, and nothing anyone wrote could make much difference.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30-- President Juscelino Kubitschek has called for "a new spirit" in Brazil's relations with the United States. He made clear he meant more help for the development of his nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Mrs. Victoria Geaney is almost as much of a tradition here as is Blair House, where she is hostess-manager. It is not an unusual occurence for her to have as a guest a king whom she entertained ...
Custom smelters reduced their prices of refined copper cent a pound yesterday, to 34 cents, as demand continued to lag and quotations in Europe weakened.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30--Indian saris and Japanese kimonos are commonplace here, but another costume, American Indian ceremonial garb, became quite an attraction today.

The Eisenhower Doctrine for the defense of the Middle East against Communist aggression scored a resounding victory yesterday when the House of Representatives approved by an overwhelming bipartisan majority a resolution to give effect to it in substantially the form proposed by the Administration.
The Salvation Army is preparing to enter the voluntary hospital field in this city. On Tuesday it will dedicate a $4,800,000 building at Main Street and North Hempstead Turnpike in Flushing, Queens.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 30--The Celanese Corporation of America today officially opened its multimillion-dollar Charlotte Development Laboratories. The move brings together three key segments of the company's textile opera
With steels, motors and rails leading, the stock market yesterday made its best gain since Dec. 26.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Plans for a $36,600,000 civic auditorium and cultural center in the nation's capital were placed today before President Eisenhower by the District of Columbia Auditorium Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) --Following is the unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--The General Assembly's Special Political Committee endorsed today a move to reconsider South Korea and South Vietnam for membership in the United Nations.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30-- Lutheran leaders were warned today against what was described as a tendency within the armed forces to develop a "military church."

No one can coax more enchanting sound out of the violin than Mischa Elman. At his Carnegie Hall recital last night, the violinist demonstrated that his touch was as deft, his ear as discriminating as even.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--James D. Zellerbach, San Francisco manufacturer and patron of the arts, was confirmed by the Senate today to be Ambassador to Italy.
The Soviet Union is planning to spend $60,000,000 in an effort to win friends and influence people at the Brussels World's Fair next year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --A dozen business executives, most of them oil men or bankers, were among the guests President Eisenhower invited to the formal sixty-place White House dinner tonight in honor of King Saud of Saudi Arabia.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 30--A panel of five private and Government economists was unanimous today in predicting that over-all economic activity would be higher this year than last.
PARIS, Jan. 30 (Reuters)-- Grigore Gafencu, Rumanian Foreign Minister from 1938 to 1940, died here tonight of a heart attack at his home. He was 65 years old.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 31 (AP)--John Marshall, former Australian swimming star who attended Yale, died early today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. The 26-year-old athlete had been in a coma for five days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm products prices had increased four-tenths of one per cent during the month ended Jan. 15.
THE French company of Jean-Louis Barrault and his actress wife, Madeleine Renaud, returned to New York last night with a piece of theatrical magic by the late Paul Claudel, "Christophe Colomb."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP)-- The Army tonight suspended five concerns involved in the Senate's military uniform inquiry from doing business with the Army.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--The United States and Canada have tentatively agreed to introduce two resolutions on the Israeli-Egyptian dispute.

Wearing uniforms of workers in the volunteer service division of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center, several young women will participate in "The Parade of Volunteer Colors" Wednesday at the society's annual fashion show luncheon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Following is the text of a joint resolution on the Middle East as it was adopted today by the House of Representatives:
St. Peter's College has been a respected institution of higher learning since 1872, but until recently had never created much of a stir in sports beyond the confines of Jersey City.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30--The General Assembly appealed to South Africa today to take a constructive attitude on the question of racial discrimination.
THE nymphs and sprites painted by Hans Boehler exist in a luxurious natural setting brilliant in color, caressing in climate.
A six-month deadlock in Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshore contract negotiations was broken yesterday when representatives of 10,000 New Orleans dock workers signed a new three-year contract.

Robert L. Joseph is back from Paris with a new stage property It is a comedy by George Tabori called "Brouhaha." The title, Mr. Joseph explains, is a French idiom meaning "hub-bub, uproar, hurly-burly."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- King Saud's talks with President Eisenhower may prove to be a turning point in the political life of the Middle East.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) off to 6 points (30 cents a bale) up yesterday.
Ernest Bloch, one of music's grand figures, is 77 years old and still composing prolifically. Last night his String Quartet No. 5, composed in 1956, was introduced to America by the Griller Quartet.

The conduct of foreign policy in a democracy is always a ticklish and difficult matter. Just how very ticklish and difficult it is has now been demonstrated the last few days by the events surrounding King Saud's arrival and by the protests voiced against the proposed visit of Yugoslav President Tito.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 30--The expanding world trade role of the port cities in the Southeast was underscored today in a report by the regional field office of the Department of Commerce.
Mediation efforts to find a peace formula in the contract dispute between newspaper and magazine wholesalers and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union were continued early today.
Two countries behind the Iron Curtain have accepted invitations from President Eisenhower to participate in the United States World Trade Fair at the Coliseum.

VENICE, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Wilma Montesi's parents testified today that she was "a good girl, a saint," and expressed the belief that her death on a beach near Rome in 1953 resulted from some accident.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., is moving today to expand its capital base by nearly $200,000,000 through an offering to its shareholders of rights to subscribe to 4,379,758 shares of capital stock.
THE chicken and the egg question turns up in the fashion field at an exhibition of nineteenth and twentieth century stage costumes that opened at the Museum of the City of New York yesterday.

A father who has given five careers and lost one arm in Government service will retire today. He is Frederick W. Dickman, property and supply officer of the United States Maritime Administration's Atlantic Coast District.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UP)-- Jackie Robinson is a "pop-off" who hurts people and "then writes them a letter of apology," Brooklyn's clutch pitcher, Sal Maglie, said today.
MOSCOW, Jan, 30--The Soviet Union announced tonight the extent of its major industrial and agricultural accomplishments during 1956 and admitted a few setbacks.
LONDON, Jan. 30--Britain has proposed a meeting here of the Western European Union to study integration of the political, defensive and economic organizations of Europe into a central authority.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30--Marshal Tito's proposed visit to Washington in April appears to be off. But then it may be on again, thanks to President Eisenhower.

The May Department Stores Realty Corporation's $25,000,000 issue of 5 per cent, twenty-year general mortgage bonds will be marketed today by a syndicate managed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.
TORONTO, Jan, 30--Dr. William Newton Barnhart, a psychiatrist who testified at the 1906 murder trial in New York of Harry K. Thaw, died Monday at near-by Terra Cotta. He was 93 year's old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)-- The Government's home mortgage buying agency lowered today the price it would pay for Government-insured home mortgages bearing interest of 4 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 34--Publication today of the United Nations Yearbook of International Trade Statistics for 1955 revealed that trade on a world-wide scale rose to new heights that year.
MIAMI, Jan. 30--James E. Fitzsimmons hopes he has another Nashua in the Wheatley Stable's 3-year-old colt Bold Ruler. Maybe he has.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--France and the United States, which have been divided on a number of matters lately, opposed each other today on the issue of a special United Nations fund for economic development.

BOSTON, Jan. 31--The Bates Manufacturing Company has proposed a wage cut of 14 cents an hour as the opening move in union contract negotiations this year. Bates employs 6,000 workers in five mills in Maine.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31 (R')--The Connecticut Turnpike Bond Committee today sold $16,000,000 of state notes secured by general taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A former Army Quartermaster Corps inspector testified today that a concern under Senate investigation for possible fraud against the Government had failed to return more than $80,000 worth of Government materials left over from uniform contracts.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31-- Following are the texts of the codes adopted here today by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations:
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Governor Harriman renewed today his support of a municipal preference clause in a Federal Niagara power development bill.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--The Soviet and Czechoslovak Communist parties issued a communique tonight pledging themselves to establish "closer and more regular contacts."
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 31--"Get out of town" has been the message dinned into the heads of families and factories alike in Stockholm for the last ten years.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 31--The words quoted above began an observation in an opinion by Associate Justice Stanley Reed of the Supreme Court of the United States that is a key to the constitutional philosophy he followed with unusual consistency in his nineteen years on the bench from which his voluntary retirement was announced by the President today. The net of the observa
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31-- Stringent codes designed to bar all forms of union racketeering were approved today for the 15,000,000-member united labor movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) --There were pickings and pickets at the National Football League meeting today. The clubs picked players and pickets marched outside protesting alleged discrimination against Negro players by the Washington Redskins.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Governor Harriman signed today a Republican bill delaying the effective date of the Youth Court Act until April 1, 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- King Saud of Saudi Arabia was subjected today to the rigors of state visits in Washington.
Stocks improved yesterday morning, lost a little ground in the early afternoon and dipped in the final hour. The net result was a small loss in The New York Times combined average.
LONDON, Jan. 31--President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan expressed their faith tonight in the lasting strength of the British-United States alliance.
Artificial magnetic fields that create pressures greater than a million pounds to the square inch have been produced as a result of joint research by three physicists.
Mickey Mantle, who seems to be covering more ground around the dinner circuit this winter than he does in the outfield for the Yankees in summer, swept into New--York yesterday.
Government agencies have settled a long-standing dispute with American Export Lines, Inc., over ship construction subsidies.

Operating revenues of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries in 1956 passed the half-billiondollar mark for the first time in history, according to a preliminary annual report issued yesterday. Sales of electricity, gas
The port's biennial tugboat crisis poses a thorny problem for the city and the metropolitan aria
A New York State jurist called yesterday for a system of alimony awards that would not "convert a host of physically and mentally competent women into an army of alimony drones."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's immigration message to Congress today:
Gisele MacKenzie's manager said yesterday that the singer would leave the cast of "Your Hit Parade" after her contract expires in June. She has been on the television program for four years.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31-- Juscelino Rubitschek completed today the first of his five years as President of Brazil.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was phased over today in the assignment of subcommittee chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee.

A strike of 4,000 crewmen that had been expected for a week halted 400 tugs and oil craft in the Port of New York last midnight.
Howard Fast said yesterday that he had disassociated himself from the American Communist party and no longer considered himself a Communist.
The narrow streets of Chinatown were overrun yesterday with the clangorous festivities of the New Year. It was the First Day of the First Moon in the Chinese Year 4655.
A DIVERTIMENTO by the 16-year-old Mozart and a scintillating performance by Nathan Milstein, the distinguished violinist, helped to redeem a lackluster evening at Carnegie Hall last night.
Wild Bill Stewart got back on skates recently, the Russians heard about it, and presto--no more world amateur hockey championship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Home builders and real estate men asked Congress tooday to act to loosen mortgage money for veterans' housing.
Tentative assessed valuations on taxable property in New York City for the fiscal year 1957-58 continue the upward trend that began after World War II.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (UP)-- Al Rosen, a unanimous choice as the American League's most valuable player in 1953, retired from baseball today "because I can't do the job any more."

The armed services are looking to pathology to provide explanations for the wide variety of airplane crashes that hitherto have wound up in the "cause unknown" file. A rela tively new research program already has turned up some interesting data, including:
FRANK BRANNAN could roam through Times Square when it pulses and throbs with sign-play at night-- though he rarely does--and probably not one person in 10,000 would know him,
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Robert C. Weaver, State Rent Administrator, sought today to quiet the uproar that followed Governor Harriman's rent-control proposals last week.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--Nikita S. Khrushchev and Nikolai A. Bulganin, the Soviet Union's most widely traveled leaders, accepted today an invitation to visit Finland in the spring.

The appointment of Paul R. Screvane as Commissioner of Sanitation, effective March 1, was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Mr. Screvane will succeed Andrew W. Mulrain, who recently announced that he would retire from the $25,000a-year post at the close of business Feb. 28.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 31--Stockholm is unusual among metropolitan areas in Europe for the large proportion of aged to the total population and also for its policy that older persons have as great a claim to housing, medical care and recreation as younger members of society.

"FILLING STATION" was revived last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center, and though it is a basically naive little cartoon, and 19 years old, to boot, it still can be wonderfully good fun.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Secretary of the Air Force told Congress today that United States air retaliatory power had grown greatly during the current year and would continue to grow in the fiscal period beginning July 1.
Thomas D. Heed, former chairman of the board of the Edward Hines Lumber Company, Chicago, died in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Tuesday, after a long illness. His age was 81.
The chairman of the nation's second largest steel company said yesterday he could see no reason whatever for any pessimism concerning the steel industry.

BUCHANAN, N. Y., Jan. 31-- This has "suddenly become financially the biggest little village in the country," according to Mayor William J. Burke.

Futures prices on the New Fore commodity exchanges closed irregularly yesterday. Sugar, cocoa, cooper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined; coffee, wool, onions, potatoes and lead rose, and price movements for hides, rubber and tin were Mixed.

"THE GREEK CASE," a novel by Presiding Jus tice David W. Peck of--the Appellate Division was dramatized last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. It proved a thoroughly acceptable courtroom drama, a shade heavy on detail but generally interesting viewing, thanks to a number of fine individual performances.

ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, off the Knox Coast, Jan, 28--If this icebreaker is lucky she may be able to find out when the great rivers that drained the once-forested hills of Antarctica were overwhelmed by the Ice Age.

In a statesmanlike move, offering the best promise thus far for a solution of the Middle Eastern problems, the United States and Canada are now working on a twophase plan to end the EgyptianIsraeli deadlock. This plan, on
WASHINGTON, Jan, 31--The Treasury Department disclosed tonight it had gone to England to get a new type of high-speed press for printing United States currency.
The Appellate Division for Manhattan and the Bronx recommended yesterday that a separate Family Court be set up to handle all family matters that come into the courts of New York City.
Until last April we had had no decisive answer to a question that many economists had then been asking themselves for a number of months. That question was, Could
BOMBAY, India, Jan. 31-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru charged today that the United Nations Security Council had dealt with the Kashmir problem in a "casual way."
WARSAW, Jan. 31--The Polish youth newspaper Sztandar Mlodych lectured a Soviet party periodical today. It said "epithets and instructions" were not necessary in discussions among Communist parties.
SUKHNE, Yemen, Jan. 30-- The Imam Ahmed, King of Yemen, said today the British were refusing to yield the Aden Protectorate to Yemen because they hoped to find "a lot of oil there."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 --Warner Brothers obviously views the future with optimism. The company is investing more than $85,000,000 in thirty-five pictures, ten of which will be released in the near future, Jack

Sales and earnings of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in 1956 were the highest in the company's history, according to the preliminary annual statement issued by Morse G. Dial, president, for publication today.
ROME, Jan. 31--Accusations in Austria that Italy was mistreating the German-speaking inhabitants of Upper Adige drew an emphatic protest from the Italian Government today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- William C. Bourne, a senior planning officer with the United States Information Agency, died of a heart attack at his desk this morning. He was 57 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Witnesses from industry and labor joined private economists today, in rejecting or discounting President Eisenhower's appeal for voluntary restraints on wages and prices.
The sweet tooth has been getting sweeter. Consumption of chocolate has been increasing in most parts of the world. However, production in the main African growing areas has risen even more sharply.

Skiers were watchful and waiting hopefully last night as reports from the north country continued to be far from impressive. Good conditions were reported in scattered areas, but the over-all picture was far from white.
The Ward LaFrance Truck Corporation was barred yester day from getting a new contract to supply fire engines to the city.
The New York Stock Exchange is pleased with what it has accomplished by its advertising.

A fleet of local short-haul trucks is scheduled to put a twoway radio communications system in operation by March 31. Local trucking officials say the venture is the first undertaken by the industry on a cooperative basis.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31-- The Buenos Aires committee of the Radical party, Argentina's biggest political group, rebelled today against the national committee.
Nearly four years ago President Eisenhower gave his support to the idea of a United Nations fund for assistance to underdeveloped countries. It was contemplated then, and has been contemplated since,
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31-- Religious leaders are viewing with considerable concern their potential legal liability for refugees who become public charges after arriving in the United States.
The nation's gold stock has just gone up S300,000,000, for the largest week's increase in sixteen year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Ben R. Gordon has resigned as president of the City Stores Company, owner of the Franklin Simon and Oppenhelm Collins fashion chains which operate in sixteen major cities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UP)--Gene Fullmer agreed today to give aging but determined Sugar Ray Robinson a chance to capture the world middleweight title for the fourth time in a match at the Chicago Stadium April 24.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Mrs. Charles E. Wilson stood up for her husband today against all comers, including the President of the United States.

Even though Gilbert Miller was suffering from neuritis yesterday, his illness did not prevent him from buying a newly opened Parisian hit, "Patate." Marcel Achard is the author of the comedy, the title of which is a nickname for a milquetoast type of character. Mr. Miller
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- Flamboyant is the last word anyone would use to describe Justice Stanley Forman Reed. Yet he rose to prominence in one of the most flamboyant periods in United States history.

Soviet students are bombarding their professors with sharp questions about the latest changes in the Communist party line.
Geologists have traced a crack in the floor of the oceans that is twenty miles wide, two miles deep and runs around the world in a continuous line that is 45,000 miles long.

SHOPPERS will find eag prices somewhat higher this week than last. After the Government's announcement last Friday that it would be buying more eggs for the school lunch program, prices advanced both at wholesale and retail levels. In
PROVIDENCE, R. L. Jan. 31 -Spencer Borden, banker, industry leader and a prominent yachtsman, died at his home here early today after a long illness. He was in his eighty-fifth year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 --The Ampex Video tape recorder in the first ninety days of network use has achieved the status of a highly useful and practical television tool.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The mail of Senators on the Foreign Relations Committee is running 8 or 9 to 1 against the "Eisenhower doctrine" for the Middle East.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31--The United States drew up today its own version of twin resolutions on the Middle Eastern situation.
Glimmers of hope stole into the murky affairs of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Wstern Railway--yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 31--London is an area, a region, a state of mind. It is no longer, save in the narrowest administrative sense, a city. The problems of its growth are those of all growing cities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Treasury announced plans today for refunding about $12,500,000,000 in securities maturing in February, March and April. For holders of $10,200,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The resignation of Mr. Stanley Reed from the Supreme Court of the United States has started here, as all such resignations do, an erudite and perhaps bootless argument about the decisive tests that should govern the President in filling the vacancy.

ANDROS TOWN, Bahamas, Jan. 31--In fishing, an expert is a man who can be dogmatic without committing himself irretrievably. It is not an easy thing to do and an expert is always in danger of painting himself into a corner.
Gustave Langenus, who was solo clarinetist for the New York Philharmonic Orchestra from 1920 to 1923, died Wednesday at his home in Commack, L. I. He was 74 years old.

A city detective had a hunch that a wooden cross burned in front of a Negro's home in Bayside, Queens, two weeks ago, had been made by a left-handed carpenter. The hunch led yesterday to the arrest of three men--including a left-handed carpenter --on charges of malicious mischief.
Robert Moses sent a report to Governor Harriman yesterday explaining the reasons behind proposed sales of state-developed St. Lawrence power to private industry.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 31-- A foreign policy debate in the Bundestag today gave a preview of the positions the two major parties will take in the election campaign.
The death of John Marshall in Australia as the result of injuries suffered in an automobile accident brings to mind a favorite anecdote concerning the great swimmer.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--The American Library Association announced today its annual list of "notable books." The list contained forty-two titles. It ran from Marian Anderson's "My Lord, What a Morning" to Robert Penn Warren's "Segregation: The Inner Conflict in the South."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The United States is moving toward agreement with its Western European allies to maintain existing military manpower goals in the North Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--More questions were being prepared by Democratic Senators today for John Foster Dulles on the eve of the resumption of hearings on the Administration's Middle East proposals.
Gustave Langenus, who was solo clarinetist for the New York Philharmonic Orchestra from 1920 to 1923, died Wednesday at his home in Commack, L. I. He was 74 years old.
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union early today rejected tentative agreements reached yesterday with suburban and city newspaper and magazine wholesalers.
At the sixty-first annual meeting of the New York' Zoological Society Dr. Fairfield Osborn, the president, announced May 15 as the date of an event long awaited by New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize more than double the present allowable annual flow of immigrants to the United States.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 31 --The engagement of Miss Suzanne Taxman Ginsberg, daughter of Mrs. A. Morris Ginsberg and the late Mr. Ginsberg, to Dr. Harry Statland, has been announced by Mrs. Ginsberg.
REDDING, Conn., Jan. 31-- Mrs. Evelyn Wight: Allan, former principal of the old Girls Commercial High School, Brooklyn, and one-time commissioner of the Brooklyn. Girl Scouts,
A recommendation that $3,089,400 be approved as the cost of restoring three Federal historic shrines in New York was made yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UP)--Vice President Chuck Comiskey of the Chicago White Sox got on the long-distance telephone today and talked his ace pitcher, Billy Pierce, into becoming the highest-paid hurler in the club's history.

MIAMI, Jan. 31--An 18-to-1 shot, Charles L. Heekin's Careless Miss, was the winner of Hialeah's best horse race today. Under the handling of strongarmed Steve Brooks, she won by a head from the second choice, A. J. Della-Pietra's Miss Erlen.
PARIS, Jan. 31--The hopes of Premier Guy Mollet to mobilize solid political support for his Algerian policy appear to have miscarried.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The retirement of Justice Stanley F. Reed from the Supreme Court, effective Feb. 25, was announced at the White House today.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Funds for the opening of the long-sought state college for teachers on Long Island in the fall of 1958 are provided in the budget that Governor Harriman submitted to the Legislature today.
DETROIT, Feb. 1--The American Motors Corporation has resigned from the National Association of Manufacturers.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP)-- Milon Marusic, a 40-year-old professional golfer "on vacation" from his club job in St. Louis, took the lead at the midway mark of the $15,000 Phoenix open today. He tallied a fourunder-par 66 for a thirty-sixhole total of 135.
James W. Morgan, president of the Ayshire Collieries Corporation of Indianapolis, died here yesterday at Memorial Hospital after a long illness. His age was 57.
WARSAW, Feb. 1--All Warsaw newspapers received telephoned messages today that a strike had started at the Zeran automobile plant on the capital's outskirts and that the situation there was "grave."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Three private economists strongly supported the Eisenhower Administration today in its policy of tight money and taxes high enough to balance the budget.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1--A survey last year indicated that 15 per cent of the adults in Los Angeles did not know the name of the Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Federal Maritime Administration asked the Supreme Court today to review the judgment of lower courts in the controversial dualrate shipping proposals.
United Air Lines announced yesterday it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to authorize a 6 per cent increase in its fares. It is expected that a number of other lines also will seek increases.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--King Saud of Saudi Arabia motored today to Walter Reed Army Medical Center to see his 3 year-old son.
MIAMI, Feb. 1--Mrs. John W. Galbreath's Summer Tan is ready for the $50,000 and $100,000 races that will be run later this month at Hialeah.

Coach George Eastment's young men of Manhattan had their expected romp to an eighth straight team title in the fifteenth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1-- Five million Lutherans were called upon today to pray for the United States Government and the United Nations in their search for a "righteous" solution to the critical Middle East situation.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 (AP) --An American student said today he was seeking political asylum in West Germany because he feared prosecution for fighting alongside Hungarian rebels while wearing a United States Army uniform.

The New York knickerbockers will be seeking their fourth triumph in six meetings with the Boston Celtics when the teams clash in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 --More new personalities will parade across the motion-picture screen this year in star and feature-player roles than in any comparable period since the early Nineteen Thirties.

Directors of the American Chicle Company raised the dividend on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 75 cents quarterly, payable on March 11. The company said this new rate would place the stock on an annual basis of $3 a share.

LONDON, Feb. 1--With buying of industrial shares at a low ebb, price movements on the stock market today were narrowly irregular. Only British Government securities continued to advance.

BERNARDO SEGALL, pianist, gave the third of three chamber music recitals with the assistance of the composerpianist, Leo Smit, last night at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 4--Reports of a Soviet peace overture to President Tito of Yugoslavia circulated here tonight.

TRENTON, Feb. 4--The State Supreme Court ordered the Newark Board of Education today to reconsider its dismissal of three public school teachers who invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Congressional subcommittee.
THE day when a story had to be not only realistic but also ploddingly dull to be considered wholesome for the pre-school set is definitely gone.

The increasing advantages of bonds over common stocks as trust investments were emphasized yesterday by speakers before the first session of the midwinter trust conference of the American Bankers Association.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4--A landholders' organization was urged today to promote a lagging conservation program to the nation's farmers and ranchers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--One thing now is certain about the visit of King Saud of Saudi Arabia: His 3 -year-old son, Prince Mashhur, has won the children's vote. Presents and "get-well" wishes have been piling up for the Prince at Blair House.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Feb. 4 (AP)-- Robert S. Devaney, Michigan State end coach, today was named to succeed Phil Dickens as head football coach at the University of Wyoming.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--President Eisenhower assured National Guard leaders today that he would not permit the Guard to be destroyed or materially reduced in strength.
UNITED NATIONS, N,Y., Feb. 4--France announced here today that she had long-range plans to promote the formation of a European-African community.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4--Dag Harnmarskjold had a two-hour-and-fifteen-minute discussion of the Middle Eastern situation today with Abba Eban, Israeli delegate to the United Nations.
The report of the Temporary Commission on the Courts that was made public yesterday gives the latest figures on congestion and delay in the courts.
Confusion over the Middle East has been further compounded by the two resolutions adopted by the United Nations General Assembly over the week-end.

Two of the most useful members of the Senate--Gore of Tennessee and Mansfield of Montana--have signed a report that will stand as a landmark in the long and painful history of efforts to keep national elections democratic with a lowercase "d."

Mickey Mantle, the New York Yankees' star outfielder, went through the formality of signing his 1957 contract yesterday. The world champions' American League triple-crown winner will receive a reported $58,000 this year.
PARIS, Feb. 2--Fashions this season were marked by the emergence of two figures who deserve special mention: Pierre Cardin and Guy LaRoche.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 4-- Premier Suleiman Nabulsi said today that Jordan wished to remain a friend of Britain although the treaty of alliance between the two nations is ending.
PARIS, Feb. 4--A committee of experts has decided that a free trade area in Europe linked with a proposed West European common market is "technically possible."

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4--Two unions accused of unethical practices offered some reforms at hearings today before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation's fifty-two-story building, to be built on the site of the Marguery Hotel on Park Avenue, will have a stainless steel and glass facade rising from a landscaped plaza at street level.

TOKYO, Feb. 4--A program designed to align Japan with the "free democracies" abroad and to promote continued prosperity at home was presented to the Diet (Parliament) today by the new Government of Premier Tanzan Ishibashi.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 --Titles of the five pictures that will compete for the best foreignlanguage film award to be given for the first time in March by ...
VIENNA, Feb. 4--The Hungarian Government has charged that a new revolt was being organized in the country, timed to break out in March, the Budapest radio reported tonight.

William Wyler is pondering a proposal by Metro-GoldwynMayer to direct the studio's long-contemplated remake of its 1927 silent-film classic, "Ben Hur." The word is that Mr. Wyler has expressed satisfaction with the screen play written by Karl Tunberg.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 4--Edward MacHugh, "Your Gospel Singer" of radio fame, who retired about twelve years ago, died here yesterday in Holy Cross Hospital after an operation for cancer of the liver. His age was 63.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 4 --This city's 363 public-school teachers stayed away from their classrooms today in a dispute over salaries. Twenty-two elementary and grammar schools and two high schools, with 9,217 pupils were closed.
An accounting method that sounds like the description of a shirker is saving business millions in taxes.
That Tommy Carroll is one of the best high school trackmen in the metropolitan area is not disputed. But how good will the 17-year-old Fordham Prep senior be in college?

A group of independent oil producers has asked the Department of Interior to investigate the "failure" of the Middle. East Emergency Committee and other oil shippers "to divert Caribbean oil from the East Coast to the European emergency area."
The states of New York and Massachusetts yesterday added $120,000,000 to the schedule of borrowings to be made soon in the public bond market.
On the eve of this week-end's scheduled Communist national convention in New York, Moscow has chosen to intervene with its usual heavy hand.
A summary judgment that may enable R.H. Macy Co., Inc., to collect $9,000,000 in tax refunds was handed down here yesterday.
Manfred Kridl, Adam Mickiewicz Professor Emeritus of Polish Studies at Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday at his home at 423 West 120th Street. He was 70 years old.
World sugar prices continued to decline yesterday in heavy volume on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final prices were 6 to 10 points (hun-- dredths of a cent a pound) lower on 83,600 tons.
BISHOP, Va., Feb. 4--Thirty-seven miners were killed today in a gas explosion deep in the giant Bishop Coal Mine, which lies under mountains at the Virginia-West Virginia line near here.
MIAMI, Feb. 4 (AP)--Needles, the speedy little Florida-bred champion who specializes in come-from-behind finishes, is up for sale. Price: $800,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP)-- The Budget Director warned Congress today against pumping new funds into G.I. home loans. He said it would aggravate a "serious threat" of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The Secretary of the Treasury told Congress today he feared that revenue increases resulting from the growth in the economy would not be sufficient in themselves to provide a tax reduction.

ADEN, Feb. 4--The action at Qataba, Yemen, on Jan. 26 will never rate among the decisive battles of the world. Yet the absurdly Gilbertian frontier skirmish still is causing repercussions in this British colony.
LONDON, Feb. 4--Government Funds had their first real setback this year in the stock markets here today.

EDWARD MULHARE can take a nice long breath this morning and relax. So can everyone else connected with "My Fair Lady," including all those lucky ticketholders for one of the greatest musicals of our time.
One baffling issue emerged yesterday to overshadow the theorizing about what could have caused the crash of a Miamibound airliner here Friday evening:
SOMETHING new, cheese canoes, come from Mrs. Ferenc Kormendi, whose pastries deserve every accolade in the epicure's dictionary.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 4--Provisional President Joseph Nemours Pierre-Louis resigned last night. Tonight the political leaders who had forced him out were split over what to do next, and a general strike was continuing.

Edgar Kaplan of New York won the twenty-seventh annual Life Masters Individual contract bridge championship early yesterday. He finished ahead of 136 high ranking players in competition since last Friday evening at the Roosevelt Hotel.
OTTAWA, Feb. 4 (AP)--Canada had a record deficit of $1,290,100,000 in trade with the United States in 1956, the Bureau of Statistics estimated today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP)--Wheat resisted a general decline in grains on the board of trade today, ending with gains running to more than a cent. New crop months led the advance.
A United Nations General Assembly committee yesterday was debating the proposed Special U.N. Fund for Economic Development--which the public might as well become accustomed to calling SUNFED.
PARAMUS, N.J., Feb. 4--In a woodland clearing here half a hundred men sloshed about this morning in sticky mud.

ROME, Feb. 4--The first pipeline for Italian oil was opened by a United States concern today. It links the oil field of Ragusa in southeastern Sicily with the seaport town of Augusta, forty-seven miles distant.

The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union yesterday scheduled a general membership meeting for tomorrow night to "consider and act upon" a report from its negotiating committee in its current strike. The union is striking against thirty-one newspaper and magazine wholesalers.
The University of Michigan's surveys of consumer spending and finances over the last ten years shoved a growing inclination to save money, despite installment buying and inflation.

It's a good-looking $20 bill printed on a good grade of bond paper. However, the back of the note has a washed-out appearance and no attempt has been made to simulate the Treasury's red and blue fiber threads. It's a counterfeit.

AS if there were not enough belligerence roiling the bright streams of humanity, Charles Neider has brought out a book called "Man Against Woman."* This sets back universal friendliness by 210 pages and perhaps as many days.
Two men and a woman were indicted yesterday under a section of the espionage law that carries the death penalty or a prison term up to life. They are accused of having spied for the Soviet Union.
The bonded debt owed by the city of Berlin to the outside world is about to go back on an interest-paying basis after twenty-four years of default.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 4 --Indonesia's gold and convertible foreign exchange reserves have dropped below the legally fixed minimum of 20 per cent of currency in circulation partly as a result of the recent revolts in Sumatra.

Court congestion and delay cannot be ended without increasing the number of judges and modernizing court structure and procedure, according to a new report by the Temporary Commission on the Courts. It has found congestion and delay getting worse, especially in the New York metropolitan area.

The issues in the tug strike include union demands for a 20 per cent wage increase, a $5,000 insurance policy, additional accident and sick benefits, doubled employer pension payments, eleven paid holidays and three weeks' vacation pay.
The State Power Authority split again yesterday as it voted tentative allocations of power to be developed by the state on the Niagara River.
Cotton futures advanced 15 to 25 points (75 cents to $1.25 a bale) yesterday. Business on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active.
The unbeaten North Carolina Tar Heels remained on top in the United Press college basketball ratings yesterday. However, the Kansas Jayhawks cut the Southern team's first-place margin.
Mayor Wagner put squarely up to the State Legislature yesterday the question whether the city should immediately repeal its controversial $5 and $10 auto use tax.

THE speech delivered by Casey Stengel at the Baseball Writers Dinner could not be described as a model of lucidity. It was rattled off in Stengelese, which is Casey's private language. Unfortunately, there were no interpreters present and few of the guests had the faintest idea as to what he was talking about. Ol' Case was funny without being understood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4-- Southern railroads, with one of the largest carriers abstaining, revised their application for increases in freight rates today by advancing the total requested amount to 15 per cent.

The port's tugboat stake, now entering its fifth day, was no nearer solution yesterday despite Mayor Wagner's personal intervention.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reported today its net income in the last half of 1956 was $17,994,105, compared with $13,680,689 in the same months of 1955.
Modifications in the restrictions against the employment of foreign players here were weighed at a special midnight meeting last night by the Actors Equity Council, the union's governing board.
STUART, Fla., Feb. 4--Serious hound men in this part of the country--and nobody is more serious than a serious hound man--blare the praises of the non-baying, slow-trailing deer hound.
A crowd of 19,300 fans jammed Madison Square Garden last night to see the wrestling program. It was a non-televised show.
Three Columbia University coeds who are afraid of mice and grow faint at the thought of baiting a fish hook are sharing their crowded apartment at 110 Morningside Drive with an alligator.

HAL MARCH gave a convincing performance last night as a fear-ridden television wisecracker who has lost his popularity. The play in which he appeared was Robert Allan Arthur's "Tale of the Comet on "Studio One" over Channel 2.

"VOLPONE" is great fun, however you take it. We got it last night from the Renaud-Barrault company in French out of Stefan Zweig's German version--the same one being played so excellently in English at the Rooftop Theatre downtown. This translation is by Jules Romains.
IT is agreeable to see an exhibition of drawings respect fully mounted and properly presented as in the current display at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 4--A Harriman program to outlaw "bait" advertising was introduced in the Legislature tonight.
TRENTON, Feb. 4--A spokesman for a mental health group defended tonight the tranquilizing drugs against their detractors, among whom he included the National Institute of Mental Health.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP)--The nation's automobile makers are maintaining a fairly steady production pace with volume around 145,000 units a week.
LONDON, Feb. 4--The gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as banker for the sterling area declined by $49,000,000 last month. This brought the total down to $2,084,000,000.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 4 (UP)--Pancho Gonzales, enraged by 13,000 jeering, foot-stomping Australian tennis fans, hurled his racquet into the crowd tonight when Ken Rosewall rallied to defeat him, 4--6, 4--6, 6--3, 9--7, 6--1.
DUBLIN, Feb. 4--A general election will be held in Ireland March 5.
President Eisenhower's idea that people of the world can understand each other in spite of governments was furthered yesterday by the People-to-People Foundation, Inc.
An implied charge that Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Communist party chief, is an antiSemite, was made in yesterday's Daily Worker by the paper's foreign editor, Joseph Clark.
Garnett (Sugar) Hart, a welterweight boxer from Philadelphia, was the knockout victor of record over Barry Allison of Springfield, Mass., at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Two Supreme Court orders were obtained yesterday by the Ward LaFrance Truck Corporation in a move to prevent New York City from awarding a contract for forty-four new fire engine trucks to another firm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4-- Television rights to the title and history of the Paris edition of The New York Herald Tribune have been acquired as the basis of a television series. The producer of the projected program is Lee Loeb. The title of the new show will be "Paris Herald."
CAIRO, Feb. 4--Informed Egyptian seemed to agree today that it was "up to the Americans" to save the Middle East from another blow-up in the Arab-Israeli crisis.
A short circuit on an IRT train at Nevins Street, Brooklyn, played hob with the usual routes traversed by Lexington Avenue and Seventh Avenue trains during the morning rush hour yesterday.

LAST night's presentation of "Mayerling," starring Au drey Hepburn and Mel Ferrer, very possibly was the most expensive single performance in the annals of the entertainment world. If it is possible to say it with reasonable gentleness, $620,000 isn't everything.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3-- For three months this year, an expedition led by a Texas oil man will roam the mountains of Nepal to try to find the truth about one of the great Himalayan mysteries, the mystery of the creature of the icy rocks.
The Public Service Company of Oklahoma raised $12,000,000 on 4 per cent 30-year first mortgage bonds yesterday.
About two dozen manufacturers of gem rings and dealers in such jewelry have joined in forming the Ring Guild of America, Inc., as a promotional group.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4-- A nation-wide testing program at the junior high school level to discover hidden talent was proposed here today.
WILEY THOMAS BUCHANAN Jr., the for mer American Ambassador to Luxembourg, was recognized in that nation by the limousine he owned.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 4-- The Chief Rabbi of Ireland tonight urged leaders of Orthodox Judaism in this country to help revitalize Jewish life in Western Europe.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 4 (AP)--Harry H. Halsell, trail driver, Indian fighter and author who credited his long life to many guns and the ability to use them, died in his home here today. His age was 96.
The National Steel Corporation, the nation's sixth largest steel producer, last year had the highest sales and operating revenues in its history.

Dave Sime, the Duke University sprinter who broke records right and left last year, will be an absentee on Saturday, when the track and field fraternity assembles in Madison Square Garden for the holden anniversary Millrose Games.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 5 (Reuters)--England's touring Marylebone Cricket Club scored 382 runs today, but rain robbed it of victory against the Transvaal side.

BOSTON, Feb. 5--Mrs. Harold M. de Berkeley has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Brenda Alice de Berkeley, to Donald Conrad Conradi. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Conradi of Locust Valley, L.I.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Feb. 5 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Parke Dean of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elisabeth Dean, to Earle Wilford Orr Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Orr of Omaha.

Prof. Harold F. McNiece, assistant dean of the School of Law at St. John's University, Brooklyn, has been appointed associate dean. The Very Rev. John A. Flynn, president of the university, announced the appointment yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has announced the appointment of V.C. Georgescu as associate London Middle East representative. He will serve on the staff of P.J. Anderson, who was recently appointed to the new position of London Middle East representative.

Two young married couples yesterday were feted by the New York Stock Exchange in celebration of the third birthday of MIP. Those letters stand for the Monthly Investment Plan, introduced to encourage small investors to buy stock on a pay-asyou-go basis. As little as $40 a quarter may be invested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Fewer factory workers quit and fewer were hired in December than in November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. It said "hirings went down from thirty to twenty-two per 1,000 and the quit rate from thirteen to ten, while lay-offs remained substantially unchanged." It described the reduced activity as a seasonal decline.

AN audience of almost 1,500 persons assembled at Town Hall last night to hear the Collegiate Chorale sing Bach's B minor Mass. And the choristers rewarded them with one of the most vital performances of the great work that has been heard here in recent seasons.
Mayor and Mrs. Wagner attended the dedication of the Salvation Army's Booth Memorial Hospital yesterday at Main Street and North Hempstead Turnpike, Flushing, Queens.

Plans for rearranging the space now occupied by the Actor Pharmacy at the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel are being made by the Sheraton Corporation of America, operator of the Times Square landmark.

VINCENNES BAY, Antarctica, Wednesday, Feb. 6--A gale with gusts that exceeded 60 miles an hour today brought a halt to all supply unloading for the United States outpost that is being built here on a littleexplored sector of the Antarctic coast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- The Navy today awarded Newport News, Va., Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company a contract to build a $24,000,000 nuclear-powered submarine.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP)--Governor Harriman today announced the appointment of Maj. Gen. Edwin G. Ziegler, retired, of Buffalo to the State Civil Defense Commission.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5-- Joseph Benson Hardaway, animated-cartoon story man who was instrumental in the creation of Bugs Bunny, died of a heart attack last night at his North Hollywood home. He was 66 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- Representative H.R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, told the House today that United Nations headquarters in New York was "very clubby."
A prosy claim for the $26,000 "load Bomber" rewards may be made on behalf of Miss Alice G. Kelly, the Consolidated Edison clerk who has refused to put is a claim for herself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP).-- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today that all test flights, civil and military, be made over open water or over sparsely settled areas approved by the Administrator of Civil Aeronautics.

Three hundred and sixty-two students received degrees last night at Queens College's thirtieth semi-annual commencement Dr. Thomas. V. Garvey, provost of the college, presided at the ceremonies in the college gymnasium.

HONG KONG, Feb. 5--An increasing number of Chinese are being resettled in Tibet under the Peiping Government's "reclaim-the-wastelands" program.

MIAMI, Feb. 5--There have been days during this Hialeah meeting when so many long shots won that the students of form vowed to disregard the past performances on their next visit to the horse park. Today was not one of those days.

TORONTO, Feb. 5--Randall B. O'Hara, advertising executive and a past president of the Canadian Daily Newspapers Association, died yesterday in Key Biscayne, Fla., where he resided. He was 67 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Twenty surgeons will use drugs on patients this month in the start of a nation-wide experiment to find a chemical cure for cancer.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 5--The Haitian General Assembly set up a seven-member committee today to study whether Supreme Court Justice Jean Baptiste Cineas should become Provisional President under the 1950 Constitution. The committee is to report tomorrow.

Errol Flynn last night won $30,000 on "The Big Surprise," quiz show on National Broadcasting Company television. The actor will decide next week, whether to go for the jackpot-- $100,000. His category is "The Sea and Ships."

ALBANY, Feb. 5--Senator William S. Hults and Assemblyman John J. Burns, Nassau Republicans, asked the Legislature today to set up a temporary state commission to cooperate with the Federal Government in planning celebrations for the centennial of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt on Oct. 27, 1958.

UPTON, L.I., Feb. 11--The Brookhaven National Laboratory became a giant classroom today as 200 Suffolk County high school students received an on-the-spot introduction to atomic science.
FOUR heat-and-eat frozen fish dishes, just arrived in stores here, are delectable evidence that cooks sometimes can use short-cut preparations to advantage.

A committee of New York debutantes, all freshmen at Vassar College, has been formed to aid in plans for the thirty-fifth annual scholarship fund opera benefit of the Vassar Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- A spokesman for the National Education Association suggested to congress today a compromise on formulas for distributing proposed Federal school construction aid to states.

The Federal Home loan Bank Board in Washington disclosed yesterday that it was considering a change in its regulations to permit Federally chartered savings and loan associations to credit dividends quarterly.
