UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.,Feb. 12--A nine-nation committee approved today a United States proposal that it take no decision regarding the credentials of Hungary's delegation to the General Assembly. The vote was 8 to 1.
LONDON, Feb. 12--A Labor party motion condemning the Government's economic policy was defeated in the House of Commons tonight, 312 to 249.

MIAMI, Feb. 12--Willie Hartack, the 23-year-old jockey from Black Lick, Pa., had a four-winner afternoon at the Hialeah track today. He also had a second and a third--and 'only one "out" in seven rides.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 12-- Franz-Josef Strauss, Minister of Defense, announced today a plan for a shake-up of the structure of the armed forces command.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union's six-point plan for the Middle East was generally dismissed in Washington today as a self-serving device armed with a propaganda warhead.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 12 --Ali Sastroamidjojo of Indonesia was confronted today with a political move that would end his Premiership.

PARIS, Feb. 12--The most eloquent British plea yet made for the economic integration of Europe was heard today by finance ministers representing the seventeen countries in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
THE last tenant of the former Marguery Hotel (now being torn down to make way for another) is now at home and receiving callers at 1246 Second Avenue. The staff of Dino Levi,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The United States is trying to break not only the Arab-Israeli deadlock in the United Nations but also Egypt's monopoly over maritime traffic between the Red Sea and the Mediterranean.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 12-- When "Jumbo" Wilson, the jovial British general commanding in the Middle East, gave a cocktail party during the last war, he invited his friends by saying: "This will be a poker game. We contemplate a full house--three kings and two knaves."

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP)--Ann Richardson, Columbus, Ohio, and Jack Penrose, Miami Beach, won the medal today with a 2-over-par 70 in the national mixed foursomes golf tourna-- ment at the Boca Raton Club.
VENICE, Italy, Wednesday, Feb. 13 (Reuters)--Italy's Leftwing and Right-wing Socialist parties, which three days ago seemed to be moving quickly toward a merger, were bitterly divided last night.

WHEN I was a boy exploring the hinterlands of my grandfather's library I discovered the works of Henry Morton Stanley, the African explorer. "How I Found Livingstone," "In Darkest Africa" and the rest were enormous volumes bound in ugly green cloth, printed in small type.
PARIS, Feb. 12--France took steps today to safeguard the assets and activities of the Suez Canal Company outside Egypt against interference by the Cairo Government.
Directors of the Virginian Railway Company proposed a split yesterday of the carrier's common and preferred stocks 2.5 for 1 and a change in the par value from $25 to $10.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) --Congress was urged today to grant more Federal school aid than proposed either by President Eisenhower or the Democrats.

A 2 -year-old Afghan hound named Champion Shirkhan of Grandeur leaped into national prominence on the pointing finger of a dog show judge at the end of the eighty-first Westminster Kennel Club competition in Madison Square Garden last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 12--The Legislature, by concurrent resolution, today directed the Public Service Commission to make a comprehensive investigation of the Long Island Rail Road.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb. 12 --A two-year survey of the least-known region of northern British Columbia will be undertaken by the Wenner-Gren Foundation, it was revealed today by the Provincial Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The Justice Department has had no indication "so far" that the oil industry's Middle East Emergency Committee has violated the anti-trust laws, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today.
Benjamin Henry Inness-Brown, retired lawyer who had been associated with several firms in this city, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 78 years old.
ALBANY, Feb.12--The state's Republican leadership announced today its support of the proposed contract between the State Power Authority and the Reynolds Metals Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) --The Eisenhower Administration urged Congress today to authorize a stepped-up Federal civil defense program to cost $533,885,000 over the next five years. Val Peterson, Federal
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 12--Glenmont, Thomas A. Edison's home and "thinking bench," as he called it, was dedicated as a national historic site today
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 --Harvard plans to raise $82,500,000 for its college in the next three years.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12--V.T.Norton of New York, an intelligent and serious conservationist, has again challenged Florida champions of saving the sailfish to produce evidence that released sailfish will live.
A $750,000 gift from the Adele and Arthur Lehman Foundation to Barnard College was announced yesterday by Millicent C. McIntosh, the college president. The money is to

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 12--The California Savings and Loan League was warned yesterday by an Eastern state banking official that California needs "urgently" to develop a larger savings pool of its own.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 12-- Field Marshal Sir John Harding, Governor of Cyprus, reprieved tonight a Greek Cypriote condemned to death for the murder of a British police sergeant last fall.
The big losers in Monday's market break made a halfhearted attempt to recover yesterday. However, none of the
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 12--Wladyslaw Gomulka has ordered a drive against "revisionists" and "conservatives" in the Polish Communist party.
ALBANY, Feb. 12-Governor Harriman accused today Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck of engaging in a "smear" campaign against Charles Abrams, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination.
MADRID, Feb. 12--The Spanish Government has quietly approved a new "tourist" exchange rate of 46 pesetas to the dollar. A "tourist" rate of 42.5 to the dollar has been in effect since late 1953.
Reports from Washington this week have hinted that action may at last be near at hand looking toward improving the relative position of the savings bond holder vis-a-vis other types of investors.
Crimes on the citys' transit system during 1956 declined 21 per cent from 1955, Charles I. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads were advised today by an Interstate Commerce Commissioner to institute a cover charge in their dining cars--one high enough to erase a $24,000,000 annual deficit the carriers insist that they sustain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Two fundamental attacks on President Eisenhower's Middle East proposals were defeated today in the combined Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--Legislation to make social security available to all state and municipal employes was introduced today by the Joint Legislative Committee on the Employes Retirement System. The bills have Republican endorsement.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb.12 --President Eisenhower played the first golf of his Georgia holiday today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12--The Securities and Exchange Commission does not plan to make its investigation of the Fairbanks, Morse Co. proxy fight with the Penn-Texas Corporation a public one, J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the S.E.C., said today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 12 (AP)-Communist-ruled Hungary has begun to rebuild her Army, shattered in the antiSoviet revolt of last October.

The State of Connecticut sold yesterday an issue of $42,300,000 of one-year housing notes to J.P. Morgan Co., Inc. and associates at a rate of 2.3 per cent, with a premium of $205.30. A further block of $2,500,000 of the notes were sold to a group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at a rate of 2.14 per cent, with $38 premium.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 13 --Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo again defended his Sumatra policy in Parliament today and said his coalition Cabinet would be reshuffled.

According to a chronicler of customs, Valentine's Day comes in the "time of year birds choose their mates and probably thence came the custom of young men and maidens choosing their Valentines." And this, too, is a day to try men's handwriting, although ...
The City Housing Authority is trying to break up the concentration of relief families in several public housing projects.
HONG KONG, Feb. 13--Speculation on rumors that peace feelers have been sent to the Chinese Nationalists by the Communists has run wild during the last two days in Chinese language newspapers here.
LONDON, Feb. 13--The Conservative Government won a decisive victory tonight for the "very difficult and awkward decisions" it will take soon to reshape Britain's defenses.
Two attorneys, who disagreed on whether radio and television should be permitted to broadcast courtroom proceedings, proposed yesterday that a commission be set up to explore the question fully.
"Holiday for Lovers," a "romantic comedy" by Ronald Alexander, starring Don Ameche, will have its Broadway debut at the Longacre Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 13-- The United States Government has invited Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to visit Washington this spring or summer.
The annual advertising award of Printers' Ink, advertising and marketing trade weekly, was presented last night to Charles G. Mortimer, president of the General Foods Corporation.
Last year, for the first time since 1948, a rise was reported in the national incidence of syphilis, according to a survey released yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 13--The stock markets here rallied after a dull start today to recover a small part of yesterday's losses. Industrial shares in particular responded to buying at the start of a new bookkeeping account.
Two hundred Eagle and Explorer Scouts from New York got a look behind the scenes yesterday at the city's workshops of administration, industry, publishing, the arts, education and peace.
SAG HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 13 --Miss Elizabeth Hall is a woman with many political firsts to her credit. Today she became the first woman Mayor in Suffolk County history.
The "linguistic illiteracy" of Americans was characterised here yesterday as disgraceful.
A general fund revenue of $640,119,761 for the fiscal year starting July 1 was predicted yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.

Tuesday's legislative hearing on the Tweed Commission's proposals to modernize the courts--Senator Pliny W. Williamson, known opponent of at least some of them, presiding--magnified the opposition out of all proportion to its actual strength. The hearing also served to minimize the extraordinarily wide support which the commission's program has received.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) --Cigar tobacco growers in five states voted tonight to ettend rigid marketing quotas and price supports on their 1957, 1958 and 1959 crops. They voted to continue supports at 90 per cent of parity on cigar binder (types 51 and 52). The states were Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York, Vermont and New Hampshire.
A FRIENDLY taxi pilot in Washington once asked Eliahu Elath what part of the world he came from. He answered: "From the Middle East."

PARIS, Feb. 13--The French Government reacted with calm --one might almost say lethargy --today to the news that the Committee for Liberation of Brittany had appealed to the United Nations for freedom from French domination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The General Services Administration announced today that it was postponing indefinitely the construction of some $700,000,000 worth of Government buildings, mainly post offices, under the new "lease-purchase" program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Two Oregon Democrats today proposed an expanded, centralized research program on how to protect mankind from the dangers of atomic radiation.

ATLANTA, Feb. 13 (UP)-- Gov. Marvin Griffin's lieutenants presented a resolution to the State Legislature today asking impeachment of six United States Supreme Court Justices on the ground that they were guilty of "high crimes and misdemeanors."

MARY Curtis-Verna, American soprano, achieved a place on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera last night. Her debut role, Leonora in "Il Trovatore," was not easy, and she carried it off with outward evidences of poise.
ALBANY, Feb.13--The Legislature was urged today to give New York City more financial assistance than Governor Harriman had recommended in his $1,617,400 record budget.

A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., expects 1957 to be a good year, bettering the levels of 1955, Walter B. Gerould, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. Weather in the spring, he noted, will be an important factor, since a large part of the company's business is done at that time.

Steels, metals, aircrafts, oils and rails--issues that have been under consistent pressure since the turn of the year--shot up in yesterday's stock market. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks recovered 26.6 per cent of its earlier February loss.
The "national Communist" Government of Poland has opened negotiations aimed at receiving aid from the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations.

PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 14-- Seventeen European nations agreed early today to begin negotiations to determine how a free-trade zone in Europe might be created and linked with the common market or customs union planned by six of their number.
Clinton Davidson Jr., board chairman of Resort Airlines, Inc., died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He would have been 46 years old Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- Southern state officials won a further delay today for the presentation of civil rights recommendations to the House of Representatives.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13-- Plans are being completed for a building on the campus to house the Princeton University Store and several student publications, including The Daily Princetonian.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Treasury will announce in the next few days, probably tomorrow, an improvement in the terms of Savings Bonds to attract buyers. The basic decision has been made, it was reliably reported tonight, although details were not available.
THE Bach Aria Group, Frank Brieff conducting, performed two interesting and seldom-heard Bach works at their Town Hall concert last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees denied today President Eisenhower's request for unlimited authority to use military force in the Middle East against Communist aggression. They then adopted a substitute for his proposal.

Governor Harriman pressed his attack last night against the Eisenhower Administration's policy in the Middle East. He asserted that the United States had been supporting "a double standard of morality" in the United Nations.
In an overtime basketball game last night, Fordham defeated Villanova, 69 to 68, at the Fordham gymnasium in the Bronx.
The St. Regis Paper Company announced plans yesterday to acquire the St. Paul and Tacoma Lumber Company of Tacoma, Wash.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 13 (AP)-- State Commerce Department men collecting funds to save the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad reported today they faced tomorrow's Federal Court deadline $55,000 short of their $250,000 goal.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 13 (AP)-- Joe Brown, a fancy dancer with a pinpoint left, sliced up Wallace (Bud) Smith and stopped the sluggish ex-champion on an eleventh-round technical knockout tonight to retain his world lightweight title.

A one-story taxpayer building at 310 to 318 East 166th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Bissan Realty Company after an ownership of ten years. It was bought by Samuel Solomon for investment. The Brener Lewis Company was the broker. The building contains nine stores.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 13--A Federal judge here has come up again with a direct challenge to Virginia's legislative defense of racial segregation in public schools by ordering Norfolk and Newport News to inaugurate mixed classes of whites and Negroes by Aug. 15.

HARTFORD, Feb. 13--Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff presented a $584,900,000 biennial budget to the Connecticut Legislature today. It provides for the largest outlay in the state's history, exceeding the current two-year appropriations by $114,800,000.
LONDON, Feb. 13--President Eisenhower threatened Britain with economic sanctions after the British-French intervention in Egypt, a Conservative Member of Parliament charged tonight.
If the alarm "Calling all beekeepers" ever goes out from Police Headquarters, there will be at least one member of the uniformed force who could respond.
Charles Abrams characterized as "a sham" yesterday the stand taken by Oswald Heck, Assembly Speaker, against wider powers for the State Commission Against Discrimination.
Chet Forte had the biggest night of his career, setting a number of scoring records, as he paced Columbia to a 93--75 Ivy League basketball triumph over Pennsylvania last night at University Hall.

Net earnings of Mack Trucks, Inc., last year rose 55 per cent on a sales gain of 31 per cent above the 1955 levels, P.O. Peterson, president, reported yesterday. The profit and volume were the highest in the company's fifty-seven-year history, he noted.
The scheduled airlines in the United States are attempting to reduce collision danger in the air by a voluntary tightening of traffic regulations.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 13-- The retail merchants division of the Chamber of Commerce, irked by continued delays in obtaining Federal aid for a local redevelopment program, has asked the Citizens Action Committee here to take over the project.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13-- The City of Philadelphia signed a contract today giving one union "sole and exclusive bargaining rights" for employes in departments where it held a majority.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13--Abba Eban, the Israeli Ambassador to Washington, who has been negotiating with United States officials on the question of an Israeli withdrawal behind the Palestine armistice line, could, ...
ELMDALE, Kan., Feb. 13 (AP) --Members of the Christian Church here wondered today about the man who had been their minister nine months.

The issues in the tug strike include union demands for a 15 per cent wage increase, additional accident and sick benefits, increased employer pension payments, nine paid holidays and three weeks' vacation pay.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 13 (UP)--The defending champion team of J. Walcott Brown of Manasquan, N.J., and Anne Quast of Marysville, Wash., knocked out W.B. Merry and Ellen Gerry, both of West Palm Beach, Fla., in the first round of the national mixed foursome two-ball golf championship today. The score was 6 and 5.
Lessing J. Rosenwald reiterated his opposition to political Zionism last night despite what he described as his strong appreciation of Israel's problems and the character and integrity of her people.
Governor Harriman announced last night he would approve sale of more than a quarter of the state's St. Lawrence River power to the Reynolds Metals Company.

Three reporters leaving Madison Square Garden a little after 1 o'clock yesterday morning after covering the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show met a short, dark-haired excited woman. She was insisting to a guard at the door that she be allowed to leave the building with her dog.
Three persons accused of spying for Russia were remanded to prison without bail yesterday after they had pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy to violate the espionage laws.

The major issues in the longshore contract dispute appeared to have been settled before the dockers struck Tuesday. A wage increase of 32 cents an hour was provided for under a proposed three-year contract that would cover dockers from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va.
TED WILLIAMS was trying to be modest but his natural exuberance persisted in disturbing the pose.

The skipper of the freighter Marine Courier, which was damaged in a collision with the cargo ship Exbrook here early Monday morning, told Coast Guard investigators yesterday that the mishap had been caused by carelessness.
The National Shoe Manufacturers Association is taking vigorous action to make sure that advertising matter of its members is as truthful as it can be made.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 13 (AP) --A huge nylon tent, taller than a three-story building and looking like a monstrous beach ball, was unveiled by the Air Force today as the latest thing in radar domes.
ALBANY, Feb. 13--An upstate Republican proposed today that the state spend $500,000 this year on developing small picnic parks along highways.
A passing policeman beat the firemen at their own game in Far Rockaway, Queens, yesterday morning. He rescued eleven persons from two burning buildings before the firemen arrived.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 (AP)--Capt. Paul R. Uffelman, former Assistant United States Military Attache in Moscow, charged today that Soviet agents deliberately staged a "spy" incident to force his expulsion from the country.

LACE, a treasure of man since its development in fifteenthcentury Italy, is being re-interpreted for today's homes. Three major lace manufacturers, Scranton, Quaker and North American, are busy filling orders for their newly designed lace curtains.

Fake leaflets asserting that Groton (Mass.) School, the private boarding school, had drawn up plans to increase its number of Negro students to at least 25 per cent of the school enrollment were received through the mail yesterday by many of the school's alumni.

Cotton futures moved narrowly yesterday and closed mostly higher. With the exception of the near May delivery, which closed 1 point (5 cents a bale) off, prices were unchanged to 11 points (55 cents a bale) higher than Tuesday. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly large.

A New York-Connecticut committee has been formed to work for the success of two theatre parties for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Mrs. Frederic W. Ecker is chairman of the committee.
PARIS, Feb. 13--Western Europe's oil shortage has failed so far to precipitate an industrial crisis.

The eleven-story apartment house occupying the blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue, between Seventieth and Seventy-first Streets, has been sold by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company. The Tishman Company built the structure in 1929. The buyer was a syndicate represented by Harry J. Riker, executive vice president of Riker Co., broker in the deal.
Three men--two wearing false mustache and nose masks-- robbed a Queens savings and loan association of $27,332 yesterday. The robbery took place ten minutes before closing time.

THE world of the contemporary Australian aborig ine is thronged with wallabies, crocodiles, sea cows, turtles and innumerable spirits. Like the ancient primitive artist, the aborigine of today records the things he sees as well as the spirits so familiar to him through legend.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked by an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
The National Labor Relations Board got a court order yesterday against what its investigators consider a labor-management monopoly in the racket-infested garment trucking industry.
A lay-off for seven working days of 2,500 General Electric Company employes who turn out black-and-white television sets will begin a week from today.

A protest rally of about 200 persons drafted a petition last night calling on the city to set up a special relocation bureau to find dwellings for families compelled to vacate their homes for the $175,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment project.

Hugo E. Rogers, former Borough President of Manhattan and once leader of Tammany Hall, will be retired today by the Board of Estimate from an obscure city job to which he was quietly appointed on Jan. 10.
A possible two-thirds Republican control of the State Senate is at stake in three special elections today to fill vacancies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Government of Israel was seeking clarification today of a number of aspects of the proposed United States move in support of freedom of navigation in the Gulf of Aqaba.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13--The General Assembly's Political Committee adopted today two mild resolutions on Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The fundamentals of the legal dispute over the Supreme Court's unanimous decision that state laws requiring racial segregation in the public schools are unconstitutional were put even more clearly on the public record by two statements made in the last ten days. One was by Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman in Norfolk, Va. The other was by James F. Byrnes of South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- Investigating Senators put Robert Tripp Ross under oath today and questioned the Assistant Secretary of Defense for two hours about Army contracts awarded to his wife and brother-in-law.
Many of the country's relatively small supermarket chains are holding their own against their larger rivals because of a novel organization known as Topco Associates, Inc.

OUR guess would be, though we have no statistics to prove it, that more than half the adult Americans in this country think of rice pudding in terms of a grainy, uninviting mess. It had an allure when they were in the nursery but over the years it has lost its appeal.

The national convention of the Communist party in this country has now ended with at least one clear result: There was no open split in the party during the convention, though what may happen in the next few weeks remains conjectural. Certainly those who feel like the delegate who accused his colleagues of "throwing the science of ...
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 --The National Broadcasting Company has completed a foreign co-production deal and set "The Fox," a French period adventure series, for filming in England next month.
MOSCOW, Feb. 13--A modern American song is the latest addition to the museum honoring the great Russian composer, Peter Ilyitch Tchaikovsky.
Federal and city officials appeared last night to be mildly optimistic about ending the thirteen-day-old tugboat strike.
The announcement that NammLoeser's, Inc., would close its Brooklyn store was received yesterday with expressions of regret by retailers and shoppers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)-- United States exports rose to a record high of nearly $19,000,000,000 last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Longshore union and employer bargaining teams whittled at fringe issues yesterday while the dockers closed down Atlantic Coast ports from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va.
TOMORROW, 2 P.M.: Children aged 3 to 6 years old are invited to a story hour in which "Grandma's Tales For Children" will be told at the Brooklyn Public Library, Grand Army Plaza. Free.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The nation's oil companies were warned today that they were inviting strict Government regulation of their industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb.13--Harold E. Stassen will leave his White House disarmament job early next year to campaign for the Governorship of Pennsylvania.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 --The name of Kim Stanley heads the list of young players who are being sought to fill eight of the lead roles in "Down Payment." Martin Ritt, the director, will meet with Miss Stanley in New York and also intends to conduct screen tests of other promising stage performers there.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13--After some easiness early in today's session on the Board of Trade, wheat ftures rallied, with the July and more forward deliveries staging the best recovery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) --Thomas N. Barbour, a business executive, testified today he bought $200,000 worth of Crowell-Collier Publishing Company debentures under his own name, then distributed all but $30,000 of them to twenty-odd friends and relatives.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- One day soon a vessel flying the United States flag may steam north from the Red Sea into the narrow channel that leads into the Gulf of Aqaba.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13--On the wall of an office here is a mounted large-mouth black bass whose fighting weight was fourteen and three-quarter pounds. It was taken in the St. John's River near Deland.
Federal shipping authorities yesterday tightened their policy on future chartering of Government vessels to private American shipowners.

The annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the New York Women's Bible Society will feature a showing of reproductions of nineteenth-century ball and reception gowns as well as modern fashions. The event will take place next Wednesday in the ballroom of the Pierre.
CHICAGO, Feb.13--The transportation industry was warned today that it faced increased Government regulation unless it "finds imaginative ways to solve its own problems."

A well-known Brooklyn corner passed to new control yesterday with the sale of the twostory taxpayer building at 1 to 9 Flatbush Avenue through to 556 Fulton Street. The property was sold by Bickford's Pension Fund, Inc., to John P. McGrath for investment. The building was held at $375,000. It was sold for cash.

Dr. M. F. Ashley Montagu, who retired from the "$64,000 Question" television show Tuesday night a $32,000 winner, has a new book on World's fall list. Called "Man: His First Million Years," it is an introduction to anthropology. Dr. Montagu is the author of fourteen books including "Introduction to Physical Anthropology" and "The Natural Superiority of Women."
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 13-- Retailers of men's wear today denounced "Government-sponsored" competition in clothing by military post exchanges and naval ship stores.

MIAMI, Feb. 13--Back in 1944, Calumet Farm won Hialeah's Columbiana Handicap with the mare Mar-Kell. Today Calumet won its second Columbiana. The 5-year-old mare that went under the wire in the No. 1 position was Amoret, one of Mar-Kell's offspring.
Nylon, long in use in the synthetic fabric field, is being used to improve the finish of cottons it was disclosed yesterday.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 13 --Leonard W. Hall said today that he had given "no serious consideration" to the prospect of seeking the Republican nomination for Governor in 1958.
The nation's steel industry turned out more steel last month than ever before in any January--11,001,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

ROME, Feb. 13--Pietro Nenni, the Left-wing Socialist leader, regained partial control of his party today. He was reappointed Secretary, which he has been for the last six years, and he won three out of the five places on the party's Executive Committee for himself and two men who share his views.

So long as we have a free public market for any commodity--whether it be cotton or wheat or shares in the nation's industries--we must be prepared to expect periods of declining prices, such as we have been witnessing the last few days, ...
Ski Sketch: Margaret (Meg) Hilly, just turned 3, is not an Olympic skier, but her parents have hopes. Meg has reached the point where she can schuss (ski without turns) down a modest slope.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13--The United States and Britain are planning to ask the Security Council to send Gunnar V. Jarring, its president, to India and Pakistan in an effort to settle the Kashmir dispute.
MADISON, Conn., Feb. 13-- The body of George Sessions Perry was found today in the East River here. The 46-year-old author disappeared two months ago from his home in Guilford, about two miles away.

General Electric, after announcing two years ago what seemed like the ultimate achievement in alchemy --the development of a man-made diamond--now comes along with a synthetic substance as hard as, or harder than, diamonds. This is borazon, composed under great pressure mainly from boron and nitrogen.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 13 --President Eisenhower shot a 22 pound 2 ounce wild turkey today and bagged another batch of quail.

Major crimes committed in the United States rose 12 per cent in 1956 as compared with 1955. Preliminary figures from Albany show a rise of 10.5 per cent in arrests for major crimes for the state as a whole, and of 12.6 per cent for New York City.
One of the most thrilling victories scored in the Olympic Games in Australia was the triumph of the Yale eight-oared crew.

To nobody's surprise the Soviets have reacted to the Eisenhower Doctrine and its growing acceptance in the Middle East with a massive propaganda campaign in which they attack not only the doctrine as such but the whole American foreign policy.
The Potomac Electric Power Company sold $30,000,000 of 25year debentures at competitive bidding yesterday.
Thirteen hundred passengers on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth will spend the last day of a trans-Atlantic crossing to New York aboard a boat-train of the Canadian National Railways.
ALBANY, Feb. 13--The counsel to the Public Service Commission disputed today a claim that pending telephone rate legislation would jeopardize pay increases for telephone employes.

CAIRO, Feb. 13--Egyptian officials today attacked the United States offer to support Israel's right to send ships through the Gulf of Aqaba in exchange for an Israeli withdrawal from Egyptian territory.
Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York exchanges.

ALHAMBRA, Calif., Feb. 13 --Eli Harvey, a sculptor whose studies of animals are at the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx, New York, and in museums throughout the world, died Sunday at the Baldy View Sanitarium, South San Gabriel. His age was 96. He had made his home in Alhambra since 1928.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 13--Princeton scored a one, two sweep in the broad jump, the final event on the program, to win team honors in the Polar Bear track meet for the eighth successive year today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- The White House is considering a vast atomic shelter program that would cost $20,000,000,000 to $40,000,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13--The United States will vote for a General Assembly debate on a Soviet accusation that its "aggressive actions" in the Middle East and elsewhere constitute a threat to peace and security.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 13-- The political murder last week of a young Opposition legislator in the state of Alagoas has brought fears of new violence to the Brazilian Northeast.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13-- Navy's basketball team led all the way except for a few moments in the first half in scoring a 72-66 victory over Franklin and Marshall today.

The "Show Me" state--Missouri--came up yesterday with an answer to the problem of how to cope with the high interest costs in a period of "tight" money. Missouri borrowed $20,000,000 at long term in the public market at the breathtakingly low cost of 2.385 per cent.

Andres Segovia returned to Town Hall on Saturday evening and put his gossamer art on display. The eminent Spanish guitarist played, for a sold-out house, a program of original guitar music and transcriptions.
Use of the old New York City Reformatory at New Hampton, N. Y., as a reception center for youthful lawbreakers from the city was suggested yesterday by the Prison Association of New York.
Marketing dates were set over the week-end on school building bonds totaling $26,477,000 in seven states.
MIAMI, Feb. 18 (AP)--Valley View Farm's Lady Elliott raced to a three and one-quarter length victory in the $5,000 Winter Blossoms Purse at Hialeah today.

The High School of Music and Art, which is threatened with closure, won support yesterday from several quarters. The Board of Education is weighing a plan to give the art and music departments to other schools.
The proceeds of the opening performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus at Madison Square Garden on April 3 will go to the New York City Cancer Committee.

The Maryland Ship building and Drydock Company has deceived a $6,000,000 contract for the enlargement and modernization of two T-2 tankers. The award was announced yesterday by the American Trading and Production Corporation of Baltimore.
Retailers have found a way to combat trading stamps.
Argentina's new privately financed airline, Transcontinental S.A., has ordered four Convair 880 jet airliners.
A warning against excessive storage of kerosene in residen tial dwellings was issued yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. following a fatal fire in a South Brooklyn tenement.

Dealers in garden supplies anticipate a good year. This was evident yesterday at the sixteenth national Garden Supply show in the New York Coliseum. Buying by dealers at the booths of 150 exhibitors was brisk.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- The Secretary of the Interior said today power revenues must be tapped more often to finance reclamation projects.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18--The Security Council postponed a vote on the Kashmir problem today after it had been learned that the Soviet Union intended to veto a resolution sponsored by the United States and three other nations.

The Barium Steel Corporation has declared a cash dividend of 15 cents a share and a stock dividend of 2 per cent. Both are payable April 16 to holders of record March 27. This is the first cash payment since Aug. 30, 1954, when 5 cents a share and a stock dividend of 2 per cent was paid.
The tug strike and unfavorable docking conditions failed to mar the debut here yesterday of the 27,000-ton Italian liner Augustus.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Feb. 18--Dr. Arthur Dudley Whitman, Professor Emeritus of Education at New York University and first Dean of Hofstra College, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. His age was 73.

MAKERS of fishing tackle, who wrack their brains and the brains of their designers a11 year long for new wrinkles, bring them with anxious pride every year to the National Sports and Vacation Show, now open at the Coliseum.
Representatives of the Catholic Youth Organization gained a major share of the honors in the thirty-first annual New York City Golden Gloves finals at Madison Square Garden last night.
VIENNA, Feb. 18--With mines, barbed wire, motor boats and freshly recruited guards, Hungary has refashioned her Iron Curtain along the 220-mile Austrian border.

CAIRO, Feb. 18--A spokesman for Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler indicated today that the United Nations salvage team under his command would not be able to meet the scheduled date for the first phase of Suez Canal clearance.

Joseph Bonaventure Lynch, lawyer and prominent Roman Catholic layman, died on Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 3530 Henry Hudson Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 64 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 18--The Harriman Administration's program to regulate all installment buying in the state got a mixed reception at a public hearing today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Maj. Gen. Ellard A. Walsh charged before a Congressional committee today that the Awmy's new six-month training requirement presaged federalization and extinction of the National Guard.
The British had expected a new outbreak of terrorism in Cyprus to accompany the open ing yesterday of another debate in the United Nations on the future of the embattled island

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 18--Jacob A.L. Moller of Camp Fire Road, Chappaqua, and Yucatan, Mexico, a textile importer and sportsman, died here yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital. His age was 73. He had suffered a stroke last December.

Tight money received support yesterday from an unusual source. James B. Douglas told a group of shopping-center executives that the tight money market "is a good thing which is preventing ruinous competition."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 (UP)--Ingrid Bergman was one of five actresses nominated tonight for an Academy Award by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
Net income of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries rose 4.7 per cent last year to a new high although sales slipped 1 per cent from the peak set in 1955.
DENVER, Feb. 18 (UP)--Gene Fullmer belted Ernie Durando for ten rounds tonight to win his second unanimous decision since he lifted the middleweight boxing crown from Sugar Ray Robinson last month.

VIENNA, Feb. 18--A new onslaught on President Tito of Yugoslavia was delivered yesterday by Enver Hoxha, Albania's Communist leader. He made the attack in a speech to the Central Committee of the Albanian Labor (Communist) party.

The sudden recall of Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, for consultations at home underlines the critical nature of the diplomatic struggle now going on to turn the face of the Middle East toward a peaceful settlement.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York last night selected for the first time a Negro to receive its Distinguished Service Award.
A plaque commemorating Wendell L. Willkie was unveiled yesterday on the wall of the New York Public Library, across the street from Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.
The plan for extending oneway avenue operation in midcity has been postponed again.

Final figures for the Gross National Product of the American economy for 1956, just released by the Department of Commerce, show a total of $412 billion, an increase of $22 billion, or about 5 per cent over the previous peak of $390 billion achieved the previous year.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18 --The Indonesian Communist party has thrown its support behind President Sukarno's call for a "new style" government to help the country surmount her crises.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.,Feb. 18--Another postponement of the General Assembly debate on the Middle East was arranged today to give Israel more time to consider an United States proposal for evacuating the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.

GLEN HEAD, L.I. Feb, 18-- Mr. and Mrs.Dudley H.Mills have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss H. Lee Mills, to John R.Petty, son of Mrs.Anton P.Carlson of Chicago and St.Petersburg, Fla., and the late Dewitt Talmadge Petty. The couple plan to be married on May 11.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) --The Bonneville Power Administration had gross power revenues of $60,992,623 in the fiscal year that ended last June 30. These revenues were the highest for any year since the beginning of service by the Federal Columbia River Power System.

"SPRING LIST" is a bright, fantastic novel about British publishing by a director of Constable Co., London. Our second book for today is "What Happens in Book Publishing," which covers-factually--the American scene. Between the two you will learn many mysteries of art as business and the business of a gallantly surviving art.
ALBANY, Feb. 18--Four Harriman Administration proposals to give New York City $17,400,000 more in state grants were "temporarily deleted" today from the Governor's budget by Republicans.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 18-- Space travel moved formally today out of the field of science fiction into what an Air Force spokesman called the realm of reality.
ALBANY, Feb. 18--A move to put new legal limits on wiretapping was opposed today by New York City law-enforcement officials.

NEARLY a month having gone by without a new Shaw production, the Stage Society has solved the crisis by putting on "Press Cuttings" and "O'Flaherty, V.C." They were acted last evening at the Tempo Playhouse, 4 St. Marks Place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Investigating Senators will have to "pin a rose" on the oil industry for its accomplishments in betting oil to Europe, the president of the American Petroleum Institute predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The renewed argument between management and labor over which has the principal responsibility for the steadily rising price level that has pushed the American economy into inflation will probably never be settled until one of two things happen: an act of statesmanship by management,or an act of Government.

The issues in the tug strike include union demands for a 15 per cent wage increase, additional accident and sick benefits, increased employer pension payments, nine paid holidays and three weeks' vacation pay:

Stocks put on a display of activity and strength at the opening of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. When this failed to generate further enthusiasm, they settled down and drifted lower, finishing with a mild loss.

The Republic Aviation Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to lay off 4,000 Long Island production workers in the next three months. The company said that further cuts might be ordered before the end of the year.

After two postponements, a brace of short plays that is said to have won prizes in Brazil will be assayed tonight at the Provincetown Playhouse. The program, which gets under way at 7:30, is comprised of "Enemies Don't Send Flowers" and "A God Slept Here."

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 18 --The Portuguese nation joyously welcomed Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh today as they landed here from the royal yacht Britannia to start a three-day state visit.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 18--The last resort of 18,000 homeless Hungarians, unwanted in the West and most of them unwilling to settle in Yugoslavia, is to turn back across the border.
WASHINGTOIN, Feb. 18--A Senate subcommittee decided 4 to 2 today to terminate its hearings on civil rights legislation March 5 for a showdown vote.

Total assets of the Bell System--American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its twenty-eight telephone subsidiaties and affiliates--soared beyond $16,000,000,000 in 1956, according to the annual report released yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18-The Soviet Union is backing up its campaign to get people to move to remote and underdeveloped areas of the country with elaborate offers of rewards.
Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that its new giant Lockheed airliners would make their debut on both domestic and overseas routes on July 1.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 18-- Dr.Henry Norris Russell, one of the world's leading astronomers and Professor Emeritus of Astronomy at Princeton University, died today in Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
A five--member interdepartmental committee to survey the sixteen private dumps in the city was appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Administration is about to start a fight in Congress to get control over several Government agencies that now operate virtually on their own.

TEX McCRARY and his wife, Jinx Falkenburg, began a new interview program at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon over Channel 4. It is entitled "Close-up," and in its production technique it is derived from Mike Wallace's "Night Beat."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. urged today that Congress move slowly in creating special antitrust treatment for banks. It was the first time since he took office that he had testified on an antitrust matter.

PARIS, Feb. 18--The foreign ministers of six European nations worked late tonight on the problem of transforming the overseas territories of the European states into a kind of European domain. The territories involved are mainly those in Africa under French rule.

Five tape-recorded conversations between Tibor Foldvary and his mother, Dr. Mary Foldvary, were under official scrutiny yesterday. Part of them dealt with his accusation that she had tried to poison him.
The Brooklyn Museum will open a number of bright new galleries today when it shows off the first stage of a $3,500,000 modernization program.

The apartment house at 810921 Twentieth Avenue, constituting the entire blockfront between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn has been purchased by Leon Sacks from Nachman Nachan. Saul Siller was the broker in the transaction.
Nine days and $43,500. Those were the survival terms meted out yesterday to the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.
The complex relationships between disorders of the lungs and heart failure are being studied at Bellevue Hospital by Columbia University scientists.
A full resumption of longshore work along the East Coast before the end of the Week apgeared unlikely yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--George M. Bragalini, chairman of the State Tax Commission, announced today that six collectors in the New York City offices had been allowed to resign after an inquiry into a shakedown practice.

BECAUSE of the demand for seats, the Metropolitan Opera, for the first time in its history, is giving a third "Ring" cycle this season. Last night, "Das Rheingold," the first of the music dramas of the Wagnerian tetralogy, began the third of the cycles on its stirring way.
LAKE WORTH, Fla., Feb. 18 (UP)--The Cavalcade of Champions golf tournament got off to a rough start today for Phil Rizzuto.
The new Lincoln Tunnel Expressway, an $11,000,000 "jigsaw puzzle," will open today with appropriate fanfare.
TRENTON, Feb. 18--Gov. Robert B. Meyner submitted to the Legislature today a record New Jersey budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
The New England Power Company yesterday raised $10,000,000 on 4 3/8 per cent thirty-year first mortgage bonds.

A Polish group is scheduled to depart today from Warsaw to negotiate with our Government regarding possible United States-Polish economic cooperation. The major political changes which made this mission possible took place last October in Warsaw, and the present mission is another sign of the growing independence and sovereignty of Poland.
CHICAGO, Feb.18--The American Bar Association approved today a proposal to combat communism by having its meaning explained in colleges and high schools throughout the country.
Dave Polansky, the City College basketball coach, got the Irish up yesterday. In this case it was Ned Irish, executive director of Madison Square Garden.
Wool prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Heavy speculator liquidation touched off stop-loss selling. Trade buying on a scaledown basis absorbed the offerings.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 18 (AP) --Rabbi Joseph Rauch, one of Louisville's formost religious personalities died in his sleep last night. He was 76 years old.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 18--The chief of the North Atlantic Treaty armed forces pressed today his campaign against military cuts by the fifteen member nations.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 18 --President Eisenhower will fly back to Washington tomorrow to take personal, on-the-spot charge of United States policy in the tense Middle Eastern situation.

Leaders of the paper industry took a calm view yesterday of a current problem--overcapacity. They expressed confidence that the problem was a short-term one that could be met by development of new markets and more orderly management of new plant investments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) --The Senate Select Committee on Labor and Management Practices said tonight that a New York carpenters' union official under committee subpoena had been "threatened with bodily harm if he talks to us."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 --President Eisenhower paid tribute to Walt Disney last night as an artist whose "genius as a creator of folklore" has won universal recognition.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 18 (UP)--The 6,643-ton collier Reading ran aground on a rocky ledge near the entrance to this harbor today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18--Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, said tonight that the Kremlin's foreign policy remained the same despite the personnel changes in the Foreign Ministry.

The final act began yesterday at the Brooklyn store of Namm-Loeser's, Inc., a borough fixture since 1886. It was a crowd scene. By 9:30 A. M., an estimated total of 2,500 shoppers had lined up behind police barriers for the "liquidation sale" that began one minute later.
Basketball coaches say that Tom Stith of St. Francis Prep is the leading high school player in the metropolitan area. The record books say pretty much the same.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company has sold the eleven-story apartment house at 14 East Seventy-fifth Street, at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue, to a syndicate represented by Harry J, Riker.
Carl T.Gossett Jr. of The New York Times and Jack O'Brien of The Journal-American were named yesterday as winners of the principal 1956 awards of the Press Photographers Association of New York.
ALBANY, Feb. 18--The Senate approved tonight a proposed constitutional amendment to legalize bingo on a local-option basis. The vote was 44 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-The Israelis would go to war again rather than give up or risk the freedom of passage through the Gulf of Aqaba they won in their Sinai campaign, according to reports reaching the State Deparartment.

Stefan Redl gained the decision over Paddy De Marco, former lightweight champion of the world, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The verdict in favor of Redl was unanimous and was boisterously greeted by the crowd of 1,980.

LOS ALTOS, Calif., Feb. 18-- Col. Ray T. Elsmore, the former Army Air Forces officer who arranged Gen. Douglas MacArthur's flight from the Philippines to Australia early in World War II, died of a heart atttack yesterday at his home in Los Altos hills. He was 66 years old.
ALTHOUGH Georges Neveux clipped the poetry from "El Perro del Hortelano" when he turned it into "Le Chien du Jardinier," he groomed its humor for 1957.

Something has gone out of the world of music with the death of Josef Hofmann. He was a symbol, a landmark, almost an institution. It is hard to imagine the piano in our time without him. Perhaps in these more recent years we took him too much for granted.

The number of infant deaths before and dust after birth has been cut almost in half in the last five years at Kings County Hospital Center. Since as many people die in this period as in the next forty years of life, this gain was represented yesterday as a major medical achievement.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Donald C. Lillis, the president of Bowie race track, charged today that a proposal to close Pimlico was a move by Laurel to monopolize Maryland horse racing.
The Arosa Line, a comparative newcomer to trans-Atlantic passenger shipping, will enter the New York to Europe service in May.
LONDON, Feb. 18-A Nazi plan to insure the failure of German-Polish negotiations and thus provide a propaganda excuse for Hitler to launch his attack on Poland and World War II was revealed today.

ABOUT 4 O'clock one morning a week ago, after hectic hours of trying to wring concessions from feuding longshore union leaders and waterfront employers, a tired man sat idly rearranging pieces of hard candy on his desk.

Dr.Leonard Greenburg became New York City's first Commissioner of Air Pollution Control in November, 1952. Now, nearly five years later, he has acknowledged his disappointment with the results of educational work and friendly persuasion to voluntary compliance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-Lyn. don B. Johnson of Texas, Senate Democratic leader, admonished President Eisenhower today to avoid "coercion" in United States relations with Israel.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 18 (AP)--Wilt Chamberlain fouled out with only 11 points but Ron Loneski came through with 28 as Kansas whipped Oklahoma, 76-56, tonight to maintain its Big Seven basketball leadership.
MILAN, Italy, Feb. 18 (UP)-- Arturo Toscanini was buried here tonight.
The Soviet Union spends more money jamming radio broadcasts than the Western nations spend on all their cultural and informational activities, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A Federal grand jury indicted Arthur Miller, playwright, today on charges of contempt of Congress. He had refused to name names before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
The State Attorney General yesterday accused a New York broker and his Canadian associate of a stock fraud in which buyers of Canadian mining shares lost at least $6,000,000.
The tunes on "pour Hit Parade" will be sung by a completely new cast of singers beginning in the fall.

The Adelphi Theatre, 152 West Fifty-fourth Street, will revert to the legitimate fold on March 31. Until recently, the 1,400-seat house, which was leased from the Shuberts by the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., had been used as a television studio.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18--Following are the texts of resolutions on the Cyprics question, presented by Greece and Britain, that were debated today in the General Assembly's Political Committee:
WARRENTON, Mo., Feb. 18 (UP)--A nursing home destroyed by a flash fire that killed seventy-one persons here yesterday was disclosed today to have been operating without a license.
Negotiations to end the eighteen-day tugboat strike were called off early this morning with no date set for a new meeting.

HAVANA, Feb. 18--The American yacht Glider, sailed by Richard Stearns of the Wilmette Harbor fleet, Chicago, was over the line first today in a surprise finish in the second race of the Bacardi Cup series of the twenty-fifth annual International Star Class regatta.
The North Carolina Tar Heels, who need only four more victories for an undefeated campaign, led the Kansas Jayhawks by 19 points yesterday in The United Press basketball ratings.

TRENTON, Feb. 18--The State Supreme Court ruled today that boardwalk and amusement park games of "skill" were illegal no matter what type of prize was awarded to players. The 6-to-1 decision also made it clear that operators of such games were illegally maintaining places to which people "resort for gambling" in violation of the New Jersey Constitution.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 18--The Sudan has decided to ask the United States for economic and military assistance. This was disclosed today by Premier Abdullah Khalil, who said Vice President Richard M. Nixon would visit Khartoum March 14.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18-- From $3,500,000,000 to $6,000,OO0,000 annually in Federal aid to public schools was asked here today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 18 (AP)--A young woman medical student testified today in Hungary's first major public trial of rebels that she had disabled a Soviet tank with a hand grenade and had killed a security policeman.

CAIRO, Feb. 17--The mass departure of Jews and foreign residents of Egypt is continuing unabated, according to the best available sources. But the number of persons expelled by official order has dwindled to almost nil.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18--Israel presented to the United States tonight a new set of proposals for breaking the deadlock over the future of the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18--Strength in corn futures was the main feature on the Board of Trade today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18-Britain called on the United Nations today for "redress" by the Government of Greece for alleged instigation of terrorism in Cyprus.
Hundreds of passers-by in the busy theatrical district witnessed a real-life melodrama last evening.

Current discussions about Middle Eastern refugees at the United Nations are emphasizing what everybody, knew before: that behind the principles, policies and programs that cause international controversies there are always people in trouble. In the Middle East too many of those now concerned show less interest in relieving human wants than in using them for political purposes.

WHEN Ted Williams finally completes his baseball career, it's a cinch that the State Department won't invite him to join the diplomatic corps. No diplomat is Theodore Samuel Williams. The big Red Sox slugger speaks too frankly and he's even less tactful now than he was in his younger days. He was no great bargain then.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18-- Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind ruled from a hospital bed today in favor of California on a basic issue in this state's battle with Arizona over Colorado River water.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 17--When Vice President Richard M. Nixon visits Ethiopia next month he will find her preparing for her first popular elections.
ALBERT FULLER, harpsichordist who made his debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, is no antiquarian.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, estimated today that a surprise enemy attack would kill about 50 per cent of the American people, regardless of whether they had bomb shelters.
THE art of deviltry was rampant last night on the intimate stage of the Blackfriars Guild, the Roman Catholic experimental little-theatre group on West Fiftyseventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- The House Veterans Committee turned down today a move to increase G.I. home loan interest rates and approved a bill to spur new G.I. housing in rural and small town areas.
WASHIGTON, Feb. 18--Tax reform rather than over-all that reduction was signaled today as the Democratic leader ship's probable policy for nest year.

The New York State Bankers Association and the American Bankers Association have offered to make a free analysis of costs and earnings for most of the state's smaller commercial banks, to determine what rate of interest they can afford to pay on their savings deposits.
Asserting that the moral support of refugees escaping tyranny was not enough, Mayor Wagner said yesterday that "America should keep its doors open to those who flee from repression and persecution."

The University of Dayton and the University of Cincinnati basketball teams yesterday accepted bids to play in the twentieth annual National Invitation Tournament starting March 16 at Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb, 18--An official of the Liberal party told a conference of legislators tonight that the party remained adamant in opposing a state power contract with the Reynolds Metals Corporation.
The City and County of San Francisco, Calif., sold yesterday eight issues of bonds amounting to $23,610,000 to a syndicate managed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

LIKE many European artists, Marc Chagall has given to the graphic media a great deal of his time and inspiration. At The Contemporaries Gallery, 992 Madison Avenue, his marked affinity for printmaking is best revealed in the black-and-white series of illustrations for La Fontaine's "Fables."
TRENTON, Feb. 18--Meade Alcorn called on New Jersey Republicans today to make an all-out effort to win the Governorship in November.
Charles Van Doren met his match in a woman attorney last night.
A ninetieth birthday party was held last night for Homer Folks, one of the most accomplished social workers this nation has known.

AMERICANS have enthusiastically adopted the robust salamis of Italy. But they are confused by the varieties, as numerous as the regional dialects and cuisines of Italy. What, they ask, is the difference between a salami from Milan and one from Genoa, Cremona or Parma?

Manhattan beat City College, 72--68, in an exciting intracity basketball game last night at the Fordham gymnasium.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 19-- A general strike of Greek Cypriotes paralyzed Nicosia, Famagusta and Limassol today. It was called to support Greek Cypriote demands for the end of British rule and a union with Greece.
Had your cookbook today? The country is being flooded with cookbooks by the millions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19--The United States, Britain, France and Norway submitted a joint proposal today for interim operation of the Suez Canal. The waterway is scheduled to be partly reopened next month.

An influential Chinese business man and civic leader here was convicted yesterday in Federal court as the behind-thescenes leader of a conspiracy to bring Chinese nationals into this country illegally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--The Senate cited for contempt today four officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. They had refused to answer certain questions before the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation last year was $45,705,188, including the earnings of the Motors Insurance Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary. The profit was 29 per cent above the $35,276,581 earned in 1955.
A new method of food distribution, which could become a big factor in consumer prices, became an actuality yesterday.

HAVANA, Feb. 19--A Cuban yacht, Kurush IV, today won the Bacardi Cup series of the twenty-fifth annual International Star Class regatta when a 22-year-old skipper, Alvaro de Cardenas, guided it first across the finish line in the third race.
ALBANY, Feb. 19--A legislative committee with the task of plugging loopholes in the Compulsory Automobile Insurance Law declined unanimously today to make any recommendations on the subject.
The Government moved yesterday to collect a $555,000 "windfall" assertedly shared by nine stockholders in two Queens County housing corporations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19--Greece charged today that Britain had made "fake deliveries" of arms to Cyprus.

SOME men perfect strangers to each other look surprisingly alike. What would happen if they exchanged places? Could they get away with it? Would physical resemblance, quickness of wit and luck be enough? The idea has fascinated writers for generations. So we have had novels, plays...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)-- A Negro leader warned today that he could not "predict what mood might be enbendered" among Southern Negroes if they did not get "a minimum guarantee" of constitutional nights.
TIRED of the dimly lit "intimacy" of many smart restaurants, we were prepared to like the new Chateau Henri IV almost immediately. For it is well illuminated, airy and fairly roomy.

Business men, diplomats and bankers gathered yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange for ceremonies to mark the listing of the American depositary receipts of Montecatini Societa Generale per I'Industria Mineraria e Chimica Anonima ...
A "campus" where American industry will conduct basic research and on which its scientists will live, work and play is to arise adjacent to Tuxedo Park, N.Y., forty miles from the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce said today it was delaying temporarily the issuance of export licenses for scrap iron to Japan, Britain and the six-nation European Coal and Steel Community.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States "would deplore it very much" if Egypt were to delay reopening the Suez Canal.

Bob Cousy's one-hander with two seconds remaining enabled the Boston Celtics to defeat the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Eastern Division's pace-setting Celtics won by 112 to 110.

The Anaconda Company trimmed its price of refined copper 2 cents a pound yesterday to 32 cents, the same level quoted since Monday by the other "big three" producers, the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

Hungary's Communist tyrants have restored the Iron Curtain on the Austro-Hungarian border. Once again miles of barbed wire bar refugees' way to freedom, while thousands of land mines lie in the ground ready to kill or maim any Hungarian who seeks escape to the West.
The Public Service Commission moved yesterday in two directions to bring relief, or at least the hope of it, to many New York commuters.
ALBANY, Feb. 19--Mayor Wagner was urged today to investigate whether the city's "traffic-ticket war against motorists" could be ended.
Funds for short-term lending seem suddenly to abound in the New York money market, temporarily at least. Yesterday, rates on time loans were cut by ...
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 19 --The high spirits being displayed by the Duke of Edinburgh on his visit here caused sympathetic comment among Portuguese and foreigner alike today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--The Middle Eastern situation has been made to look much worse than it actually is as a result of a lot of vague public threats that nobody in authority here is really thinking of carrying out.
The nation's paper industry was advised yesterday to look abroad for an important part of its need for new markets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that it would be "premature, to say the least," to talk now about recognizing Communist China.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19--United Nations efforts to raise funds for relief work in Hungary have brought in $86,000.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19--Bill France loves fast automobiles, and as president of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, he sees, drives and commands thousands of them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)-- An Administration officials said today the demand for building materials and money must be lessened before the Government's lease-purchase building program could be resumed.
The North German Lloyd, one of the oldest lines active in North Atlantic steam navigation will celebrate its 100th anniversary today.

HONG KONG, Feb. 19--The Peiping radio announced tonight the formation in Communist China's capital of a "Working Committee for the Peaceful Liberation of Taiwan."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19--A prominent Syrian political exile was slain here today. The shooting may provoke an international political crisis.
ALBANY, Feb. 19--Harrison M. Tweed was told today that the court reorganization program offered by his commission faced defeat unless it was modified.
Medical science reportedly has conquered a type of heart disease that ten years ago was killing virtually all its victims.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 19-- Settlement of the Algerian struggle for independence from France continues to be the main preoccupation of Tunisia.
The Lincoln Tunnel Expressway was dedicated yesterday in a silent ceremony.

The field director of the Catholic Relief Services in Austria asserted yesterday that if "immoral and obscene" conditions in overcrowded refugee camps were not relieved, "hundreds of Hungarians" would elect to return to their homeland.

FISHING dominates the National Sports and Vacation Show in the Coliseum, Hunting gets short shrift, whatever short shrift may be. That is largely because the big firearms-and-ammunition companies do not see fit to exhibit at such shows.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19-- The ideas and plans that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and the men around him dread most for India's sake are outlined in a little booklet with a picture of a burning oil lamp on its cover.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) --A rapid transit system between Philadelphia and southern New Jersey ought to be built by the Delaware River Port Authority, Mayor Richardson Dilworth said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 19--The Republican-controlled Legislature sought today to fix the blame on Democratic mayors for slum conditions in the New York metropolitan area.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 19--The nation still operates on an oxcart system of school districts, a report made public here today charged.

Armed with paint brushes and a handful of rhymed slogans, the Long Island Rail Road is taking advantage of ready-made advertising space in an effort to woo harried motorists back to its passenger ranks.

On both sides of the Capitol the proponents of civil rights legislation are edging forward toward an inevitable showdown with the diehard opposition.
Louis B. Seltzer, chairman of National Brotherhood Week, declared yesterday that international brotherhood was "the greatest single challenge facing humanity today."

ALBANY, Feb. 19--An outlay of $903,400,000 in state and Federal funds for new highway construction in New York City over the next twelve years was recommended today by the Temporary Highway Finance Commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) --The House Agriculture Committee overrode Republican opposition today and approved a Democratic plan to expand soil bank payments to farmers.

IF the Manzoni Requiem Mass is not Verdi's great est masterpiece, it comes close. It is a work that deserves to be performed with intensity and grandeur, and it had that kind of performance at Carnegie Hall last night.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19--The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association tabled today a report opposing the Bricker amendment.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19--A reunified neutral Germany on the Austrian pattern has been suggested as a "theoretical" possibility by Franz-Josef Strauss, West German Minister of Defense.
Southern California Edison Company yesterday raised $37,500,000 at a cost of 4.29 per cent on twenty-five-year first and refunding mortgage bonds.
THE common passion for organization seizes on al most everyone in every field, even among men who once made a livelihood through fisticuffs.
LONDON, Feb. 19--The stock markets here remained quietly firm today with little change in prices and buying still selective.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it would terminate its connection with the TV-Radio Workshop next month. The workshop, underwritten by the foundation since 1951, produces the "Omnibus" program on television.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 19-- Three Navy attack planes accidentally shot up a Coast Guard lighthouse in Chesapeake Bay last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--A legislator who has dealt for a decade with problems of mass destruction through nuclear weapons looks back wistfully to the days when he dispensed soothing syrups for babies.

Automobile clubs are not often caught advocating or even acquiescing in a gasoline tax increase. So the words of the New York State Automobile Association, an A.A.A. affiliate, in its Feb. 18 Legislative Newsletter should be engraved in the record.

There is reason for encouragement and hope in the word from Johns Hopkins University that significant advances have been made in the development of vaccine to provide immunization against encephalitis and dengue fever. Both have been formidable and mysterious foes.
Futures prices on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. Cocoa registered the largest volume of the year but most other markets were dull and featureless.

One can only describe as highly unfortunate the action of the House Veterans Committee in turning down the Administration-backed proposal to raise the interest rate on guaranteed G.I. home building loans from its present level of 4 per cent to 5 per cent.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday dropped its plans to have an independent citizens' committee investigate charges of Communist affiliation against two union organizers.

PARIS, Feb. 19--Six European Premiers spent about eight hours today in a vain effort to reach agreement on the main lines of a treaty to create a common market, or customs union, embracing their countries and overseas territories. They will try again tomorrow.

NOT far behind the cabled reports of the European col lections come the fashion buyers back to New York, bearing the ideas that will influence the American look for months to come.

Reflecting the 4.1 per cent drop in sales, net income of the B.F. Goodrich Company last year declined 6.2 per cent to $43,765,431 from the record $46,662,127 earned in 1955.

John J. O'Rourke took over last night as New York head of the much-investigated International Brotherhood of Teamsters and had a cheery message for any of his associates who might find themselves afoul of the law.

The Travelers Insurance Companies achieved gains in 1956 premium volume in almost every major line written, as well as new records in life insurance in force, according to the annual report released yesterday.

And now the two teams have made a mass exchange of players and that probably looks like another kissing bee.
