OBERLIN, Ohio, Feb. 24-- A memorial service was held in Fairchild Chapel this afternoon for Dr. Oscar Jaszi, Professor Emeritus of Political Science at Oberlin College, who died here Feb. 13 at the age of 81.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24-- Failure to do what Manager Bill Rigney today called the "little things" hurt the Giants and made them a sixth-place ball club last season.
COLUMBUS, Feb. 24 (AP)-- Negotiators announced today the end of the seven-month telephone strike in southeastern Ohio.
The National Lawyers Guild proposed yesterday that the Attorney General make available to defense lawyers data "concerning the lack of credibility" of Government witnesses in Smith Act cases.

The busiest man at Colgate University on a recent afternoon was Mark Randall, the Red Raiders' varsity swimming coach. It was a day on which the Maroon's new football coach had been announced and the day on which the all-important basketball game with Syracuse was to take place.

Wall Street is getting a first-hand taste these days of the real meaning of the world "underwriter." Often the term is used, in error, to mean a financial interest that buys securities outright, either for immediate resale or to hold for investment.

In presenting the issue of the disposition of Western New Guinea to the Political Committee of the General Assembly last. Saturday the Indonesian representative declared that this was simply "a problem of freedom versus colonialism."
The Republicans fired their first shot yesterday in this year's battle over state rent control.
The Eastman Kodak Company last year had record sales and earnings, Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and Albert K. Chapman, president, reported over the week-end.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 24-- There probably is as much sensibility as there is sense behind the, latest crisis in FrenchMoroccan relations.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 24 --Gene Buck, song writer, discoverer of stage stars and for many years a leader in the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died today in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. His age was 71.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 24 (AP)--Two Scandinavian Airlines System planes opening a Copenhagen-Tokyo route crossed paths near the North Pole tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)-- Charles Edmundson, former aide of the United States Information Agency officer in Korea, offered this reason today why the United States Government did not want American newsmen to go to Red China:
The first physical alteration in the Lincoln Square area looking to the proposed $228,000,000 redevelopment got under way yesterday.

The appointment of a citizens committee to investigate the effect of the city's 5 per cent amusement tax upon the financial condition of motion picture theatres was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
The Columbia English instructor and the woman lawyer tied again for the second week last night on the National Broadcasting Company's television quiz "Twenty-One."

LONDON, Feb. 25--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan rejected today the idea of sanctions against Israel and proposed that the United Nations assume responsibility for both the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Some recent television panel interviews with men in office who have been saying publicly what they don't believe privately are responsible for the dream transcribed below. Under the TV panel system each questioner must have his inning: hence each line of inquiry is broken off before the subject can be pinned down to the spot he really is on.
Earnings of the American Viscose Corporation dropped 39.6 per cent to $14,909,000 in 1956 from $24,709,000 in the year before. Sales were off 7.7 per cent.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25--Don Larsen was still an unsigned Yankee today.
W. Wayne Durham, a Brooklyn scholar who listens to books on records and takes his notes in Braille, has made the Dean's List at Columbia College.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Bill Radovich, the winner of a legal ruling against pro football, said today his chief motive had been to prove "that a player shouldn't be treated like a piece of furniture."
ALBANY, Feb. 25 (AP)--Governor Harriman says the state should move "right away" on development of a $2,500,000 ski center on Whiteface Mountain.
Here's an answer for someone who suggests taking an advertisement in an "official program" for Armed Forces Day:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--J. Albert Woll resigned today as general counsel of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
NICE, France, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Mark Aldanov, author of "Before the Deluge" and other books, died today of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.
About 7 per cent of the milk ordinarily shipped to wholesalers for the metropolitan area was reported withheld by farmers yesterday in a widening demonstration seeking higher prices.

A twenty-one-year lease on 80,000 square feet of space at 59-61 Dey Street has been taken by the Bankers Trust Company. The deal, involving an aggregate rental in excess of $1,300,000, was negotiated by Charles L. Goldenberg of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

FOR the first time in seven years Frederick Childs is showing paintings, at the Passedoit Gallery. 121 East Fiftyseventh Street. He offers straightforward still-lifes and figure studies related in style to the post-Cubist works of Picasso.
The Reynolds Metals Company last year had the highest sales and earnings in its history, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--Republican-controlled legislative committees tonight slashed $30,810,482 from Governor Harriman's record $1,617,400,000 budget.

Buying by Cuban interests opened the world sugar contract sharply higher in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trade hedge selling and profit taking lowered quotations from the highs, but the market firmed again about noon and moved in narrow ranges the rest of the session.

As a guest who arrived very early for dinner recently (in a Greenwich Village apartment), we had a chance to watch a slender and intense young Cuban prepare dishes typical of his native island. Pablo Fagundo, now a food technician here, cooked dried salt cod in a spicy tomato sauce and an herb-and-spiceseasoned combination of rice and vegetables.
LONDON, Feb. 25--Britain's battleships probably have fought their last sea fights and sailed in their last maneuvers.
HAVANA, Feb. 25--Censorship of the Cuban press and radio will be lifted tomorrow, according to an announcement today by Dr. Santiago Rey, Minister of Interior.

HAVANA, Feb. 25--The old master of the Grand Prix and sports car racing world, Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina, gave a demonstration of his great skill today in winning the first international Gran Premio of Cuba.
Two top-seeded contract bridge teams trailed their opponents last night at the halfway mark of the semi-final round of the twenty-ninth annual Vanderbilt Cup Championship.

A mutual admiration society that blossomed as a result of their managerial association with Mary Martin's "Peter Pan" has been reactivated by Richard Halliday, Miss Martin's husband, and Edwin Lester, head of the Los Angeles and San Francisco ...
Helen Sewell, illustrator, died Sunday in New York Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 60.
The largest and most important part of the Edward G. Robinson art collection was sold yesterday for between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000.
Seven Marshall Field awards for outstanding contributions to the wellbeing of children were presented yesterday in ceremonies here, other cities in the United States and in Puerto Rico.
The brave new world that provides Pennsylvania Railroad reservations by a combination of a closed television circuit and automation was struggling to prove itself yesterday.
The Liberal party and unions that strongly supported Averell Harriman for Governor in 1954 took sharp issue with him yesterday on the sale of hydroelectric power developed, by the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Kyriakos Varvaressos, Greek economist and banker, died Friday in George Washington Hospital. He was 72 years old. A funeral service was held this morning in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sophia.

Following is the text of a statement, in question-and-answer form, prepared by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, on the board's position on integration in the city's public schools:
ROME, Feb. 25--The Italian Government is considering easing its terms for oil concessions.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--Governor Harriman requested John P. McGrath today to continue temporarily as New York's representative on the bi-state Waterfront Commission.
The Supreme Court's decision that professional football is subject to Federal Antitrust laws yesterday was a "great disappointment" to Bert Bell, the commissioner of the National Football League.

Governor Harriman's approval of contracts for sale of St. Lawrence River power to the Reynolds Metals Company and the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation is a triumph of the practical over the political.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) --The Supreme Court today upheld unanimously a Federal Trade Commission order requiring individual concerns to stop selling lead pigments under a zone delivery price system.
Though Mayor Wagner parried questions on whether he would seek the Mayoralty again, the opinion in official circles yesterday was that he would decide to run next fall.

PARIS has handed women a variegated bouquet of spring fashions. By day there is a daisy-fresh sim plicity that is crisp and young. In contrast, night-blooming fashions are wildly exotic, with the splendor of the Orient pervading after dusk. On the eve of the collections the atmosphere crackled with excitement over what appeared to be the single major fashion question for the year--the status of the skirt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) ----Georgia school officials opposed today Federal aid to state school construction programs. They said it could lead to Federal "administrative" commands to end racial segregation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)-- The Administration will ask Congress soon to repeal the $2,500,000,000 Federal loan provision of the Flood Insurance and Reinsurance Law.

The plight and persecution of Jewish people in Egypt was described here yesterday by three Jewish refugees. They included a 42-year-old woman who had been born of American citizens in Cairo. She held an American passport.

Crimes against the person-- murder, rape, felonious assault and non-negligent manslaughter --rose 9 per cent in this city last year. This rise came despite an over-all decrease of 1.8 per cent in major crimes.
JAMES THURBER once wrote a wonderful short story about baseball and titled it, "You Could Look It Up." You can look up the following item, too. And it isn't fiction. It is fact.

"THE DEFENDER," an original courthouse dra ma by Reginald Rose, is being presented in two parts on Studio One over Channel 2. The first half was seen last night and the second part will be offered next Monday evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Resistance to the Eisenhower Administration's Middle East resolution is rising in the Senate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford today termed the nation's armed forces "adequate" for any war that might follow a surprise nuclear attack or result from Communist aggression against an ally.

The series of articles which this newspaper completes today on Cuba provides food for thought, above all, on the evils of censorship. The evils of dictatorship are legion in themselves, and Cuba offers no exception to them, except in degree. However, until Jan. 15 President Fulgencio Batista had avoided the mistake of trying to muzzle the press.
The Russians inadvertently chose the fifteenth anniversary of the Voice of America yesterday to present a strange indictment against the United States in a committee of the U.N. General Assembly.

ALL kinds of suggestions have been made recently for the purpose of making hunting safer and hunters more responsible. One of them is to require all hunters to pass the hunter safety course before buying their first license.
The branch banking issue is coming to a head in New York State.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- United States officials said today that legal obstacles to aiding Poland with surplus agricultural commodities had been largely cleared away.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25--Consumption of lithium, a strategic mineral under experimentation as a fuel for guided missiles, has soared about ten times in five years, an authority reported today. Percy E. Landolt estimated that use of lithium in this country in 1956 exceeded 32,000,000 pounds, in terms

ROME, Feb. 25--The tiny Republican party, which has only five seats in the Chamber of Deputies, served notice on Premier. Antonio Segni today that in the future he was not to take its support for granted.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 (AP)--An estimated $600,000 in bets during Tropical Park's racing season was attributed today to Tropical's president, Saul Silberman, by a Florida Racing Commission hearing witness. The witness also said that 116 telephone calls were made from the track to Cleveland during the forty-threeday period.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25-- Any Giant who so much as sips a glass of beer between now and the night of March 9 will be fined, Manager Bill Rigney told his players today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- James Paul Mitchell, a big man with blue eyes, hunched shoulders and bushy hair, quietly occupies what used to be one of the hottest jobs in Washington.

The Consumer Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics rose twotenths of a point between mid-December and mid-January, or slightly less than two-tenths of 1 per cent. The latest figure of the index is 118.2, which means that it now stands 18.2 per cent above the base period, 1947-49, and 3.6 points, or 3.1 per cent, above its level of a year ago.
The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial enterprise, showed a decline of 28.8 per cent in earnings last year on a sales drop of 13.2 per cent from 1955.
Owners of 123,944 shares in the former Hudson Motor Car Company were told yesterday that their stock is worth $9.81 a share.

ANYONE who likes the American Southwest will like. "The Hell Bent Kid."* This is a novel about Texas and New Mexico in the Eighteen Eighties when travel after dark through the deserts and mountains might be as dangerous, say, as a midnight stroll in Central Park is now.

Mayor Robert F. Wagner pressed a button and snipped a strip of ticker tape yesterday. The first act rang the gong that started trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The second officially opened the exchange's new exhibit hall at 20 Broad Street.

THE features of last night's "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera came in threes. "Siegfried" is the third musicdrama in the Wagnerian tetralogy. This was its third production of the season in the Metropolitan's third "Ring" cycle.
The Board of Education made clear its position on integration yesterday. It said, in effect, that the school officials would continue to eliminate segregation wherever possible in the school system.
BOMBAY, India, Feb. 25 (Reuters)--Reports tonight from Bangalore said one person was killed and fifteen were injured in election clashes between rival political groups in two near-by towns on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25--Reopening today after an extended week-end, wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade bogged down in early trading but later rallied rather briskly, advancing about 2 cents a bushel in both old and new crop positions.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 24-- There are 10,000,000 Algerians in Algeria, but that fear-ridden country is no place these days to meet them.
Private placement, which last year accounted for about 30 per cent of the estimated total of $11 billion of new capital raised by corporations, is in for tighter regulation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Three important ambassadorial vacancies--in Paris, Bonn and Canberra--were filled today by President Eisenhower.
In the past five years the number of pupils in the nation's public schools has increased by 5.5 million, and in the next five years it will jump by another 6 million.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 25--Premier David Ben-Gurion said tonight that recognition of Israel's right to use force to keep the Gulf of Aqaba open to her shipping would be the best guarantee of her use of the waterway she could expect.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 25-- A bequest of 170 acres to Westchester County for perpetual use as a public arboretum of trees, shrubs and botanical gardens was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Two private utility units reported to Congress today that the first commercial production of nuclear electrical power was going to be more expensive than originally estimated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Premier Guy Mollet of France arrived today for two days of general conversations with President Eisenhower.
TORONTO, Feb. 25 (AP)--Konstantin Paets, last President of the Estonian republic, presumably died last year as a prisoner of the Soviet Union, his brother reported last night.
MADRID, Feb. 25--Generalissimo Francisco Franco completed tonight the first major shuffle of the Spanish Cabinet since 1951.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 25 (AP)--George C. (Bugs) Moran, a Chicago gangster of the prohibition era, died of lung cancer in the Federal penitentiary here today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 25--A lighting company pole that has figured in five fatal automobile accidents since 1949 heads a list of traffic hazards that Huntington Township offi cials are seeking to have eliminated along New York State Route 25A.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 25 (Reuters)--The police surrounded at least four Western legations in Budapest today and detained Hungarian visitors leaving the buildings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the general public could not be deprived of a rugged literary diet solely because it might be harmful to youth.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 --Warren Giles, the president of the National League, dropped in today for a call on Walter O'Malley, Brooklyn's bombshell tosser.
Merger of the Harris-Seybold Company, Cleveland, Ohio, and the Intertype Corporation, was approved yesterday by directors of both companies, subject to approval by shareholders.
Stocks, which have gained in only five of the last sixteen trading days, again drifted lower yesterday, with volume light and only a double-handful of issues standing out firmly against the trend.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- The Supreme Court today, in a 6-to-3 ruling, placed professional football under the antitrust laws.
A shadowy figure linked by the Government to a Russian espionage apparatus was identified yesterday as Boris Morros, Russian-born Hollywood producer and music director.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--Well-informed delegates said tonight that a solution was in sight that would result in Israel's withdrawal from the Gulf of Aqaba area. They said, however, that a solution of the Gaza Strip problem remained in doubt.

William Worthy Jr., one of three newsmen who recently visited Communist China in the face of State Department disapproval, filed application yesterday for a renewal of his passport. It expires on March 4. A renewal would normally be for two years.
Taking advantage of the balmy weather the Port of New York Authority started to train patrolmen for "high perch" traffic duty yesterday. The purpose of the program is to

An investing syndicate represented by Louis Levine has acquired the one-story supermarket building completed recently at 111 North Avenue in New Rochelle, N.Y. The property was sold by the North and Locust Building Corporation, the builder. Abbott Adams, Inc., and Murray Adler were co-brokers in the deal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- President Eisenhower broadcast to the world today an appeal for peace, justice and freedom.

The general fund of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will receive the proceeds of the Toyland Dinner Dance in the Persian Room of the Plaza on May 13. The organization serves more than 5,000 blind persons in the Greater New York area.
Dates have been set for up to $340,000,000 in five major state and public authority bond issues.
An interesting thing has happened in Tokyo. Japan has had a change of Premiers without any suggestion of a Cabinet "crisis."
The boycott of extracurricular lar activities in the city will continue, the High School Teachers Association declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Davis Grant, Assistant Attorney General of Texas, denounced today proposed civil rights bills as "basically bad legislation."
ALBANY, Feb. 25--An intensive behind-the-scenes battle is being waged in the Legislature by the apparel industry to prevent a $6,500,000-a-year increase in its unemployment insurance taxes.

"Producers' Showcase" is arranging what it believes to be television's first big magic show for presentation May 27. Featuring seven magicians from various countries, the ninety-minute show will be televised in color by the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Three motions were filed in Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Government from selling three-fourths of its stock holdings in General Aniline and Film Corporation. These holdings amount to nearly $110,000,000.

SALTPOND, Gold Coast, Feb. 24--Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of the new West African state of Ghana, which will come into being March 6, said today that he was determined to eradicate bribery and corruption from the country.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--The Senate approved tonight by a vote of 46 to 8 a one-year extension of the security risk law.

The public hearings of the Select Committee on Labor and Management Practices, Senator McClellan chairman, will be supercharged with consequence--for labor, the public and the political future of the members of the committee themselves.
Willi Besmanoff, an aggressive German heavyweight making his American debut, defeated Calvin Wilson of Philadelphia in the ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--The Soviet Union and its satellites called on the United Nations today to condemn what they described as "the subversive activities of the United States" against the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Harold E. Stassen urged 5,000 school principals today to teach teen-agers a sense of perspective "to balance black headlines."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 --A giant-size step toward decentralization of production at Metro-Goldwyn--Mayer became apparent today with the announcement that the company has entered into a partnership arrangement with two of its staff producers, Pandro S. Berman and Lawrence Weingarten.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The texts of the majority opinion and dissents in the case of William Radovich v. the National Football League, Bert Bell, J. Rufus Klawand, et al, is as follows:
"Supertramps" are increasing on the world's bulk-cargo trade routes.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--Chile suggested today that the new United Nations attitude toward colonial problems should be applied to the dispute over West New Guinea.
The National Guard has unlimbered its biggest political guns in Washington to retain its preferred position in the nation's defense structure.
TOKYO, Feb. 25--Japan's new Premier hopes to visit the United States soon for high-level talks on relations between Washington and Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Two assistant secretaryships in the Defense Department were combined today under Frank D. Newbury, who was named Assistant Secretary of Defense and Research and Engineering.
CAIRO, Feb. 25--King Saud of Saudi Arabia told the fourpower Arab conference today that he detected in Washington a considerable shift in the United States attitude on Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Administration proposed today that minimum wage coverage be extended to about 2,500,000 additional workers, most of them in the retail trade. Few pay rises would result.

Penn-Texas Corporation, seeking to take over control of Fairbanks, Morse Co., big Chicago maker of industrial equipment, has announced a proxy soliciting committee and a slate of directors for election at the annual meeting on March 27.
Collective bargaining in the port's twenty-five day-old tugboat strike will be resumed this morning.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 26 (AP) --The first scheduled Europe-toTokyo airliner to come by the North Pole route arrived from Copenhagen at 8:15 A.M. today.

The old, corrupt order in Cuba is being threatened for the first time since the Cuban Republic was proclaimed early in the century. An internal struggle is now taking place that is more than an effort by the outs to get in and enjoy the enormous spoils of office that have been the reward of political victory.

LONDON, Feb. 25--Prices in the stock markets here continued to move irregularly today with gains generally outnumbering losses. Trading was restricted by Mideast uncertainties, reports of new issues and the imminence of the end of the trading account.
Dr. William F. Arndt, a retired seminary professor and an authority on the Bible, died yesterday on a train on his way from Cambridge, England, to London. He was 76 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--Democratic legislative leaders assailed today a Republican proposal to exempt apartments renting for $150 or more a month from state rent control as they became vacant.

The American Bureau of Shipping, this country's ship classification society, has signed a contract to survey and inspect during construction the new passenger ship the Italian Line has ordered as a replacement for the Andrea Doria.
Zionist and non-Zionist leaders as well as public officials called on the Administration last night not to impose any sanctions against Israel.
THE bitter, poetic world of Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" was affectingly evoked at Town Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the American Communist party, appeared before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today to say exactly what everybody had expected--virtually nothing.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 13.4 per cent in net income for twelve months ended Jan. 31 on operating revenues of $150,891,845, against $150,571,121 in the corresponding 1955 period.

A License Department official told the City Council yesterday that on Sept. 28, 1956, Councilman Hugh Quinn appeared before his Department in behalf of the Triboro Carting Corporation and the Mackay Trucking Corporation.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 11 points ((55 cents a bale) off yesterday in moderate turnover.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Following is the the text of President Eisenhower's broadcast today in recognition of the Voice of America's fifteenth anniversary:

Although negotiations for Israel's withdrawal to the armistice lines are proceeding in a somewhat more hopeful atmosphere, there is danger that the crucial issue in the whole conflict may become buried under a mass of detail.
A 220-pound former policeman from Ireland is throwing his weight around at Boston University, but no one is complaining.

Thirty of the city's leading scholastic basketball players have been selected to participate in the ninth annual Metropolitan High School All-Star game at Madison Square Garden Saturday, March 30. The game will precede the eleventh annual East-West College All-Star contest for the benefit of the Fresh Air Fund.
The city's Republican leaders said yesterday, the party could win the 1957 Mayoralty race behind a "good-government Republican ticket with a goodgovernment program."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Ernest G. Swigert, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today wages should not be based on productivity.
Dr. Harry Slochower, suspended associate professor at Brooklyn College, announced yesterday his intention to retire or resign from the municipal college system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) --A member of the House Judiciary Committee, branding organized baseball a "horsehide cartel," introduced a bill in Congress today to bring the game under Federal antitrust laws.

The United States Supreme Court has unanimously delivered a timely and, we hope, a fatal blow to the widespread attempt of would-be censors to limit the literature available to adults to only that which is fit for children.
The Lukens Steel Company last year lifted its sales 22.7 per cent and almost tripled earnings of the previous year.
The Rockefeller Institute has received gifts totaling $5,500,000 that will be used for the construction of a modern living and study center for its graduate university.

Members of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association are planning a fund-raising bridge and canasta party. The fete will be held Tuesday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
MIAMI, Feb. 26--After the running of today's feature race Hialeah's infield course had the look of an expanse of grass on which every golfer in Miami had been practicing niblick shots.

The International Business Machines Corporation plans to split its stock two-for-one and also to sell additional stock in an amount sufficient to raise approximately $200,000,000 of new capital. Stockholders will be asked to approve both proposals at the annual meeting on April 30. The record date for the split would be May 7.

"Destry Rides Again," a horse opera spoofing the untamed West, is earmarked for Broadway next season. The entry, which is tentatively named "Destry Was Here," was confirmed yesterday by David Merrick, who will produce the show. It is based on three "Destry" films.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 --Katharine Cornell finally has decided to do what associates and movie producers have for years urged her to do--she will star in a motion picture.
The amount of milk kept away from metropolitan dealers rose yesterday to 10 per cent--about 950,000 quarts, or 250,000 more than on Monday. The third day of a farmers'...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26--Following are excerpts from the speech of Lester B. Pearson of Canada in the General Assembly today on the Middle Eastern problem and from Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's note on his conversations with the Israeli representative yesterday:
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 26 --Willard H. Allen, former State Secretary of Agriculture, died of a heart attack last night in the Hunterdon Medical Center here. He was 64 years old.
Glen B. Miller was elected president of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation by the board of directors yesterday. He succeeds Fred J. Emmerich, who was named chairman of the board.

The Radio Corporation of America last year transacted the largest volume of business in its thirty-seven-year history, exceeding a billion dollars in sales for the second successive year. Earnings, however, declined 15.7 per cent from 1955.

A testy Brownsville squirrel yesterday attacked an 11year-old boy and a 30-year-old truck driver in Brooklyn. The rodent bit and scratched them both before the truck driver trapped it. The boy, Santo D'Eredita, was on his way to school from his home at 581 Glenmore Avenue.

For the first time in the history of peacetime ship construction, Japan far out-distanced the rest of the world's maritime nations last year in the volume of new ships sent down the ways or floated in graving docks.
WARSAW, Feb. 26--The leader of the "Stalinists" wing of the Polish Communist party was retained as one of three Deputy Premiers in the new Government proposed to the Sejm (Parliament) today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26--The feature in wheat trading today on the Board of Trade was easiness in the March delivery.
COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 21 --The German stage will draw more than 21,000,000 spectators this season and half the performances they see will include elements barred in Nazi times.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--Republican leaders of the Legislature proposed today the creation of a civil rights bureau in the Attorney General's office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Secretary of Sate Dulles, in an eighty-minute conference with Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador, sought tcaday a way to avoid a threatening breakdown in the Israelis' negotiations with the United Nations on the withdrawal of forces from the Gaza Strip.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 26-- Vast power projects are being planned here with the aid of the United States Government and United States and Canadian utility companies. They are scheduled to give 2,000,000 kilowatts of new poorer to electricity-hungry Brazil in five years.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 25--No Tunisian attempts to conceal the sympathy and support that ex ists in Tunisia for the Algerian rebellion.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 --Buzzie Bavasi, the Dodgers' general manager, today partially cleared up the tangled minor league player situation resulting from the recent Los AngelesFort Worth transaction.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 26-- North African nationalists are debating their next move in the wake of the United Nations resolution on Algeria.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Feb. 26 (AP)--Separate courts-martial at this Marine training base found a drill instructor innocent of maltreating recruits today and another guilty of maltreatment and violation of orders.

ALTHOUGH the resources of the American Savoy ards are limited, their workmanship is impeccable. And their production of "Utopia, Limited," which was put on at 264 West Eighty-seventh Street last evening, is delightful.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Republican Congressional leaders forecast today early Congressional approval of the Administration's civil rights program.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--The Legislature today put the issue of legalizing bingo to the people.
ABOARD THE S.S. ESSO GETTYSBURG AT SEA, Feb. 26--The biggest and fastest oil tanker under the American-flag passed her sea trials today with flying colors. But hers will be a brief day of glory.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Agreement was reached today between Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly and the Harriman Administration on a revised program for plugging the loopholes in the state's compulsory automobile insurance law.
LONDON, Feb. 26--Britain reassured her West European allies today that she would continue to make strong contributions to the defense of Europe.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26--Manager Casey Stengel took time out today to appraise his catching department. It didn't take him long to arrive at the conclusion that for 1957 the Yankees find themselves equipped with just about the best receiving corps in baseball.
The management of NammLoeser's, Inc., was criticized harshly yesterday by some shareholders at a special meeting in the downtown Brooklyn store.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Army and the National Guard settled their heated dispute over training policies today.
The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday a plan for the reallocation of television channels in ten cities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 --Albert McCleery, executive producer of the "N.B.C. Matinee Theatre," has agreed with network officials on a new fiveyear contract as producer. The new pact, as yet unwritten, will become effective when Mr. McCleery's present agreement runs out in August.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)--The supervisor of security at Tropical Race Track testified today that the track president, Saul Silberman, had told him to allow a one-time hoodlum to remain at the track contrary to security regulations.
Massachusetts decided yesterday that the cost of borrowing in the public market was too high to justify the sale of improvement bonds at this time.
The management of PennTexas Corporation, waging a fight to take over control of Fairbanks, Morse Co., Chicago industrial equipment maker, faces a proxy battle of its own.

DAN FERRIS and other Olympic officials were batting the conversational breezes during a lull in one of the recent track meets in the Garden. They were reminiscing about Melbourne when someone mentioned the pleasure of renewing friendship with Dave Burghley, the Olympic 400-meter hurdles champion of 1928 and now Britain's top-ranking Olympic delegate.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 26--The United States icebreaker Glacier, her hull bearing the scars of five months in Antarctica, arrived at Melbourne today.
Robert Moses has written Governor Harriman urging that John E. Burton, a Republican, be renamed as a trustee of the State Power Authority.
HILLSDALE, N.J., Feb. 26-- Bob Mason, a commercial photographer, set this Bergen County community of 4,000 persons on its ear for a week.
CAIRO, Feb. 26--King Saud of Saudi Arabia met resistance today in his attempt to persuade the four-power Arab parley here to adopt a strong declaration against communism in the Middle East.

THE laughter in Falla's "EI Retablo de Maese Pedro" is touched with compassion, whereas the wit in Poulenc's "Les Mamelles de Tiresias" is tarnished by a snicker. There you have the difference between an unpretentious little work of art and an attempted jeu d'esprit which grows less cheerful on reacquaintance.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 25-- Five Central American nations have taken decisive steps toward economic integration.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--A split in the Republican legislative high command widened today. There were strong indications that it would be further aggravated before the end of the current legislative session.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Feb. 27--Premier Pibul Songgram continued to lead the list of local candidates this morning as returns from yesterday's election for the National Assembly kept trickling in.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26--The chairman of the Socony Mobil Oil Company urged the West today to establish closer relations with countries of the Middle East so "they will not arbitrarily deny their oil to us."
A discouragig report and an optimistic forecast came yesterday from a television manufacturer.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 26 (Reuters)--The former Hungainan Premier, Imre Nagy, will not be tried in Hungary, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.
BUTLER, N.J., Feb. 26--A fire that started early today in a drying-room explosion destroyed the plant of the Pequanoc Soft Rubber Company, causing a loss estimated at $2,000,000 to $3,000,000.

NOVELS, like electric razors and soap flakes, are a manufactured, advertised and sold to customers who often judge them on arbitrarily personal grounds. If it isn't my kind of novel and the kind I feel like reading right now, it's spinach and to hell with it. But novels are not mass-produced consumer goods. They are not made on assembly lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A foreign aid study submitted to a Senate committee urges that the Administration be free to sell surplus farm commodities to Iron Curtain countries.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 8 to 14 points (40 to 70 cents a bale yesterday.
JERUSALEM Feb. 26--The Search for a compromise that would induce Israel to withdraw her troops from captured Egyptian territory went on without let-up today.

This newspaper reported on Monday that art galleries in the city have increased fivefold during the past decade. An economist might credit this rather startling fact to the simple rise in the purchasing power of people who under any conditions would be interested in painting but who only now can indulge that interest.
The General Dynamics Corporation yesterday proposed to double its authorized common stock and sharply reduced the number of directors.
Television has many detractors. But Alwyn Barnett, a 44year-old liquor store owner, is not one of them. The home screen may have saved him from death or injury yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 26-- The Tennessee House of Representatives approved today and sent to the Senate two bills aimed at forcing the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to disclose its membership list and sources of financial support.
A battle of giants is about to pop in the soft-drink field. Pegsi-Cola soon will introduce a twenty-six-ounce "family-size" bottle in answer to Coca-Cola's addition of such a container a year ago.
William de Rham of 960 Park Avenue, who had taught dancing and decorum to the children of prominent families, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack. His age was 55.

IF there is one immediate mark of success in televi sion, it is the winning of a place among the "top ten" programs announced each month by Trendex, Inc., research organization. Entering the charmed circle can lead to a fortune for a star and have profound repercussions in the worlds of advertising, broadcasting and publicity.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26-- Eleven Syrians and one Lebanese were sentenced to death in Damascus today on conspiracy and treason charges.
ROME, Feb. 26--The series of defeats the Communists have been suffering lately has been broken by a negative victory they scored in the municipal elections at Lecco on Lake Como.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee heard testimony today corroborating statements by a New York artist, Miss Josephine Truslow Adams, that she served as a "go-between" during World War II between Earl Browder, former chairman of the American Communist party, and President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

NEWARK, Feb. 27--Vince Martinez, a Paterson welterweight, defeated Kid Gavilan, the former ruler of the 147 pound class, in a ten-round bout at the Newark Armory tonight. Referee Joe Harrison gave the bout to the New Jersey fighter on a round count of six to three with one round even.

George V. Buchanan, telegraph editor of The Daily Miror for the last five years and member of its news staff for more than twenty-five years, ied yesterday at his home, 24 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness. His age was 60.
Mayor Wagner's announcement of his political plans is imminent. He is commonly expected to say that he is willing to run for re-election to a second term.
Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen yesterday issued an injunction restraining three unions from picketing a ship repair concern on the Brooklyn waterfront.

EVER hospitable to young artists and to new talent, the Whitney Museum will open to the public today the first of a projected series of exhibitions to be held periodically. The present endeavor brings together the work of twentyfour artists represented by paintings or drawings and of six sculptors, all under the age of 35.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Peter Thorneycroft, Chancellor of the Excequer, told the House of Commons today that the United States Export-Import Bank had signed a formal agreement to lend Britain $500,000,000 to finance dollar imports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Secretary of Defense said today the United States overestimated the Soviet Union's jet bomber strength last year.
MERIDEN, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP) --Fire struck two adjoining buildings in the center of Meriden early today. It left two persons missing and damage estimated by fire officials at more than $1,000,000.
Chicago announced yesterday plans for the sale of $15,000,000 of water works system certificates of indebtedness on March 12. The securities will come due serially from 1970 to 1977.

Two five-story buildings on a plot 51 by 100 feet at 12 and 14 East Thirty-seventh Street will be renovated. The plans were announced by Adele Kirsch, a realty broker, who sold the property for the East Thirty-seventh Street Corporation to Nationwide Investors, Inc. The terms were cash over a new first mortgage of $194,000 at 5 per cent which was taken back by the seller.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- Years of unspectacular legislative spadework in National Guard and military reserve affairs paid off in a spectacular way today for Representative Overton Brooks.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--Governor Harriman today accused the Republican legislative leaders of trying to fool the public by making $5,700,000 worth of "phony" reductions in his budget.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26--The United States fomented a revolution in Hungary last October in an attempt to establish North Atlantic Treaty Organization air bases on Hungarian soil, the Soviet Union asserted today.

The Kings County Medical Society heard criticism last night from labor and management spokesmen and a consultant on the working of medical insurance programs. They called on the medical profession to re-evaluate its stand on such procedure.

The defending champions last fight seemed again headed for victory in the Vanderbilt Cup Championship, most important knockout team-of-four tourney contract bridge. The members the team are John R. Crawford, Sidney Silodor, Howard chenken, B. Jay Becker and George Rapee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- An Ohio business man and a Pentagon official flatly contradicted each other under oath today before a House Armed Services investigations subcommittee.
The Borden Company attained in 1956 the highest sales and earnings in its 100-year-history, Harold W. Comfort, president, reported yesterday.
Three men were held last night for a grand jury investigation of a waterfront loan shark racket.

Still entertaining hopes of gaining an Eastern Division play-off berth, the New York Knickerbockers last night whipped the St. Louis Hawks, 107 to 76. A crowd of 10,546 saw the fourthplace Knicks play one of their better games this season in the feature of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.
TOKYO, Feb. 26--Japan is preparing to try for new conquests on the Chinese mainland, but with pins and needles instead of bayonets this time.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--A Republican bill to revoke New York City's right to impose a $5 and $10 automobile use tax was approved by both the Senate and Assembly today. At the same time, Senator MacNeil Mitchell announced that the Senate Committee on Affairs of New York City would start public hearings in New York on Friday on the New York City Transit Authority's personnel and labor policies.
LONDON, Feb. 26--Thousands of Londoners warmly cheered Prince Philip today when he received an official welcome home after his four-month round-the-world trip.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (AP)--One man was killed and twenty-six persons were injured today when a crowded Municipal Railway bus hit a streetcar and then a utility pole.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has declined a request by Warner Brothers Pictures to postpone a television play titled the "Helen Morgan Story."

Louis E. Jallade, former commanding officer of the Twelfth Regiment, New York Guard, and the architect for many public and private buildings in New York and its suburbs, died yes terday at his home, 22 East Thirty-sixth Street, after a long illness. His age was 81.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- President Eisenhower appealed today for early Senate action on his Middle East resolution, Senate debate, nevertheless, continued at an unhurried pace.
Landlords paraded in Times Square yesterday with placards calling for an end to rent controls.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26--The United States is drafting a resolution calling for temporary United Nations administration of the Gaza Strip and freedom of navigation in the Gulf of Aqaba.
Two five-story apartment buildings at 1735 Walton Avenue at Townsend Avenue, in the Bronx, have been sold by Walton Apartments, Inc., to Walton Realty, Inc., representing investors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- President Eisenhower and Premier Guy Mollet of France found themselves in agreement today on a series of problems affecting Europe.

A BIT of the Restoration theatre was boisterously and tediously restored last night at the Royal Playhouse, 62 East Fourth Street, where Edward Ravenscroft's. "The Anatomist" was given an elaborate revival.
"The Labyrinth" is off until next season. Producer Alfred de Liagre Jr. is blaming the shortage of theatres for the postponement.
Settlement of the port's tugboat strike before Sunday appears unlikely.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A Senate committee opened today a book-length story of a union-underworld combination in the Pacific Northwest.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) --The House today slashed $60,800,000, or 12 per cent, from President Eisenhower's budget for the Interior Department and the Agriculture Department's Forest Service.
Heavy attendance, a sizable amount of sampling and more orders than usual marked the fiftieth semi-annual Leather Show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America.
Asa Bushnell and George Shiebler, those men of many athletic hats, will be wearing them several at a time during the next few weeks.
Strong opposition to the proposed transfer of teachers from "good" schools to difficult ones in underprivileged areas was voiced yesterday by the city's leading school organizations.

A judge of the General Sessions Court said yesterday that he would attempt to find an orthopedic surgeon to perform an operation or series of operations without charge that might completely change the life of a 17-year-old boy.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--Labor unions lined up today with employers of the apparel industry in opposing the Republicansponsored bill revising the unemployment insurance law.

Col. Arthur Fortunatus Cosby, who was a Rough Rider in the Spanish-American War and later a leader in military preparedness and political reform movements here, died on Monday in Westport, Conn. His age was 84. He resided at the Harvard Club.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26--The General Assembly, without debate, expressed an "earnest desire" today that negotiations be resumed for a settlement of the dispute over the British Crown Colony of Cyprus.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 26--Benjamin Percival Schulberg, a former motion-picture producer and discoverer of many leading film stars, died in his sleep yesterday at his home here. His age was 65.
More than $79,000,000 of new public utility debt and equity securities are being offered today to investors.
HERRICKS, L.I. Feb. 26-- Adopting the strategy of industry, Herricks School District No. 9 has begun an aggressive program to recruit teachers for its $3,000,000 high school now under construction.
HONG KONG, Feb. 26--Communist China has renewed efforts to make Chinese youth inform on their friends and relatives, according to reports received here from Peiping.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. told a Senate committee today he approved Congressional investigation and exposure of communism.
ALBANY, Feb. 26--Governor Harriman and the Republican legislative leadership clashed again today on the issue of rent control.
CAIRO, Feb. 26--Palestinian Arab reservists clashed with Egyptian soldiers and police this morning in suburban Maadi. Five persons were killed and two wounded, according to reliable sources.
A foreign banking concern charged yesterday that Stahl, Miles Co., Ltd., of Edmonton, Alberta, had "stolen" $6,000,000 worth of the banking concern's securities.
A midtown jeweler was robbed of an estimated total of $50,000 in diamonds yesterday, after a savage beating by three thugs.

With only a dozen issues showing more than perfunctory activity, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday went through its dullest session since Oct. 23, Only 1,580,000 shares were traded, against 1,710,000 on Monday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 26 --Walter Prichard Eaton, Professor of Playwriting at Yale University from 1933 until his retirement in 1947, died here today at the Carolina Inn of the University of North Carolina. He was 78 years old. For many years he was one of the country's foremost writers and teachers on the drama.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Government funds took the lead again in the stock markets here today. Industrial shares ended the bookkeeping account irregularly. Early gains in long and undated Government stocks were not fully held, but the War Loan finished six shillings threepence (87 cents) up and the 3 per cent conversion was seven shillings sixpence ($1.05) higher.

The United Automobile Workers is taking its financial troubles to its members in the hope that it can get its operations out of the red without running into a dues revolt of the kind that has shaken other big unions in recent months.
The right of television and newsreel crews to cover sessions of the City Council and its units is slated to be thrashed out soon before a Council committee.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26-- When he so wishes Nehru can be one of the most attractive characters upon the international stage.
HAVANA, Feb. 26--Havana newspapers made their appearance today uncensored for the first time since Jan. 15.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26--The Government accused the Soviet Union today of leading a campaign to "isolate" and "discredit" Yugoslavia.
THE March 1 week-end is the time for a small but notably eccentric minority of the population to begin operating after a winter of discontent--the striped-bass fishermen.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 26 (AP)--Carol Heiss of the United States, the defending champion, sailed to a solid lead today in the first women's singles event of the world figure skating championship.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Virginius Dabney, editor of The Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch, told 5,000 secondary school principals today that the South could not be forced into school integration.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday for the third consecutive trading day on the New York Cotton Exchange. Continued liquidation and commission-house selling touched off stop-loss selling. New trade buying in the deferred months and short covering in the near-by positions absorbed the offerings.

A TOPIC of interest to us is what might be called "the unstable first course." Anyone concerned with food must realize that in this country, at least, the overture to dinner lately has become somewhat like the smile one the Cheshire Cat--now it is, now it isn't.

Juan Manuel Fangio of Buenos Aires, the world champion race driver, stood up in the seat of his Maserati at the end of the 315-mile Gran Premio of Cuba on Monday and drank deeply from a bottle of water. His face was a bit grimy and his goggles were smeared.

THE giant strides being made is modern American architecture are the subject of an exhibition opening today at the Museum of Modern Art entitled "Buildings for Business and Government."
The American Civil Liberties Union asserted yesterday that a Federal court had violated constitutional rights of free speech and association in the school desegregation case at Clinton, Tenn.
WINSTON-SALEM. N.C., Feb. 26 (UP)--Lennie Rosenbluth's 30 points, including two free throws in the last fifty-five seconds, lifted North Carolina to a 69-64 victory over Wake Forest tonight.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, the sole backer of Broadway's biggest hit in years, "My Fair Lady," is contemplating a stage and/or television entertainment with musical embellishments.

MISS EDITH LOCKE, a brisk, dark-haired young woman in the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, has just craned her way through a rather odd assignment. She worked from Lincoln's Birthday almost through Washington's counting midtown flagpoles.

The American Government is now working overtime, both within and outside the United Nations, to save the Middle East by breaking the immediate Egyptian-Israeli deadlock as an essential step toward a solution of its other problems.

MADRID, Feb. 26--Thirteen newly appointed Cabinet ministers knelt in succession today in the presence of Generalissimo Francisco Franeo during swearing-in ceremonies at El Pardo 'Palace, near here. They were then congratulated and sent off to work.

By a vote of 6--3 the Supreme Court has ruled, as it did in the case of professional boxing in 1955, that professional football is not a sport, but a business engaged in interstate commerce, and therefore subject to the nation's antitrust laws.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26-- Carroll (Whitey) Lockman, a Giant from 1945 until June 14 of last year, when he was traded to the St. Louis Cardinals, was reacquired by the New Yorkers today. In a straight player-for- ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Pentagon sought today to minimize the Army-Air Force rivalry in developing an intermediaterange 1,500-mile ballistics missile.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 27 (AP)--Denmark expelled another Soviet diplomat today on charges that he had attempted to obtain secret military information.
LONDON, Feb. 27. (Reuters) --Following, in unoffical translation, is the text of the communique issued by four Arab heads of state in Cairo tonight and broadcast over the Cairo radio:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- Senator Clinton P. Anderson hinted today that Great Britain might be withholding information about its atomic power development program from the United States.
A Newark judge issued a temporary injunction late yesterday prohibiting milk farmers from interfering with milk shipments in New Jersey pending a hearing March 8.
The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 2 Pierrepont Street, corner of Pierrepont Place, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 --The politician in India walks more and talks more than the politician in the United States. Once balloting starts he suffers more, too.
The resignation of Dr. Harry Slochower, suspended associate professor, was accepted yesterday by Brooklyn College.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (Reuters) --The Komsomol (Soviet Young Communist League) called today for a nation-wide drive to raise the moral standards of youth.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Feb. 28--The Netherlands asked the General Assembly's Political Committee yesterday to apply "common sense" and reject a resolution concerning West New Guinea that it knew in advance would have no result.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27--Although most major league managers are moaning over the new twenty-eight-player limit that goes into effect on opening day, Casey Stengel, as usual, feels a favorable wind blowing in his direction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Following are excerpts from the text of the speech delivered in English today by Guy Mollet, Premier of France, at a luncheon meeting of the National Press Club:
Stock market statistics will catch up with the electronic age on Monday, when Standard Poor's Corporation will begin to distribute its new hourly index of 500 New York Stock Exchange stocks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly, reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 20:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- The United States withdrew Edward Thompson Wailes as its Minister to Hungary today rather than have him present his credentials to the Sovietdominated Government of pre mier Janos Kadar.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The National Association of Secondary School Principals asked the armed services today not to call pupils into active service except in a national emergency.
DETROIT, Feb. 27--A Capital Airlines Constellation, crippled in the air for four and one-half hours with a frozen nose wheel, landed here safely shortly after 6 P.M. today.
John E. Burton has been a symbol of common sense on the New York State Power Authority.
The K.L.M. (Royal Dutch) Airlines used the trans-Atlantic telephone cable yesterday to conduct a press conference to announce the opening on April 15 of a free port at Schiphol Airport, Amsterdam.

The Alleghany Corporation, an investment company, increased its holdings of New York Central Railroad stock by 127,100 shares to 973,500 shares during 1956, and since the yearend has purchased another 3,500 shares.
SOMETHING of the doggedness with which the citizens of New York State hunt and fish can be gleaned, with great difficulty, from figures just released by the State Conservation Department.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 27 (AP)--Glen Alden Corporation was ordered today by Luzerne County Common Pleas Judge Harold Flannery to show cause on March 7 why a temporary injunction barring its purchase of Maremont Automobile Products, Inc., should not be issued.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27-- Frank Sinatra and a private detective differed sharply today in their accounts of an abortive effort to break into a Hollywood apartment bedroom supposedly occupied by Marilyn Monroe.

Eighteen New York residents, including an 11-year-old school boy, received cash awards, medal pins and letters of commendation yesterday for rescues. Franklin B. Tuttle, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association, made the presentation...
Stavros Niarchos, Greek shipping magnate, has been identified as the person who bought the Edward G. Robinson art collection. M. Knoedler Co. of Fiftyseventh Street negotiated the sale on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Vice President Richard M. Nixon leaves by air tomorrow on a three-week goodwill mission through the awakening new nations of Africa.
A posthumous edition of Mark Aldanov's novel "Nightmare and Dawn" is scheduled for June publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce.
John B.Cubberley, supervising engineer of Mount Sinai Hospital since 1931, died there Tuesday of a heart attack.
While newspapers started the year with a slight drop in linage from the 1956 level, the actual figures are a bit misleading. January of 1956 had five Sundays, while this year the month had only four.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27--The Allstate Insurance Company announced today the retirement of James M. Barker as chairman and the election of Calvin Fentress Jr. as his successor.

ROME, Feb. 27--Prof. Auguste Piccard's bathyscaphe Trieste will make a series of exploratory dives in the Mediterranean under the sponsorship of the office of Naval Research, it was announced here today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27-- Bill Sarni, the 29-year-old firststring catcher of the Giants, will play no more baseball.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27-- The Provisional Government announced today that it had frustrated a Peronist counterrevolutionary plot with international implications.
WARSAW, Feb. 27--The new Polish Government of Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz was approved in the Sejm (parliament) tonight with one independent deputy voting against and eight abstentions.
TRENTON, Feb. 27--Gov. Robert B. Meyner vigorously denied here today that his annual budget did not include all state revenues.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27--Proceedings in the General Assembly were stalled today by the decision of the United States not to introduce its compromise resolution on an Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.
New major corporate stock and bond issues amounting to more than $115,000,000 will be offered to investors today.
Joseph Kassner, a member of the Chicago group that recently purchased a controlling interest in Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., has been elected president and a director of the specialty store chain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Eisenhower's civil rights program easily cleared its first Congressional hurdle today.
Dr. Ernst Kris, a psychoanalyst, died yesterday of a coronary occlusion in his home at 135 Central Park West. His age was 56.

President Eisenhower's appointment of David K.E. Bruce as Ambassador to West Germany has received universal applause except from a small-minded segment of the Republican party that resents the nomination of "another Democratic campaign contributor to an important diplomatic post."

ALBANY, Feb. 27--A joint legislative committee investigating charity rackets recommended today the outlawing of fund solicitation accompanied by the sending of unordered merchandise.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, The burgeoning Jewish population of west Germany was esti mated today to have reached a total of 45,000.
THE Theatre Guild and its sponsor, the United States Steel Company, subscribed last night to the increasing vogue for Western dramas on television.
The annual luncheon of Cancer Care of the National Cancer Foundation Tuesday will honor more than 6,000 volunteers in the metropolitan area for their efforts in behalf of the organization.

MANNHEIM, Germany, Feb. 22--This city of 250,000 persons last month opened an edifice described by some critics as a crystal palace and by others as a factory. Anyhow, it contains both an opera hall and a theatre.
A church leader said yesterday that major Protestant organizations would fight the proposed legalization of bingo in this state.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 --Roy Campanella, whose job as the Dodgers' catcher was regarded as in jeopardy, today gave lessons to his potential successor.
The development or a "revolutionary" radar system that can instantly determine and evaluate the behavior of guided missiles or space satellites has been reported by the Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27(AP)-- The Senate Banking Committee completed work today on a bulky bill overhauling the nation's banking laws.
Yugoslav Foreign Minister Popovic has finally brought into the open the serious new break between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia.
THERE is a sultry, serpentine heroine in Howard Nemerov's new novel, "The Homecoming Game,"* the likes of which --or whom--we have not seen since Michael Arlen's potted-palmy days.
TWO traditions feed the fertile imagination of Jose Luis Cuevas, a Mexican artist just turned 24, whose drawings are exhibited at the Roland de Aenlle Gallery, 59 West Fifty-third Street.
Market interest centered on a handful of stocks yesterday, with most of the list marking time on small volume. The trend was gently downward.
A champion among diamonds was weighed in yesterday at 128.25 carats. The ceremony took place at Harry Winston's, moments after the remarkable stone left the lapidary's hands.

IT was so peaceful yesterday at Mainbocher's. Amidst the sound and fury of the fashion world, which dedicates itself to whipping "looks" off women's backs almost as soon as they are wheedled on, there is Mainbocher, quietly pursuing his own private vision.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27--Wheat futures seesawed over narrow ranges during much of today's session on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The Senate Commerce Committee decided today to question Federal Communications Commission officials next week on a staff report critical of the commission for inaction in the field of subscription television.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 27--A system for landing airplanes in all kinds of weather with the pilot never touching the controls was given its first public demonstration here today.

BELGRADE, Yuogslavia, Feb. 27--The Yugoslavs scanned the western horizon today, hoping to find manna but willing to settle for more bread and a few encouraging words.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Guy Mollet, Premier of France, took a strongly pro-Israel, anti-Egypt stand in an address today before the National Press Club.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 27 --The Thai Government opened an investigation today into charges that Tuesday's elections for a new National Assembly had been less than honest.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 27 --Army's basketball team defeated Hartwick College, 92--86, in the Field House today. The cadets were forced to their highest score of the season in downing the visitors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 --Projects ranging from a New York City "mad bomber" drama to a modern version of Henrik Ibsen's "A Doll's House" are being stuffed into the "Climax!" production hopper as fare for the remainder of the season.
The Gray Manufacturing Company, which makes dictating equipment, selected a new president and reorganized its board of directors yesterday without a proxy fight.
ALBANY, Feb. 27--New York City officials, conferring for two hours today with a group of Republican legislators, got no encouragement that $17,400,000 in city aid would be restored to the budget.

The pace of saving seems to have slowed. Crawford H. Stocker Jr., president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday that deposits in the nation's 527 such banks increased by $85,000,000 in January to a record total of slightly more than $30,000,000,000.
CAIRO, Feb. 27--Four Arab chiefs of state adopted here tonight a declaration of "positive neutrality" in the "cold war."
