Justice Bernard Botein criticized last night what he called "conveyor belt" methods that have been proposed to reduce court congestion.
Just One Break, Inc., which helps physically handicapped persons to find work, will benefit from the May Festival, a dinner dance, to be held on May 13 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A Senate committee linked a few powerful union officials today with prostitution and punchboard projects in Oregon.

The High School of Music and Art will not be closed or merged, and its building will not be given to City College. City and school officials gave this assurance yesterday after scores of protests had been received as the result of a report that the Board of Education was considering closing the special school.
Forum, National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue, 12:30 P.M. Speaker: George A. Mooney, State Superintendent of Banks.
"A Hole in the Head," a new play by Arnold Schulman, starring Paul Douglas, will have its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Plymouth Theatre.
A former union official who testified "extensively" before a Senate subcommittee last month and before a New York County grand jury on Tuesday was revealed yesterday to be a mental incompetent.
Ed Sullivan and the Metropolitan Opera have agreed to terminate their television contract a month before its original expiration date.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A special Senate committee released tonight a report criticizing the nation's foreign-aid program.
Jesse W. Lewis of 1088 Park Avenue, who retired in 1947 as treasurer of the General Electric Company, died on Tuesday at the Park East Hospital after a short illness. His age was 76.

After a debate which imposed further strains on the North Atlantic alliance the United Nations General Assembly has adopted without opposition a compromise resolution on Cyprus which should have a calming and constructive effect on all parties concerned.
LONDON, Feb. 27--The death penalty for certain offenses under the emergency regulations in Cyprus is to be abolished.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 27-- Long ago this fresh water port 100 miles from the Pacific Ocean was dubbed the "spinster city" of the West.
Whatever the public may sometimes think, criminals cannot buy their way out of arrests, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday.

A jump of 51,800 barrels a day in the nation's crude oil output in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Production averaged a new high of 7,567,200 barrels a day, compared with 7,515,400 in the...
A two-story brick garage building on plot 75 by 100 feet at 217 West Nineteenth Street has been purchased by Arnold T. Milton from Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia made a frontal attack today on President Eisenhower's Middle East resolution.
The Labor Youth League, fraternal affiliate of the Communist party, announced yesterday that fifty delegates to its national convention had voted "with great reluctance" to dissolve it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court assured a Senate committee today that his religion imposed no obligation upon him that outweighed his judicial oath. Justice Brennan is a Roman Catholic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--An old vaudeville act comes irreverently to mind in a perusal of the majority and minority opinions of the Supreme Court in the professional football case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) A newsprint producer said today the industry's profit on a ton of newsprint "is surprisingly low."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 27--Four thousand Negroes shouted defiance tonight to an ultimatum designed to end their seven-week-old bus boycott.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27-- Don Bab, a substitute center, sank a twenty-three-foot jump shot as the final buzzer sounded, enabling Yale to gain undisputed possession of first place in the Ivy League basketball race tonight with a 57-56 victory over Dartmouth.
The Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries realized an increase of 17.3 per cent in earnings last year on a 6 per cent gain in sales over 1955.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 27 (AP)--The United States' Carol Heiss swept far ahead of her European challengers today in quest of her second straight world figure-skating championship.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27-- Most of the financing for civilian atomic power will have to come from the Government until private investmet in the program can be better justified, mining engineers were told here today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 8 points off on the March delivery but 2 to 4 points up on other months.
Many cocktail parties will be given this evening before the sixth annual Mardi Gras Ball of the Junior League of the City of New York, Inc.
LONDON, Feb. 27--Two thousand dockworkers staged a wildcat strike at Southampton today in a dispute over the loading of the Union Castle liner Arundel Castle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Senate Internal Security subcommittee called on Congress today to curb secret police and espionage activities by Soviet diplomatic officials in the United States.
LONDON, Feb. 27--A further rise in Government funds helped the stock market today, the first day of the new bookkeeping account.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--State Department and Israeli officials said tonight that Premier David Ben-Gurion had accepted in principle United States proposals for solution of the Gaza Strip and Gulf of Aqaba problems.

MIAMI, Feb. 27--Mrs. Gene Markey, William Hartack and Ben and Jimmy Jones were in the winner's enclosure again, posing happily with a piece of silverware, after the running of today's stakes race at Hialeah.
HARTFORD, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The state police said one of two former convicts picked up last week had admitted tonight six hold-up slayings in Connecticut since Dec. 15.

A score of Caribbean-bound vacationists almost missed the boat yesterday because of the continuing tug strike. To put out safely at slack water, the cruise liner Olympia pulled away from her berth at West Forty-eighth Street at 9:45 A.M.
LONDON, Feb. 27--A graduate scholarship for the study of American history has been established at Queen's College, Oxford University, in memory of the late George Washington Ochs Oakes.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 27 (AP)--Two Federal judges joined today in an informal warning that a proposed new all-white bus line in Montgomery would violate the United States Supreme Court's ban on racial segregation.
The Transit Authority struck a new blow yesterday at subway squint, a peevish facial expression worn by New Yorkers who try to read on station platforms.
The City Council's investigation of the fitness of Councilman Hugh Quinn to retain his office moved through its sixth public hearing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP)-- A Congressional dispute over professionalsports erupted today when Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, introduced a bill to exempt pro football, hockey and basketball, as well as baseball, from the antitrust laws.

Ski Sketch: Roger F. Langley is the principal of Rice School in Holden, Mass., but there is no doubt that he is better known for his contributions to skiing. He has been active in the governing end of the sport for thirty years.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 27--Protestant churchgoers were urged today to unite against what were described as new moves to obtain formal United States representation at the Vatican.
DENVER, Feb. 27 (AP)--Rory Calhoun, a New York middleweight, bent to his work at the midpoint of the fight and punched out a split decision over Charley Cotton in a ten-round televised bout tonight.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--Three university students, including two Negroes, were convicted in Municipal Court today on charges of violating Tallahassee's unusual bus seat assignment ordinance.
A group of 125 persons suddenly chartered three buses and left a dinner of the Dominican Cultural Society last night to make a protest march on Washington.
One of the big battles now shaping up in Congress involves amendments to the Federal minimum wage law.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27--The General Assembly's Special Political Committee rejected today a Soviet proposal for Assembly discussion of "subversive activity" by the United States among the Eastern European satellites.
A local law conditionally repealing the city's $5 and $10 automobile use tax was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
PARIS, Feb. 27--The Ministry of the Interior announced tonight the arrest of the principal leaders of one of the two major Algerian nationalist groups in France.

Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education gave assurance yesterday that the integration reports to be considered by the board today would not change the current extent of school bus transportation.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (UP)--An iron and steel brokerage concern announced today that it had purchased the Puerto Rican National Railroad.
Trade buying and stop-loss purchasing opened world sugar futures up slightly yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
PALM trees now stand like sentinels just beyond the center-field fence at Al Lang Field in St. Pete. In a short while Mas ter Mickey Mantle will be rifling drives over those sheltering palms.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)-- Saul Silberman swore today he had never knowingly violated any racing regulations or laws of Florida.

THE Afternoon Theatre last evening presented Moliere's "The Doctor in Spite of Himself" at the Tempo Playhouse. The comedy is imperishable. Its satirical comments on the medical profession are devasting,...
The Transit Authority provisionally appointed Nelson Seitel to the new position of hearing examiner yesterday. It calls for an annual salary of $15,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 27--Landlords, most of them from New York City, staged a noisy mass demonstration here today in favor of liberalizing state rent controls. Tenant groups, who staged a rival demonstration in favor of tightening rent controls along the lines advocated by Governor Harriman, were outnumbered by better than three to one.

The New York Rangers solidified their hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League race, but they had to go all-out to hold the Chicago Black Hawks to a 6-6 tie at Madison Square Garden last night.
For the second time in the twenty-seven-day-old tugboat strike the Queen Elizabeth, the world's largest passenger liner, has been diverted to Halifax.
A $1,500,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against American Coal Shipping, Inc., the United Mine Workers of America and the union president, John L. Lewis.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) --La Salle College downed Fordham's basketball team, 84--66, tonight at the Palestra before a capacity crowd of about 9,000.
When he announced that the Consumer Price Index had reached new high ground in January, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, added: "I can't point to any...
The Georgia Farmers Market Authority, an instrumentality of the state government, borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday on revenue bonds maturing between 1958 and 1979.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 27 --Geraldine Farrar, glamorous prima donna of the Metropolitan Opera in the extravagant Twenties, will pass her seventy-fifth birthday at her home here tomorrow quietly recalling "the snows of yesteryear."

HAVANA, Feb. 27 (AP)--Three articles on Cuba published by The New York Times based on an interview with a Cuban rebel leader were termed "fantastic fiction" today by Santiago Verdeja, Minister of National Defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) --Representative F. Edward Hebert said today that conflicting testimony given under oath to the House Armed Services Investigations Committee would be shown to the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The mysterious death of an American's pilot in the Dominican Republic was debated on the floor of the House today as rival groups of Dominicans paraded before Congress and the White House.
Forty-five prisoners at Rikers Island Penitentiary were rewarded yesterday for their rescue work in the Feb. 1 airliner crash on the island.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 --Duke Snider is still hitting left-handers, despite his alleged weakness in that department.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 28 (AP)-- After holding a 15-point lead early in the fourth period, the New York Knickerbockers needed an overtime period to shade the Boston Celtics, 122--121, in a National Basketball Association contest tonight.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28--The Yankees' contract worries ended today when the last holdout, Don Larsen, yielded to the combined efforts of George M. Weiss, the Bombers' general manager, and Lee MacPhail, the director of personnel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Government investigators today ended--at least for the time being--an inquiry into allegations that the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company misrepresented a big debentures issue as private.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the future political course of Africa could be "decisive" in the Western world's contest with communism.
Net income of the American Tobacco Company in 1956 was the highest in the company's history, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Paul M. Hahn, president.
Rain has ruined the skiing picture in the East. With the exception of the Laurentians of Canada, prospects for the weekend are the poorest in years.
Manhattan's defending squad views tomorrow's indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America with dedicated hopefulness.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28--Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hazelton Kurtz of Shaker Heights have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Clorinda Kurtz, to Allen Standish Hunt. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Franklin Livingstone Hunt of Summit, N.J.
The purchase by Webb Knapp of the Belair Stud Farm in Maryland for $1,187,500 is being contested in a court action brought by William J. Levitt, the builder.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Dockworkers were back on the job at Southampton today after a wildcat strike that began yesterday noon.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Feb. 28-- Ralph Peters Jr. of Braestead, former president of the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Company (now the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank) and former superintendent of the Long Island Rail Road, died tonight in the North Country Community Hospital, Glen Cove, after a long illness. His age was 69.
The often-postponed expansion of the one-way avenue network into midtown will go into operation March 10.

Differences of opinion on corporate policies have brought about the decision of Hanns Ditisheim, chairman of the board, and some other directors to withdraw from Butler Brothers, big Chicago merchandise house.

The lesson to be drawn from the latest abortive military plot in Argentina is that the sooner the exdictator, Gen. Juan Peron, is expelled from the Western Hemisphere the better. He is making mischief all over the hemisphere and he ought to go to Switzerland and spend the millions he put away there.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 28 --Finland's coalition Government faced imminent collapse tonight after six Agrarian Cabinet members resigned.

A banking syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $25,000,000 of Commercial Credit Company 4 per cent notes due in 1947. The securities are priced at 93.06 to yield 4.65 per cent to maturity.
What do you do when you receive --and who doesn't?--a mail appeal for a charitable donation with some unordered merchandise enclosed, to be returned if it isn't used?
The traditional spirit of Mardi Gras came to New York last night several days in advance of New Orleans' Shrove Tuesday revelry.
The Democratic opposition in the Senate has launched a flank attack that would cripple the President's program for the Middle East.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 28, (AP)--Carol Heiss of New York won her second straight world figure-skating championship tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Senate Internal Security subcommittee told Congress today that Hawaii was virtually controlled by two labor unions run by Communists.
OUT of some commonplaces of American life, Arnold Schulman has composed a tender and humorous drama, "A Hole in the Head," which was put on at the Plymouth last evening.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Berk of 240 Central Park South of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Jacqueline Berk, to Lewis Jay Horowitz. He is the son of Mrs. Frank Wartur of Yonkers and the late Jack Horowitz.

Leo R. Portney, controller of the Barber Oil Corporation since 1946, died yesterday in Harkness pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 53 years old and resided at 240 Fletcher Avenue, Valley Stream, L.I. His office was at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
MIAMI, Feb. 28--William Hartack scored another triple at the Hialeah horse park today and tied his own Hialeah record for finishing first at one meeting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The United States was informed today of Israel's decision to withdraw her troops from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.

THE horseshoe of roses for Beulah Charlat! Today is her day and down at the Scranton Lace Company, 295 Fifth Avenue, she is being treated with all the deference accorded to an Academy Award winner in Hollywood.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 28--The Government made public today Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's conciliatory reply to the Feb. 5 note of Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier.

As Senator William F. Knowland, one of the United States representatives to the U.N. General Assembly meeting, remarked the other day, "the very term 'Soviet item' has become a synonym to the United Nations for a propaganda offensive against the United States."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Bell Howell Company of Chicago, a leading manufacturer of cameras and camera equipment, with illegal enforcement of price fixing agreements with its dealers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Administration urged Congress again today to abolish the Postal Savings System.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--The General Assembly rejected tonight a proposal to set up a Good Offices Commission to arrange talks between Indonesia and the Netherlands over the disputed territory of West New Guinea.
The Commissioner General of the Brussels World's Fair next year, Baron Moens de Fernig, said here yesterday that the exhibition would be a spectaculer with a cast of fifty nations.
CAIRO, Feb. 28--King Saud of Saudi Arabia failed to obtain from President Gamal Abdel Nasser a definite pledge of freedom of transit of the Suez Canal, informed sources said here tonight.

Loew's State Theatre played to an interested audience yesterday morning. The feature was the annual meeting of stockholders of Loef's, Inc., who met to vote on selection of the thirteenman board of directors, which had almost caused a proxy fight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Following is the text of a joint United States-French statement issued today at the conclusion of three days of talks between President Eisenhower and Premier Guy Mollet:
TOKYO, Feb. 28--Japan's new Premier intends to visit Washington next summer for "heartto-heart talks" on pending questions, he said today.

Business loans outstanding from the major New York City banks declined $35,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. This compares with a rise in the similar week last year of $120,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 28--Premier Antonio Segni was accorded a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies early this morning by a margin of eight votes.

Commodity futures, closed iregularly yesterday on the New York exchange. Activity was dull and featureless in most markets. There was a balancing of holdings as traders waited for the markets to develop trends following the sharp flucuations in the last few days.
EVEN crowd-happy Times Square was set reeling a week ago when thousands of teen-agers jammed the area, smashed windows and disrupted ...
Senator Paul H. Douglas called last night for a crusade by progressives to break up what he called the threat of big business to democracy.

THE beginning archer, struggling with the complex problems of elbow and wrist, may take heart from the experience of Dr. C.H. Rothfuss of Woodbridge, N.J. After six months of intermittent practice, with no instruction, he has just downed a jaguar and an ocelot with arrows and now is on fire to take lessons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Gus Courts, a Negro testifying for civil rights legislation, said today he was one of many persons who had to leave Mississippi because they had tried to vote.

LAST week eggs declined to the lowest price for this season in ten years. This week, another 2-cent-a-dozen drop in price brings them down to the lowest rate they have been at any time since May, 1950. Hence, eggs deserve the most important place on shopping lists for this week-end.
Guy Mollet, Premier of France, asked the Foreign Policy Association here yesterday to support his "Eurafrican" proposal.

IT is so easy to forget. We read in the newspapers about the heroism and suffering of a persecuted people and perhaps we send a contribution for the refugees, a sum we can spare without much inconvenience. But life goes on and pity and indignation are not emotions that can be maintained at a permanent peak of intensity. We citizens of...
The State of Delaware was the major borrower in the market for tax-exempt securities yesterday.
A strike by 250 longshoremen yesterday halted operations at the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation's pier at Marsh Street in Port Newark, N.J.
MASTERFUL cut and deft handling of imaginative fabrics marked the spring and summer collection of Elizabeth Arden yesterday.

A SPLENDID calm pervades the new paintings by Esteban Vicente at the Rose Fried Gallery, 40 East Sixtyeighth Street. They offer an unlimited tour for the senses. Sumptuously painted, these canvases contain within themselves a world of essences so subtle that words can scarcely touch their emotional significance.

The angry controversy over the length of time recruits to the National Guard must undergo active duty training has now been resolved, largely through the tireless mediation efforts of Representative Brooks of Louisiana, a leading member of the Armed Services Committee.
George P. Metesky was ordered yesterday to go on trial as the so-called "Mad Bomber."

The stock market last month lost 10.75 points as measured by The New York Times combined index. This was the greatest loss for any February since the index started in 1911. The volume of trading was the smallest for that month since 1954.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--The United States told the General Assembly today that it would "not forget" the countries of Eastern Europe and would work consistently for their independence.

"The Ziegfeld Follies," nostalgically regarded by theatre buffs as an American institution, opens at 8 o'clock tonight at the Winter Garden, with the inimitable British comedienne, Beatrice Lillie, starred. Since the celebrated series was inaugurated in 1907, New York has witnessed twenty-five predecessors, the last of which was put on here in 1943.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 28--Viiu Viljur, 16 years old, trembled as she held the squirming white mouse in her left hand. In the other hand she held a hypodermic needle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The crisis over the recall of Israel's troops from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area was finally resolved today, primarily by the collaboration of two men who have been highly critical of each other in the past.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28-- Nine career civilians in the Federal Government were named today to receive Rockefeller Public Service Awards. The awards were announced by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

St. John's put across the last punch of a tense, strategic basketball duel to upset Manhattan, 61--59, at Madison Square Garden last night. In the opener of an all-metropolitan double-header witnessed by 4,138 spectators, Iona routed St. Francis, 94--80.

THERE'S an appealing fragrance in the very air at Vero Beach. The Dodger baseball factory is located in the heart of the Indian River country just above Florida's Gold Coast and the orange groves crowd in from all sides.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 28--Henry A. Field, a banking and insurance executive, died today in Springfield Hospital. He was 86 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28-- Jordan is near a critical test of strength between King Hussein and anti-Western forces headed by Premier Suleiman Nabulsi, informed sources say. Such a crisis might cost Hussein his throne and cause general trouble in the Middle East.

Freezing rain and sleet that iced roads and made driving in some areas hazardous last night caused the detouring of westbound traffic on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn and delays on three other major routes.

Former President Herbert Hoover and prominent figures in the entertainment field attended a mass of requiem yesterday for Gene Buck. The songwriter, a past president of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died Sunday at the age of 71.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Eisenhower Administration sent urgent appeals to the Senate today to reject a proposed skeletonized version of the pending Middle East resolution.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 (UP) --Aging little Johnny Longden, the world's leading rider in the number of mounts he has booted to victory, scored his 5,000th victory today. He reached the milestone at Santa Anita in the fourth race aboard Bente.
A holdover October grand jury in the Bronx handed up an indictment yesterday charging three men and a television maintenance concern with conspiracy to defraud the Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices declined 2 per cent between mid-January and midFebruary.
The cotton futures market advanced 2 to 9 points yesterday. The strength was most pronounced in old May.

HAVANA, Feb. 28--The question of the veracity of a personal interview by Herbert L. Matthews of The New York Times with Fidel Castro, rebel leader, in the Sierra Maestra of Oriente Province is rapidly becoming a national issue in Cuba.

One-hour television drama programs, a feature of the National Broadcasting Company's 9 to 10 Sunday evening schedule for more than eight years, will be replaced in the fall by music and variety shows.
A measure virtually outlawing trading stamps in Tennessee becomes law on Monday unless Gov. Frank G. Clement vetoes it before then. The bill was passed 87 to 5 in the House and 28 to 2 in the Senate.
Kenneth Gordon, violinist, gave a brilliant recital last night in Town Hall.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28 --President Sukarno said today that he was postponing for four days any decision on carrying out his plans for a new style government that would include Communists.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb, 28-- Programs that foster greater awareness of interdependence and mutual respect among American nations will help make this hemisphere "a living example of what mankind can be."
A two-part program designed to lessen racial segregation in the city's public schools was adopted yesterday by the Board of Education without a dissenting vote.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 --Nanette Fabray is on her way to returning to television on a regular basis. The former stage wife and comedy foil for Sid Caesar has agreed to star in "June," a projected film series being created by Jess Oppenheimer for the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A witness told Senators today that a high union official had sold out his own agents for $10,000.
Member bank reserve positions were fairly tight during much of the week ended Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
TRENTON, Feb. 28--Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today his candidacy for re-election. He is expected to be unopposed in the Damocratic primary April 16.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Grains closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board or Trade today, with wheat declines extending to 2 cents a bushel on the March delivery. This equaled the low made on Feb. 11.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--A series of proposals to revise laws affecting public authorities came under attack at a public hearing here today.
A West Coast gambler's story of "fantastic profits" possible from the pinball machine serves to cast fresh doubt on the legitimacy of the device, descendant of the slot machine.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Legislature alone had the right to regulate the water level of Lake George.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Maj. Robert Hobart Mayo, inventor of the pickaback plane, died here on Tuesday at the age of 66.

The milk farmers' boycott lost ground yesterday when the amount of milk withheld in the metropolitan area's milkshed dropped to 9.8 per cent. This compared with Wednesday's peak of 15 per cent, and some dealers here said they had more milk than they could sell.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Governor Harriman described as a "vicious proposal" today a Republican suggestion that apartments renting for $150 or more a month be decontrolled as they become vacant.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 28 --The Thai Government announced today that Premier Pibul Conggram topped the list of local candidates in Tuesday's elections, that are now under heavy attack here as the "dirtiest ever."
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Glen R. Bedenkapp resigned from the Public Service Commission today, signaling a Democratic contest for the $18,500-a-year position.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Army will activate atomic support commands tomorrow at Fort Bragg in North Carolina and Fort Hood in Texas.
A State Senate investigation of New York's publicly owned transit system will begin here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Eisenhower has asked department and agency heads to list career officials who, in their opinion, should be removed from civil service and placed in the political "non-career executive group."
BOULDER, Colo., Feb. 28 (AP)--Warm applause greeted Kurt Von Schuschnigg, former Austrian Chancellor, today when he opened a Religion in Life Seminar at the University of Colorado.

Today is a day of decision for tobacco growers. It is the deadline for agreeing to retire acreage under the Government's soil bank program. Some $34,000,000 has been set aside for payment to tobacco farmers who participate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) --Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther said tonight that this country's military strength was so great that in his opinion "there is never going to be a third world war."
With a look at the results of New York's current architectural restlessness, the Municipal Art Society has just completed a survey of 300 noble, structures it thinks should be preserved.

The investigation into loan shark activities along the waterfront continued yesterday. Seven persons seined in raids on Tuesday and several borrowers were questioned in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28-- The flashiest performer in spring training with the Giants has been Andre Rodgers. With one exception, everyone here has been fascinated by the movements of this 6-foot 3-inch shortstop, who never had played baseball prior to 1954.
Salary increases of $2,500 a year were voted by the Board of Estimate yesterday for the fourteen Appelate Division Justices of the First and Second Departments.
Gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund mounted to a record of $477,756.73 yesterday, the closing day for the 1956-57 appeal. The previous high mark was $438,573.38, set a year ago.

Mayor Wagner said the expected. He will run for a second term. He said it in characteristically honest fashion. He was not coy. He did not have to be coaxed. He wanted to continue in the important office in which he has made a favorable record. There is no doubt that the Democratic party leadership, as well as the Liberal party's, wants him to do so.

Daily newspapers in this country set a new high circulation record--56,596,000 copies a day--last year, it was disclosed in the eighty-ninth annual edition of N.W. Ayer Son's Directory of Newspapers and Periodicals, published today. The increase was the fifth in as many years.

Closing arguments were presented yesterday afternoon in behalf of the 42,000 Westchester County commuters and the New York Central Railroad's 75-year-old Putnam Division used by some of them. A decision will be given in a few months by the Public Service Commission.
LONDON, Feb. 28--The Labor party won its second consecutive by-election today when it retained the Parliamentary seat at Wednesbury, Staffordshire, by an increased majority.

The Vehicle Realty Corporation has purchased the fourstory brownstone dwelling on lot 20 by 100 feet at 122 East Fifty-sixth Street from the Marfed Realty Corporation. Philip H. Goodman was the broker.
BAPORA, India, Feb. 28--The men of this village came in from their wheat fields for a few hours today and sat in silent rows in the dust of the school yard.

New financing in February was marked by large offerings of housing, public utility and foreign bonds. These lifted the total of new bonds publicly offered here to $1,313,899,000 for 223 issues, compared with $2,041,970,000 for 147 issues in the preceding month. In February, 1956, the total was $1,257,005,000 for 218 issues.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., plans to increase the capacity of its Indian Point atomic power plant to 275,000 kilowatts. This will be an increase of 39,000 kilowatts above the original specifications. The cost of the plant has also been revised upward by $15,000,000 to an estimated $70,000,000 when the plant goes on the line in 1960.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--The General Assembly called again today for the admission of South Korea and South Vietnam to the United Nations.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Court of Appeals upheld today the dismissal of a New York City subway conductor who had taken refuge in the Fifth Amendment. The amendment permits a person to refuse to testify when his testimony might be self-incriminating.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi denounced today efforts by the United States to make arrangements in Washington under which Israel would withdraw from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28-- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, industrialist, sportsman and moition-picture producer, today declared himself a friend of the American teen-ager--a friend who is prepared to invest $2,000,000 in a film to demonstrate his belief that "97 out of 100" of the 18;000,000 teen-agers in this country "are responsible kids."
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28-- Methods used by "scandal" magazines that traffic in reported peccadillos of Hollywood personalities were outlined today at a state legislative inquiry.
MADRID, Feb. 28--Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the eighteen members of his newly named Cabinet attended today a formal mass of commemoration for the Spanish Royal Family.

More than 3,717,000 visitors attended conventions in New York in 1956, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday. This was 1,451,000 more than in 1955 and set a record for the city.
The luxury liner Ile de France, disabled by a navigating accident in the Caribbean, will have to be towed to this country for repairs.
Subsidized American steamship companies cannot charge off the cost of special Suez war bonuses to the Government, the Federal Maritime Board ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--In a ruling of interest to dealers and users of automobile tires the Federal Court of Appeals today invalidated a Federal Trade Commission order limiting discounts on bulk purchases of tires to single-carload orders.
PARIS, Feb. 28--The Government was urged today to set a deadline for its standing offer to the Algerian rebels for a cease-fire.

JOHNNY LONGDEN will go anywhere to ride a race horse, and he will take the fastest means of getting there. Often he has flown from his home in California to New York or to Florida to compete in a single stakes event, and has flown right back.

February ended on a tired note in the stock market. Yesterday, after fairly general early gains, stocks receded and generally closed at or near their lows of the day. The over-all loss for the session, however, was moderate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A couple of the amendments made by a House Judiciary subcommittee in the texts of what are known as "the President's civil rights proposals" meet objections that have been raised against the legislation.
BOSTON, Feb. 28--The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that local public-service programs were the safeguard of broadcasting.
The Union Pacific Railroad lifted its net income to $5,075,707 in January, a gain of $656,240 over the like month last year when earnings totaled $4,419,467.
VIENNA, Feb. 28--A reorganization of the Hungarian Government and of the leadership of the Socialist Workers (Communist) party were announced tonight by the Budapest radio.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he was a candidate for re-election. He declared that he would be glad to have Council President Abe Stark and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa as his running mates in the election Nov. 5.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Eisenhower opened the American Red Cross' biggest peacetime fund drive tonight. The campaign's goal is $95,000,000.
This date has a ring around it on the calendars of all the really deepdyed baseball fans. This is the formal ...

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 28--The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A, gave its support today to those who have been exposed to violence and ill-will in their stand for racial integration.

The designation of March as Neighborhood Houses Month has brought again to public attention the work of forty-seven neighborhood houses situated in the lowincome areas of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28-- An added attraction who stirred much favorable comment at the mining engineers' big annual meeting here this week was a geologist named Pauline Moyd.

A NEW symphony by an American should be an oc casion not only for the composer but for the ever hopeful public. Gail Kubik, whose Symphony No. 3 had its premiere at Carnegie Hall last night, did what he could to make a brave noise, and Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic gave his music a rousing reading.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 28-- America was pictured here today as becoming a nation of two-house families. Such a trend was said to be a result of the gigantic Federal interstate highway construction program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28--Israel will announce to the General Assembly tomorrow afternoon the decision to withdraw Israeli forces from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.

LONDON, Feb. 28--Mideastern developments in the United Nations helped Government funds advance today and other sections generally followed suit. In a moderate turnover, gilt edges gained up to 5s (70 cents).
The port's tugboat strike went quietly through its twentyeighth day yesterday. Liners and freighters continued to dock and sail without mishap.
FEW townies stop to search the limestone trim on skyscrapers with eager eye, as Robert G. McCullough does. He finds the stone rich in sermons about forgotten milleniums. In it he's likely to find.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Court of Appeals, in a 3 to 4 decision, revoked today a death benefit award under the Workman's Compensation Act to the widow of a heart attack victim.
The Philco Corporation reported yesterday that its net income last year slumped to $398,690 from $8,423,329 in 1955.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Americans added more than $14,000,000,000 to their savings last year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. This brought the total at year-end to $249,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Eisenhower and Guy Mollet, Premier of France, avoided a direct statement on Middle East policy in a joint communique issued today at the end of their three days of talks.

David Greenberger, a former department store owner who was active in the retail advertising and merchandising field for forty-two years, died Wednesday night at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston, after a long illness. His age was 58.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Congressional Joint Economic Committee and its staff agreed separately today that current economic conditions still called for restraining policies by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Office of Defense Mobilization today authorized rapid tax write-offs for strategic oil and gas pipe lines and petroleum storage facilities. It also announced it is ending the fast tax write-off in certain other fields.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company of Chicago and its subsidiaries achieved new highs in consolidated gas revenues and net income and otherwise had a record year in 1956, according to the annual report released yesterday.
MIAMI, March 1--The Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds will have its twenty-eighth running at Hialeah Race Course tomorrow. The expectation is that it will be a superfine horse race.
NEWARK, March 1--The Newark Housing Authority announced today that it was ready to proceed with the second phase of its $40,000,000 urban redevelopment project.
The annual, city fund campaign of the American Red Cross was officially opened yesterday by Mayor Wagner at City Hall. The Mayor accepted a Red Cross flag and a poster on behalf of the city.

Paolo Rosi defeated Johnny Gonsalves, a lightweight from Oakland, Calif., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision in favor of the Italian was by a split vote.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The future of the tiny sun-baked port of Elath and a six-mile strip of Israeli coastline are at stake in the current United Nations debate on Israel.
THERE must be some kind of fascination in selling stuff. Harrington Richardson, makers of good shotguns, has just announced that it will sell shotguns with brightly colored stocks.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, March 2--Premier Pibul Songgram proclaimed a state of emergency today throughout the Kingdom of Thailand, charging there was a plot to overthrow the Government by force.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 1 (AP)--Bill Nary scrambled into a one-stroke lead today in the second round of the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.
City Hall and the Transit Authority refused to say yesterday whether a union representation election would be held this year among New York's 41,000 transit workers.

The New York State Power Authority signed contracts here yesterday with Reynolds Metals Company and the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation for large blocks of power to be developed on the St. Lawrence River.

The boycott by milk farmers continued to lose ground yesterday. The amount of milk being withheld in the metropolitan area milkshed decreased, but organization work among milk farmers in northern New York increased.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 1 --A decision that could be of great importance to all of Southeast Asia may be made here during the next few days.

The New York Telephone Company started the new year with gains in January of more than $6,300,000 in gross revenues and about $778,000 in net income compared with the January, 1956 levels. This was disclosed yesterday in the company's monthly report filed with the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 1--A proposed increase in New Jersey-New York commutation fares met with unorganized opposition today.
Houston, Tex., raised $16,750,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of schools and an athletics building.

LINCROFT, N.J., March 1 --Mrs. Geraldine Livingston Thompson will not celebrate her eighty-fifth birthday tomorrow. She will leave that triviality to the twenty or thirty relatives and friends who will toast her at Brookdale, her 250-acre farm here.
WARSAW, March 1--Eight leading writers and editors on Poland's main Communist newspaper, Trybunu Ludu, resigned today.
Trading in most commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Most of the volume involved evening of holdings for the week-end.

TRENTON, March 1--Gov. Robert B. Meyner today assailed Republican charges that his Democratic Administration had been guilty of extravagant spending. He characterized the accusations as "stupid and completely insincere."
George Heckman Burgess of 51 Fifth Avenue, managing partner in Coverdale Colpitts, consulting engineers at 120 Wall Street, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 82.
LONDON, March 1--Lady Megan Lloyd George led the Labor party to its third consecutive by-election victory yesterday.
DUBLIN, March 1--A casual visitor to Dublin today would scarcely know that a general election campaign was taking place.

The purchase of a large plot on the West Side for future development was announced yesterday by the Estate Securities Company, realty operators. The company has resold 404 to 412 West Fifty-fourth Street and 405-07 West Fifty-third Street, a plot through the block that it assembled a little more than a year ago.

Net income of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., rose last year to a new high of $14,735,458, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, chairman, and Thomas F. Armstrong, president.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 1 (UP)--The Indiana Legislature today passed a "right-to-work" bill banning the union shop. Thousands of union members made plans to march on the statehouse tomorrow demanding the Governor's veto. But Gov. Harold W. Handley said he would let the bill become law without his signature.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 28--While seemingly immune to the political convulsions that shook neighboring Poland and Hungary last October, Czechoslovakia, is troubled by economic consequences of those upheavals.

New York City got a new junior college yesterday. The State Board of Regents, meeting in Albany, approved a change of status for the New York Institute of Technology, a nonprofit privately supported institution at 500 Pacific Street, Brooklyn.
Modern medical science might wisely take a close look at the Bantu of South Africa a scientist who has studied them for a decade said last night.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 1 (UP)--Negotiators for the state and private landholders reached a tentative, but shaky, agreement today designed to assure the holding of the Olympic winter games at Squaw Valley in 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --Witnesses from Louisiana and Georgia testified today that the civil rights bills now before Congress fitted into a Communist scheme to make trouble for America.

AMERICUS, Ga., March 1 (AP) --Koinonia Farm, a religious community of Negroes and whites, rejected today a Ku Klux Klan suggestion that it sell out "because we feel there are basic principles at stake which we cannot forsake at any cost."

The Oratorio Society of New York, which was cut down to ninety singers for its performance of Handel's "Messiah" last December, was expanded to a membership of 163 voices for its concert last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 1--An Oregon state official told Senators today that high officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had plotted to take over law enforcement in the state "from the District Attorney to the Governor's chair."
"THE style is lush and turgid," Somerset Maugham observes in a bland, biographical overture to a new edition of his novel "The Magician,"* which was written fifty very odd years ago.
The superficiality of many secondary school courses was assailed yesterday by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College.
ALBANY, March 1--Prospects improved today for a start this summer on a major dredging and beach erosion control project in and around Fire island Inlet.
LOS ANGELES, March 1--A State Senate committee concluded today three days of hearings centering on scandal magazines without turning up any notable ideas for curbing their operations.

TUNIS, Tunisia, March 1-- When Vice President Richard M. Nixon and his party visit Tunisia in mid-March they will be guests of one of the most progressive, friendly and pro-Western nations in the Moslem world.

Premier Guy Mollet of France urged Americans yesterday not to sell France short. He said France was undergoing a spiritual revival as well as a physical one, and could be counted on to stand firm for freedom against Communist materialism.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 4 points up to 1 point off, after holding within a narrow range all day.
BELGRADE,Yugoslavia, March 1--Yugoslavia has formally protested against what she called "incitements" against her "territorial integrity" by Albania.

Today's new film is "The Immortal Garrison," a Soviet-made drama in color, at the Cameo. The import, which has English titles, was co-directed by Z. Agranenko and E. Tisse and produced by Mr. Agranenko, from a scenario by Konstantin Simonov.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 1 (UP)--David Jenkins of the United States established himself as a solid favorite to take the men's world figure-skating championship today. He clearly surpassed the others in the field of seventeen in compulsory figures.

CAN a baked Alaska be assembled, complete with me ringue "frosting," then frozen before baking? That question came from a home cook who is planning a party and wants to do as much of the preparation in advance as possible.

AGRA, India, March 1--When the Great Moguls made this splendid site their capital it was difficult neither to define India nor the forces holding it together. India was an empire. Its peoples were subjects of a dynastic power. They were controlled by a stratified hierarchy and military strength.

March arrived in wintry fashion yesterday. Sleet, freezing rain and snow caused some trouble in transportation and made driving conditions hazardous.
Sales of New York City's major department stores averaged 1 per cent higher in February than in the 1956 month according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Harold E. Stassen's special White House group on disarmament planning was made subordinate today to policy directives from John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A Defense Department spokesman said tonight that "something went wrong" when a guided missile was fired today in a test at Patrick Air Force Base in Florida.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is investigating the possibility that certain State Prison inmates who committed crimes both here and in other states had received excessive sentences.
CAIRO, March 1--President Gamal Abdel Nasser is eager to restore diplomatic relations with Britain, according to informed sources, but is in no hurry to repair the break with France.

GLOVE news is a long story. Lengths begin with the onger shortie and end with the evening glove that extends to he shoulder. Following the shorter coat and suit sleeve lengths, gloves this spring will most often stop midway to the elbow or at it. These take on a heath-like look as they mold to the arm.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1-- At this early stage of the Giants' spring training, the left-field job, declared "wide open" by Bill Rigney, the manager, only six days ago, appears to be the property of Hank Sauer.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 1--Events move rapidly and the status of a player can change swiftly on a major league club, especially on a team that travels at the exacting pace of the world champion Yankees.

Forty-nine colleges will send 700-odd athletes into frenzied competition at Madison Square Garden tonight in the thirtysixth annual indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.
THANKS to the American Institute of Graphic Arts, a comprehensive exhibition of Ben Shahn's graphic work has been put on display at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.
CHICAGO, March 1--Net earnings of William Wrigley Jr. Company dipped last year, although sales increased 4.6 per cent, Philip K. Wrigley, president, said today in the annual report to stockholders.
Word that Israel had agreed to quit the Gaza strip and Aqaba sent the stock market vaulting upward in the closing minutes yesterday. That gave the averages a microscopic gain for the week.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)-- Grains made a smart rebound on the Board of Trade here today following the weakness of the previous session.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --President Eisenhower received a report today from a citizens' advisory committee that toured the world to study United States foreign-aid operations.

Christians will begin the penitential season of Lent next week on Ash Wednesday. Lent lasts for forty days and six Sundays until Easter on April 21. It will be marked by special services and fasting for many Christians.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 --The leaders of five Moslem and Christian political parties have urged Attorney General Suprato to take action to prevent further "unfavorable incidents and intimidations" in Jakarta.
Agreement was reached early today on a contract covering 3,500 typographers on ten major daily newspapers in the metropolitan area.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 --Twentieth Century-Fox is losing no time in preparing to film "The Hell Bent Kid," a new novel by Charles O. Locke about Texas and New Mexico in the Eighteen Eighties.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Arthur Miller, playwright, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to an indictment charging contempt of Congress.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 --Bob Darnell was pitching batting practice from the Holman Stadium mound yesterday, and Walt Alston, the Brooklyn manager, was at his usual vantage point behind the cage.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The Republican Administration got some timely Democratic help today in the Senate battle over the military-economic aid section of the pending Middle East resolution.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's bookkeepers once again are making their entries in red ink.

BOSTON, March 1--The Boston Herald Traveler Corporation and its subsidiary radio station WHDH reported today a consolidated net profit of $646,477 in 1956, compared with $758,990 in 1955. Earnings per share were $1.72 as against $2.01.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 (AP)--Gregory Bell of Indiana University, the Olympic broadjump champion, broke his own Western Conference record with a leap of 25 feet 7 inches tonight in the qualifying trials of the forty-seventh annual Big Ten indoor track and field meet.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Two admirals charged today that high manufacturing costs of missiles and defective conventional parts for nuclear reactors were threatening the security of the nation. They addressed a luncheon meeting of the Navy League here.

LONDON, March 1--British Government funds extended early gains today after the announcement of a drop in the Treasury bill rate to 4 per cent. This is the rate that banks and money houses offered on 220,000,000 ...

LONDON, March 1--Three representatives of Euratom concluded a fact-finding tour of the United States and Britain today confident that the prospective European Atomic Energy Community would have the support of both countries.
WASHINGTON, March 1--A bill to put sharp curbs on campaign contributions and expenditures in Federal elections was introduced in the Senate today.
EASTON, Conn., March 1-- Rear Admiral Raymond S. Lamb, U.S.N., retired, died here today at the age of 54.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1--Israel agreed today to the prompt withdrawal of her forces from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1-- The recent Cairo conference of four Arab chiefs of state appears to have resulted in a setback for President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
Chicago financial interests are negotiating to take over control of United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation, and name a Westchester County banker as chief executive officer.

The continuing procession of large new, issues of corporate securities to the market is taking some of the spotlight away from the secondary markets maintained on the public stock exchanges and over the counter.

NEW CITY, N.Y., March 1 --Six men were arrested today in the theft of drugs worth $300,000 at retail. The drugs had been stolen from the Lederle Laboratories in near-by Pearl River. All the suspects are employes of the concern.

PARIS, March 1--In spite of the oil shortage, production and trade in France are undergoing something comparable to a boom. But the imports required to keep the boom going are greater than France can continue to pay for.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --President Eisenhower today nominated Andrew H. Berding, now assistant chief of the United States Information Agency, to be assistant Secretary of State for public affairs.

The most striking development in the automobile industry this year has been the setback for General Motors Corporation. The Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation have scored gains. This is pointed up by the latest production figures.

The work of the Catholic Big Sisters will be furthered by the proceeds of the organization's annual luncheon and bridge part. The fete will take place Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 1 (AP)--Plants of Alco Products, Inc., were shut down today in three cities by a strike of about 4,500 members of the United Steelworkers of America.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- In Thomas Sovereign Gates Jr., the Navy will get an "old salt" and Philadelphia "Main Liner" as its Secretary.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Why did teen-agers get their clothing caught as they left a moving sidewalk, although their elders had no such trouble? A patent issued this week answers the question and promises the youngsters a happy landing.
Representative Porter of Oregon performed a public service in the House on Thursday when he brought up the Galindez case.

Two four-story apartment buildings on a plot 132 by 108 feet at 294 to 312 Webster Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Borey Realty Corporation after an ownership of twenty years. Arthur Maxwell Co. real estate investor, paid cash for the property over a first mortgage of $120,000. The buildings, containing seventy-six apartments, were sold through James Boyd, Inc., broker.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 (AP) --The twentieth running of tomorrow's $144,500 Santa Anita Derby drew fourteen entries today. A California colt, Prince Khaled, is favored to capture the mile-and-a-furlong test for 3year-olds. Each horse will carry 118 pounds.
A dispute broke out yesterday over where George P. Metesky should be lodged pending his trial as New York's "Mad Bomber."
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--A new five-step program designed to help United States merchants sell their goods abroad was announced today by Samuel C. Waugh, president of the ExportImport Bank.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --Senate investigators tried today to link the name of an American diplomat now on duty in the Middle East with that of Harry Dexter White, accused by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. of serving a Soviet spy ring.
LIKE everything else that is mortal, the "Ziegfeld Follies" is susceptible to the infirmities of old age. The edition that opened at the Winter Garden last evening shows symptoms of tired blood.

Three New Jersey shore hotels were burned to the ground and a fourth was badly damaged in fires early yesterday. Property loss was estimated at $800,000. The fact that the hotels had been closed for the winted probably prevented heavy loss of life, authorities state.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Charles S. Thomas resigned today as Secretary of the Navy, effective April 1.
Spokesmen for teachers and community groups yesterday showed a varied reaction to the school integration program adopted on Thursday by the Board of Education.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1--A judgment calling for integration of the public schools here "with all deliberate speed" was affirmed today by the United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.

JERUSALEM, March 1-- After weeks of intricate maneuvering, Premier David BenGurion has had to settle for an agreement on the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba that fell far short of the rigid guarantees he had sought.
RABAT, Morocco, March 1-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon gave Moroccans a demonstration of old-fashioned American political handshaking and baby-admiring today and they liked it.
HAVANA, Saturday, March 2 --Rebel forces under Fidel Castro in Sierra Maestra of Oriente Province have been reduced to about fifty men, the Cuban Army said yesterday.
GAZA, Feb. 28--Three hundred thousand persons, 260,000 of them on relief, can only wait in the sunshine among the golden dunes, oases and mudbuilt villages of the Gaza Strip.

TUNIS, Tunisia, March 3-- Negotiations are nearing completion here for an agreement under which Tunisia will receive economic aid from the United States.
The Minnesota 'Mining and Manufacturing Company set new sales and earnings records in 1956, according to the annual report issued by William L. McKnight, chairman, and Herbert P. Buetow, president.
"SEE IT NOW" examined yesterday afternoon the impact of the Suez crisis on British opinion.

Jim Ethridge and Carl Badger of the Field Club of Greenwich, the country's top squash racquets doubles team, won the final of the annual Arthur H. Lockett invitation tournment at the University Club yesterday.
New York City covers 315 square miles. In less than one square mile of that area are concentrated the rich and fashionable.
Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner, has again criticized Congress for its "piecemeal approach" to housing legislation.

ZLATKO BALOKOVIC walks with The King--with the King Joseph, an almost legendary violin. It was made by the master, Giuseppe (Joseph) del Gesu Guarnieri, 222 years ago. Professionals and collectors speak of it with reverence. It is The King because many think it is the greatest of all violins.

Charles Miller and Samuel Friedman, New York realty investors, have announced their purchase of properties in Westbury, L.I., and Atlantic City. They were represented in the deals by Milton Gerber, a New York attorney.
MIAMI BEACH, March 3-- The United Jewish Appeal started its 1957 campaign here today with contributions of $35,100,000 to help meet Jewish needs throughout the world, with emphasis on Israel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3--If natural ability, hard work and serious thought spell success, Bob Grim should have an excellent season ahead as a Yankee pitcher. Unfortunately there is a little more to it than that.

Heitor Villa-Lobos, Brazil's most famous composer and one of the truly distinguished men of music of our time, will be 70 tomorrow. His energy and enthusiasm are undiminished, and his creative powers remain at flood tide.

It's almost embarrassing. The Putney (Vt.) School, which does not have a major athletic program, has just captured one of the winter's most important athletic championships. In competition against eleven rivals, Putney won the Eastern prep school skiing crown.
AMSTERDAM, March 3--The lower chamber last week had a sharp debate over the Government's proposals to cut general spending. None of the political parties is satisfied.
Five youthful panelists agreed yesterday that tolerance should be the key word in matters of musical taste.

PITTSBURGH, March 3.-- This is the month in which steel records usually are shattered. Due to a lower rate of new business, steel production this month may not reach the 11,000,000-ton goal. But it will not be far from that figure. Backlogs still are heavy and new steel business has, as yet, showed no signs of a serious slump.
THE Roger Wagner Chorale was at Town Hall last night to prove that Los Angeles can produce a musical group with a respect for standards and taste.

MIAMI, March 3--Conn McCreary may be the smallest of the Little Men but he always is wearing the biggest smile. He was beaming from ear to ear in the jockey room late yesterday afternoon immediately after the running of the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah.

LONDON, March 3--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan expressed today his "high hopes" that his meeting with President Eisenhower would clear away differences between their countries and lead to a common policy in the future.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 --Emmett Kelly made his clowning debut and the "Pitlers" beat the "Hermans, 4--0, in the Dodgers' first intrasquad game today. More than 3,000 fans, admitted free, were at Holman Stadium, quite a number apparently attracted by the former Ringling Brothers circus clown.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3-- Whether it be as a first baseman or a left fielder, Carroll (Whitey) Lockman returned to the Giants today determined to win a regular job.
TOKYO, March 3--Japanese Foreign Ministry analysts expect a Chinese Communist move through India for closer ties between Peiping and Tokyo, it was reported today.
JAIPUR, India, March 3--A happy child might have imagined the absurd, pink city or Jaipur with its brilliantly costumed women, bright turbans, palaces, peacocks, camels, ...

Mrs. Miriam Sutro Price, who was long active in educational affairs, died Saturday in her home, 35 East Eighty-fourth Street, after a long illness. Her age was 84. She was the widow of Joseph M. Price, a leader in the Fusion movement here and chairman of the City Club.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) --A private committee to promote the return of confiscated German and Japanese assets announced today that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had agreed to join the group, then changed her mind.

ALTHOUGH Franklin D. Roosevelt died less than twelve years ago the number of books written about him has already passed all counting. First the reporters and journalists had their say. Then Roosevelt's political associates were heard from, carefully putting their best feet forward. Then his political enemies filed their dissenting opinions.
Judge John A. Mullen said yesterday that there was no "tension" between him and Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross in the case of George Metesky, the "mad bomber".
Republican leaders in Albany are considering increased state aid, instead of a $10,000,000, share of motor vehicle registration fees, to compensate the city for loss of its auto use tax.

A Protestant denomination that predates the Reformation by nearly a century celebrated the 500th anniversary of its founding yesterday. Members of the Moravian Church held special services in New York and over the world.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) --The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee called today for restrictions on Tass, the Soviet news agency.

THERE is nothing shady about the window-watching that has been going on in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for the last two years. In fact, the project, under the auspices of Abraham Straus, is strictly educational --shedding light on the decorating problem of shielding walls of glass.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 3-- Miss Claire Garber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron I. Garber, was married this afternoon to Lawrence Baron Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hirsch Goodman of New York. Rabbi James Max performed the ceremony in the Venetian Room of the Peabody Hotel.
BONN, Germany, March 3-- The terms of West Germany's financial contributions to Britain's defense effort were announced here today.
A well-born septuagenarian spinster was recently asked, "What is society in New York?"

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 3 --More than a thousand West German business companies exhibited products at the opening today of East Germany's Leipzig Fair. It was an imprsessive demonstration of the eagerness of Western business to deal with East Germany and the rest of the Communist bloc.

BOSTON, March 3 (AP)--The Boston Celtics clinched their first Eastern Division crown in the eleven-year history of the National Basketball Association by defeating the Rochester Royals, 111--102, today.
ECONOMIC CONCENTRATION AND THE MONOPOLY PROBLEM. By Edward S. Mason. 411 pp. Harvard University Press, Cambridge. $6.
GIVE Ohrbach's an inch and they'll take an ell. The latest intelligence from this store is that spring coats are doing to any lengths just to be fashionable.
A Unitarian minister told his congregation here yesterday that Americans, "with their split personalities," have the bad habit of "questioning too much and living too little."
BATON ROUGE, La., March 3 (AP)--Jimmy Demaret's deadly putting and steady iron play gained a one-stroke victory today in the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his support of seven pension bills involving at least $2,000,000 of annual burden on the city's expense budget.
Leslie Morris of Bergdorf Goodman must design in an ivory tower.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 3 --Pakistan will not agree to have legal points involved in the Kashmir dispute with India referred to the International Court of Justice, Foreign Minister Malik Firoz Khan Noon said today.

Although Tuxedo Park held its first Autumn Ball in 1886, New York did not see its first important mass presentation of debutantes until 1935. The occasion was the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, which now is held annually for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

Disquieting and puzzling developments are taking place in Warsaw. High-ranking Stalinists who opposed last October's peaceful Polish revolution are retaining or gaining positions of power and influence.
This port's 4,000 striking tugboat workers decided yesterday to press for better terms before settling the port's longest waterfront labor dispute. The strike is now entering its thirty-second day.
Pope Pius XII, who observed his eighty-first birthday and the eighteenth anniversary of his election to the papacy on March 2, was honored yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
CAIRO, March 3--The Egyptian press inveighed today against Israel's stalling on her promises to withdraw promptly from the Gaza strip and the Sharm el Sheikh area on the Gulf of Aqaba.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3--Thirty-one students arrested early this morning during riots at Massachusetts Institute of Technology will face charges tomorrow in the East Cambridge District Court.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3--"The Young Lovers," a first novel by Julian Halevy, published in 1955, will be filmed toward the end of this year by Samuel Goldwyn Jr.

BERLIN, N.H., March 3-- Ansten Samuelstuen, the 27year-old electronics technician from Boulder, Colo., won his first national jumping championship today as the Nansen Ski Club's two-day meet was concluded.
BONN, Germany, March 3-- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano is regarded as a sound European who can always be relied upon to do the proper thing where the North Atlantic alliance is concerned.
VIENNA, March 3--Faced with continuous provocations from Hungary, the Austrian Government is considering reprisals.
Detour signs because of "icy" conditions have been posted on Ocean Track Charlie, the world's busiest shipping lane, linking United States ports with harbors in Northwest Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- This is a town of custom, and it has become almost a ritual for the President to be guest of honor at the annual dinners of the Gridiron Club, the White House Correspondents Association, the White House Photographers Association, the Radio and Television Correspondents Association and the Women's National Press Club.
The New York Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings spent sixty minutes on the treadmill last night. After exchanging a number of body checks and mad rushes, the sextets wound up in a 1-to-1 tie.
The Metropolitan Opera Employes Welfare Fund will benefit from a special nonsubscription performance of "La Boheme" to be given on March 17 in the opera house.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The authority of Congressional committees to require witnesses to disclose the names of associates in Communist activities has been supported by the American Bar Association.
Despite a slight reduction last year in the number of seamen employed the number of reported injuries and illnesses increased.

BOSTON, March 3 (UP)--Don McKenney scored a pair of goals and assisted on two others to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-2 National Hockey League victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,909.

BANGKOK, Thailand , March 3--The state of emergency that was proclaimed for Bangkok early yesterday remained in effect today, but the city was calm. Several of the tanks that rumbled into the sunny streets yesterday had disappeared. However, armored cars and troops armed with machine guns still occupied strategic positions in the city.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 3--Stock Exchange business in Zurich all last week, for want of any stimulus, was listless, and price movements were vague. The sole exception was trading in Royal Dutch, largely buying on Paris account.
ALBANY, March 3--The Judicial Conference has asked the Legislature to give the four Appellate Divisions broad Supervisory powers over all lower courts except the Court of Claims.

Four provinces of eastern Indonesia have set up a provisional regime and declared their revolt against rule by the central Indonesian Government of President Sukarno, seated in Jakarta on the island of Java. Thus far, happily, it is a political, not a military, civil war. This may change, and for the worse.
Activity in the steamship charter market was fairly strong last week, but rates continued the downward trend of the last month.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The Senate heads toward a final vote on President Eisenhower's Middle East resolution this week. An easy victory for the Administration is expected on Tuesday or Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- A month of intense diplomatic activity began today with the arrival here of Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 3 --K.A. Fagerholm, Socialist Premier, said tonight that "further concessions are out" as a means of getting dissident Agrarian ministers to return to the coalition Government.
New York's mental health problems are part of the city's growing pains, the director of the Community Mental Health Board said last week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 3--Glen Foster, at the tiller of Ordeal, today led the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite fleet for the seventh time during the current championship season. He totaled 190 of a possible 210 points, 5 more than Arthur Knapp Jr., the season leader, had with Agony.

OMAHA, Neb., March 3 (AP)-- Former President Truman charged tonight that "as the result of drift and procrastination," both the Middle East and Europe had been threatened and the United States defenses weakened.

Ambassador Abba Eban of Israel declared yesterday that his Government would "respect its legal and moral commitments" as expressed Friday to the United Nations General Assembly by Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3-- Congressional elections were held throughout Chile today with only a few minor incidents reported.
A welfare leader said yesterday that about 2,000 teen-age Hungarian refugees "on the loose" in Austria were posing a "real moral problem."
The passage of a state "rightto-work" law in Indiana is spurring farm and employer groups to more intensive efforts to outlaw the union shop by state action.
ALBANY, March 3--The counsel to the Public Service Commission charged today that the New York Telephone Company had spent $500,000 over the last fifteen months

Cotton futures prices moved in a narrow trading range last week and were generally lower at the close. On Friday futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 3 points (15 cents a bale) higher to 17 points (85 cents) lower than at the close of the preceding week.

There are occasions, according to at least one student of monetary policy, when the timing of a given course of action by the monetary authorities may be more important than the decision to take such action.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 3-- Among the nations convalescing from the Suez crisis Iraq is doing fairly well.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)-- A predominantly Protestant organization said today it had asked the Federal Communications Commission to deny television licenses to Jesuit universities in New Orleans and St. Louis.
The Metropolitan Opera's twentieth week will open on March 11 with "Lucia di Lammermoor." Lily Pons will make her first appearance of the season singing the title role.
Churches over the country yesterday commended the American Red Cross to the charity of their congregations. Many of them stationed white-uniformed volunteers at the doors to collect donations.
Adoption of a management recruit program to avert a shortage of trained administrative personnel was urged upon Mayor Wagner yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3--A conflict within the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union erupted today in a manner seldom matched in the labor movement.

CONSTANTLY changing in design are our clothes (at least women's clothes), cars, kitchen appliances, television sets and furniture. In contrast, our food and the way we prepare and present it seem static, divorced from shifting whims, the same now as yesterday and probably tomorrow.

LONDON, March 3--Two developments in the industrial field struck a cheerful note for Britain last week. The week started with confirmation of a surprising spurt by the coal miners. It ended with news that seemed to suggest the worst was over for the hard-hit automobile manufacturers after twelve months of trouble.
Eastern Air Lines announced last week plans for a $5,000,000 electronic reservations center in midtown Manhattan.
SIXTY cameras employed yesterday by "Wide Wide World" over Channel 4 brought viewers a varied program entitled "A Man's Story."

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., March 3 --Former Mayor Charles H. Demarest, who had been identified with the importing business in New York for sixty-one years, died here today at his home, 33 Clarendon Place, of a heart ailment. He was 76 years old.
ALBANY, March 3--Governor Harriman was urged today to order an investigation of "sinister Communist influences and shocking mismanagement" in the New York City Housing Authority.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 3 (AP)--Executing daring spins and leaps that no one else attempted, Dave Jenkins of the United States won the men's world figure skating championship last night.

Summer trials, which were held last year to reduce congestion and delay in personal injury cases, have been ordered again this year in the New York metropolitan area.
