BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 3-- A British concern, Balfour Beatty Co., Ltd., has been awarded a 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) contract by the Iraqi Development Board to build the Faisaliyah regulator dam on the Euphrates River.
Miss Alice Carroll Maisner and Stanton Irwin Robbins were married yesterday afternoon in the Park Lane by the Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson of Central Synagogue.
CHICAGO, March 3--Prices for grain and soybean futures worked irregularly downward most of last week.

NEWBRIDGE, Ireland, March 3--Gerald Sweetman, Minister for Finance in the outgoing Government of Prime Minister John A. Costello, implied today that neither he nor his party wanted any votes from Irish Republican Army sympathizers.

ROME, March 3--Italy created today a Ministry of State Participations. Giuseppe Togni, leader of a right-of-center faction of the dominant Christian Democratic party was appointed head of the new department.

The Actors Fund benefit performance of "Waltz of the Toreadors" did not take place at the Coronet as scheduled last night because a throat ailment prevented Sir Ralph Richardson from appearing in his starring role.

LONDON, March 4--Gold and dollar reserves of Britain and the sterling area rose by $63,000,000 in February despite the extra cost of oil bought from the Western Hemisphere, the Treasury announced today.

Lenox Hill Neighborhood House has served persons living in the East Side area from Fifty-Ninth to Ninety-sixth Streets for sixtythree years.

Bond issues totaling $20,000,000 to finance public school construction were listed for sale yesterday by city school districts of Los Angeles, Calif. The date of sale is April 2. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1957, and will come due serially on May 1 from 1958 to 1982.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4--A torrential downpour sent the Yankees' workout down the drain today. But it didn't stop Casey Stengel.

PIRANDELLO'S "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)," in a version by Eric Bentley, received an uneven but not unprovocative airing last night at Carl Fischer Hall. The uneveness stems from the casting, which is, life the little girl with the curl, either very, very good--or horrid.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4--The Yugoslav people seem relieved by the country's refusal to move back into the Soviet camp.
CHICAGO, March 4--In the wheat pit today the old crop months showed moderate strength while the new crop deliveries were inclined to ease, losing as much as 1 cents a bushel at the close.

EMMITSBURG, Md., March 4 --Mount St. Mary's basketball team recorded its seventeenth consecutive victory tonight, downing City College, 93--84, in a first-round contest of the National Collegiate tournament, college division.
CHICAGO, March 4--Senator Paul H. Douglas, accused private utilities today of "sneaking in the back door" of the United States Treasury.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Administration officials said today that they hoped "wild man" housing schemes in Congress would be headed off by their plan to liberalize down-payment terms on Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

AN esteemed member of the school of Paris, Gerard Schneider, whose recent abstractions are on view at the Kootz Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, has been moving steadily in a direction shared by a number of American painters.
JERUSALEM, March 4--Premier David Ben-Gurion ordered the Israeli Army today to withdraw from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba region.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 4 (UP)--Clint Courtney, the Washington Senators' last holdout, signed today for a slight increase in salary.

OTTAWA, March 4--North American trade stands to benefit, rather than to lose, from an integrated European Economic Community, Premier Guy Mollet of France told a joint session of the Canadian Senate and the Commons today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 4-- An apparent swing to the political center in Chile was emerging tonight from the still confused results of yesterday's Congressional elections.

Group Health Insurance, Inc., a nonprofit medical care plan serving the metropolitan area, has taken a lease on a full floor, with a total of 22,000 square feet, in 225 Fourth Avenue, at the corner of Eighteenth Street. Williams Co. was the broker.

A rapid increase in the women's labor force in the next ten years will necessitate Federal support for the city's day care centers for children of working mothers, Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday.

Sales and earnings for the year ended Dec. 29, higher than a year earlier, were announced yesterday by the Celanese Corporation of America. The company is a major producer of filament yarn and staple fiber made from cellulose acetate.
Leaders of three organizations representing 41,000 dairy farmers asserted yesterday that they "will not tolerate delaying tactics" and demanded speedy Federal action against a "cost-price squeeze."
CAIRO, March 4 (Reuters)-- Dr. Helmy Bahgat Badawi, chairman of the Egyptian Suez Canal Authority, died of a heart ailment today. His age was 56.
Wastern Union Telegraph Company started 1957 with higher January operating revenues and net income, the company reported yesterday.

Gil Turner of Philadelphia scored the thirty-fifth knockout triumph of his career at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. He floored Rudy Gwin of Cleveland for the count of 10 at 2:19 of the fourth round in their scheduled ten-round bout.
Coordinated Hungarian Relief will benefit from a Salute to the Freedom Fighters of Hungary dinner to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 3.
The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. denied yesterday that it was attempting to bar from the air waves the more conservative branches of Protestantism.
A 30,000,000-to-1 shot provided Radio Station WQXR with a collector's item yesterday.

The National Basketball Association's post-season play-off pool has been increased to $50,000, Maurice Podoloff, the president of the league, said yesterday. The sum is 6,500 higher than last year's pool.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4--A military spokesman for Thailand said today that the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization had given information to officials here about a reported plot to overthow the pro-Western Bangkok Government.

WINSTED, Conn., March 4-- Herman H. Smith, who retired in 1934 as Chief Engineer of the New York City Board of Estimate, died here today after a long illness. He was 81 years old on Saturday.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company increased its life insurance in force at the end of 1956 by 10.2 per cent, a gain of $6,755,000,000 over 1955. This was the largest gain achieved in the industry, Frederic W. Ecker, president, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, March 4--Egypt continues to take a cynical view of President Eisenhower's Middle East policies despite a grudging admission that the United States was the compelling force in the Israeli decision to withdraw.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 4-- Roman Catholic parents began enrolling their children today in crowded public schools in a campaign to force city authorities to provide bus transportation to parochial schools.

ALBANY, March 4--The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate tonight a bill designed to block approval of a $55,400,000 rate increase sought by the New York Telephone Company.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4--Don Newcombe of the Dodgers today quit after ten minutes of pitching batting practice because of a sore elbow. It was only the second time since he started training on Feb. 20 that Newk had worked batting practice.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Senate opened today its third week of debate on President Eisenhower's Middle East proposals.
ALBANY, March 4--Reversing an earlier decision, the Republican legislative leadership agreed today that this year's primary election should be held in the fall instead of the spring.

WASHINGTON, March 4--"The Air Force has become a part of my body," said Harold E. Talbott to the Senate investigators, and the simple words are his true and fitting epitaph. From his interment that part survived; it has grown in strength and efficiency ever since it became one with him, and for that reason.

MIAMI, March 4 (AP)--Willie Hartack continued his sensational riding as the Hialeah meeting closed today. Aboard Jabneh, he won the $106,350 Hialeah Turf Handicap for his sixty-second victory of the forty-day program.
Katherine Sutter, soprano, and Jean Gressley, mezzo-soprano, made a joint appearance last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Miss Sutter has sung with the St. Louis Opera and the St. Louis Symphony.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4--The National Broadcasting Company's "Wide Wide World" is going to be all up in the air on March 17. It will be more than a figure of speech, for the program will be devoted to a resume of man's achievements in flight.
The Teachers Guild has asked the State Education Commissinner to dismiss the members of the city Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Scovel Richardson, chairman of the United States Parole Board, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a judge of the United States Customs Court.
The General Shoe Corpoartion had net sales of $57,623,000 and net income of $1,605,000, equal to 58 cents a common share, in the quarter ended Jan. 31, it was announced yesterday in Nashville, Tenn.
Workmen atop the partly dismantled tenth story of the old Marguery apartment hotel were joined in their demolition job yesterday by a new helpmate.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- When Scovel Richardson takes his seat on the United States Customs Court, returning travelers who get in trouble with the Customs Service will face a judge who learned how to be tough in the boxing ring.
David E. Frankenstein, son-inlaw of the late Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, was indicted yesterday for evading $13,259 in Federal income taxes for 1950 and 1951.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4--The Soviet Union and India launched an attack today on the "assumptions" under which Israel has agreed to withdraw from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.
Power failures blacked out thousands of homes in the Bronx and Brooklyn for more than an hour last night.
The American Tramp Shipowners Association has temporarily vacated the offices of president and vice president and placed all administrative functions in the office of executive secretary.
LAKE WALES, Fla., March 4 --William Ayres Aglar Cook, board chairman of the Topics Publishing Company of New York, died today at his Mountain Lake home here after a brief illness. His age was 67.
"YOU are one of the consciences of our time," Georges Bidault said to Pablo Casals when he presented the great cellist with the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- United States officials generally welcomed somewhat wryly today the order by Premier BenGurion of Israel for a withdrawal from the Gaza Strip and the Gulf of Aqaba area.

ALBANY, March 4--A difference of opinion has arisen in the Legislature over the desirability and necessity of enacting the "gallon jug" bill. The measure would male clear that mills could be sold in gallon containers.
ST. LOUIS, March 4 (AP)--Dr. Evarts A. Graham, the first surgeon to remove successfully an entire human lung, died today.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, declared after a two-hour talk with Secretary of State Dulles today that West Germany and the United States were "in complete agreement on all basic questions."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4--Universal halted filming today on "My Man Godfrey" because of the illness of June Allyson, who was said to have a "mild" case of pneumonia. She is in the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center for treatment.

The clash of British and United States policy over the Middle East last fall in the United Nations was reviewed over the dinner table last night by representatives of the two nations.

President Eisenhower was represented by his personal physician, Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder, at the funeral service here yesterday afternoon for Harold E. Talbott, former Secretary of the Air Force.

Record earnings of $32,134,989 were announced yesterday by the Boeing Airplane Company in its report for 1956.

The British Labor party, having won three by-elections in a row, is justified in feeling collectively happy. Laborites sense that the winds of destiny are blowing their way, and they have some justification.

In its first change of ownership in twenty-five years the five-story apartment house at 642 Fox Street, the Bronx, was sold by Sophie Gross to a client of Leon Bizar.

Edward R. Murrow has filmed an eight-and-a-half-hour interview with former President Harry S. Truman. The commentator said excerpts of the film might be used for a television program, but that no definite decision had been made.

ST. LOUIS, March 5--T. Lamar Caudle and Matthew J. Connelly, former officials in the Truman Administration, were sentenced to two years in prison and fined $2,500 each today on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government in an income tax case.
Madison and Boys High yesterday gained the semi-final round in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs at Madison Square Garden.

American tourists visiting Europe this summer will be able to travel comfortably and under generally normal conditions, Ralph T. Reed, president of the American Express Company, said here yesterday.

The American Surety Company of New York had net written premiums of $40,407,033 last year, $2,366,750 above the 1955 level, according to the annual report released yesterday.

TWO men long in Police Department service got to wondering out loud in headquarters lobby the other day about James Cahill, killed in the line of duty in 1854. They wondered who he was and how he came to his death.

THOUGH raw potato pancakes are seen most often in the company of sauerbraten, they also furnish, in a team with apple sauce, a delicious luncheon dish. This fact comes to mind on Ash Wednesday, start of Lent, when many home cooks are brushing up on their repertories of meatless dishes.
The city-wide campaign to eradicate polio received new backing yesterday with the formation of a citizens' group to promote Salk vaccine injections among members of civic and business organizations.

A telegram asking Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson for emergency price increases for milk farmers was sent yesterday by the Dairy Farmers of America. Spokesmen warned a Federal hearing here that farmers caught in a cost squeeze might start new boycotts.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the Administration would like to reverse its ban against permitting newsmen to go to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- President Eisenhower proposed to Congress today that the states pay 25 per cent of certain farm disaster relief operations.
CHICAGO, March, 5--All wheat futures were strong today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Reports of fair amounts of moisture in parts of the hard winter wheat belt acted as a brake on the rallies.

The Liberal party decided last night to hold a city convention, probably in June, to pick a ticket for the municipal election this fall.
The first annual Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards were made yesterday in a ceremony at the Ambassador Hotel.

NILOKHERI, India, March 5--A significant test of democracy's efficiency as a system valid for under-developed Asia is taking place in India's villages. More than four-fifths of this country's immense population dwells in some 550,000 hamlets.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 5 (AP)--A big DC-7 airliner cruising at 14,000 feet cast a propeller today, which slashed off the cabin top above the heads of forty-one passengers.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Legislation sponsored by New Yorkers in Congress for the development of additional hydroelectric power from the Niagara River won Administration approval today.

Three short plays by a renowned Irish dramatist, John Millington Synge, will be presented at 8 o'clock tonight at Theatre East, 211 East Sixtieth Street. The bill is made up of "In the Shadow of the Glen," "The Tinker's Wedding" and "Riders to the Sea."

The United Automobile Workers plans to set up an outside appeals "court" to which its 1,385,000 members can turn if they feel they have not received justice from the union's own disciplinary machinery.

The four-story building occupied by the American Theatre Wing at 351 West Forty-eighth Street has been sold by the Gracemont Corporation, Harry Glickman, president, to an investing client of Walter Scott Co. L.J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company was the broker.

The Eisenhower Doctrine for the protection of the Middle East against Communist aggression scored a conclusive triumph yesterday in Congress when the Senate endorsed a program for that area already approved by the House of Representatives.
A prolonged and stormy hearing on fluoridating the city's water to cut tooth decay is expected today.
The State of Massachusetts is going ahead with plans to borrow money at long term in the public market, but on a reduced scale. The Bay State is calling for bids on March 19

Two men were burned fatally yesterday in a fire that destroyed a factory building in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. Two hundred persons escaped injury.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru apologized tonight to Queen Elizabeth for the "wholly intemperate" article published in an Indian magazine criticizing the Queen's recent visit to Portugal.

The pathetic story of seven women arrested for loitering in a lounge at Pennsylvania Station was unfolded yesterday before an incredulous magistrate in Manhattan Arrest Court. The women, six of whom are homeless, range from 45 to 72 years old.

FROM the pages of history, Leslie Stevens has writ ten a distinguished television drama called "The Duel." This story of the festering enmity between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr was presented expertly last night on the "Kraft Theatre" over Channel 4.

The city's largest bank made yesterday what it described as the smallest business loan in its history, and possibly in all banking history. It was a sixty-day unsecured loan of $15 to a Manhattan apron manufacturing concern.

BIRMINGHAM, March 6 (AP) --Angry white men, frustrated in efforts to bar a Negro minister and his wife from a white waiting room at a railroad station, attacked a white man who sat beside them today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6-- Where is Ruben Gomez? The Giants are mystified by the absence of the Puerto Rican righthander, who signed his contract in mid-January and has not been heard from since.

The long of it, 7-foot Wilt Chamberlain of Kansas, and the short, 5-foot-9-inch Chet Forte, Columbia's high-scoring guard, were two of the four players named on both The Associated Press and United Press All-America basketball squads yesterday.
The twenty-sixth annual luncheon and bridge party, for the benefit of the Loyola School and the Jesuit Seminary Fund will be held on March 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
NEW CASTLE, Del., Thursday, March 7--A Navy tanker collided with a Liberian freighter off this city early today. The tanker exploded, burned and sank.

Vassily Smyslov, the 35-yearold challenger for the chess championship of the world, yesterday gained a victory in the first of a series of twenty-four games with Mikhail Botvinnik, the champion since 1948.
Specialists from four Federal agencies will start sniffing scientifically soon to trace sources of smog and smoke in the New York-New Jersey area.

Alfred J. Allen, assistants director of the American Foundation for the Blind since 1944, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was in an ambulance en route from his home at 162-03 Eightyfourth Drive, Jamaica, Queens, to Queens General Hospital, Jamaica. His age was 55.

James A. Brewer, treasurer of the Advertising Club of New York for eighteen years and a founder of the Brewer-Cantelmo Company, Inc., died Tuesday at his home near Tucson, Ariz., after a long illness. His age was 70. The concern manufactures sales portfolios and binders.

MOSCOW, March 6--The Soviet Communists tried today to raise the level of their argument with Yugoslavia from the bitter name-calling of recent months to a more moderate discussion of their differences.

WASHINGTON, March 6--A confessed gambler who is now cooperating with a Senate committee estimated today that his pay-offs to union racketeers probably had run close to $20,000 over an eight-month period.

In 1956, for the first time since Lloyds Register of Shipping, recognized authority on maritime statistics, began keeping records, Britain was replaced as the world's Number One peacetime shipbuilder. The leading shipbuilder of the world in 1956 was Japan.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 6-- President Ngo Dinh Diem approved in principle today a suggestion for a "common market" for Southeast Asia on the pattern nearing adoption in Western Europe.

The Penn-Texas Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court here against a minority stockholder group. The suit charges that Alfons Landa, Washington attorney and head of the group, and others were guilty of conspiracy and deception.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked by an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage unless specified.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 5--Czechoslovak intellectuals have found an indirect outlet for their dissatisfaction with the existing order.
Harold J. Learoyd, former cheif make-up editor of The New York Times, died early yesterday this home, 162 Daniel Low Terrrace, St. George, S.I. He was 90 years old.

SYRACUSE, March 6--The New York Knickerbockers kept their hopes alive in their last-ditch stand to gain an Eastern Division play-off berth by checking the Syracuse Nationals, 100 to 93, in a National Basketball Association game at War Memorial Auditorium tonight.

THAT fit of indecision you had about the choice of the living room curtains doesn't mean that you are on your way to a mental clinic. It merely means that you suffered a conflict of your ego, pleasure and group drives.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 (AP) --Pylades, unheralded in a field of seven, upset the heavily favored Terrang and Duc de Fer today to win the $28,050 Santa Barbara Handicap. A crowd of 23,500 saw the Santa Anita Park feature.
ALBANY, March 5--The state's practice of paying real estate taxes on state-owned land to some communities but not to others came under heavy fire from a special legislative committee today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 6--Premier David Ben-Gurion won a vote of confidence in Parliament today by 84 to 25. The vote came a few hours before Israeli civilian adminis- ... trators began withdrawing from the Gaza Strip.
HARTFORD, March 6--Connecticut will have four chief justices of the State Supreme Court in the next fourteen months.
The rank and file of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, beset by reports of corruption in the top echelon ef the union, has finally heard from its wondering president.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 6--William Johnson, a baritone who starred last year on Broadway in "Pipe Dream," died early this morning of a heart attack in the Flemington Medical Center. He would have been 42 years old March 22.
TOMORROW, 3:30 P.M.: Stories and slides of Scandinavian countries will be presented at the New York Public Library's Great Kills Branch, 56 Giffords Lane, Staten Island.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 --The Hecht--Hill--Lancaster Company, following in the footsteps of Michael Todd, today settled an involved dispute with the Writers Guild of America, West, and removed a strike threat announced last January.

TOKYO, March 5--Premier Nobusuke Kishi has begun formally mobilizing Japan's best business brains to assist the Government in realizing his plan of aggressive "economic diplomacy" in Southeast Asia and elsewhere.
Howard Fast has attacked the Soviet system as "socialism without morality" and has called for the removal of the present Soviet leadership.

The five-story building containing twenty-three apartments and three stores at 944 East 165th Street, near Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Petra, Inc., to an investing client of Mrs. Clara Tepper, attorney.

The Twelve-story building at 5 to 9 West Thirty-seventh Street--it forms part of the Franklin Simon department store property at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street--has been sold by the Ottinger Estate to the Joseph S. Askin Estate.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6--It was such a routine play last season that Don Bessent watched with unconcern. His mind automatically reached out and scratched another mark on his mental blackboard. This would be his thirty-ninth consecutive inning of relief pitching without yielding a run.

DUBLIN, Thursday, March 7 --Returns early today from Tuesday's general election for Ireland's new Dail (Parliament) showed a swing away from the parties in Prime Minister John A. Costello's coalition Government.
Even in an uncomplicated household, keeping the family checking account in balance often proves a chore. For the Treasury it is a full-time job.

Ski Sketch: Heloisa Albuquerque, a 26-year-old brunette from Rio de Janeiro, saw snow for the first time last Christmas. She was en route to Stowe, Vt., with a party of friends from Wilmington, Del., where she is employed as a secretary.
ALBANY, March 6--Today was "Bait Robert Moses Day" in the State Senate.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 6-- Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of this new nation, told Vice President Richard M. Nixon today that he should need the "cooperation" of the United States to make Ghana successful.
LONDON, March 6--The stock market was generally depressed again today, though it steadied toward the close on news of an improvement in the Middle East situation.
PARIS, March 6--Paul Ramadier, Minister of Finance, announced tonight the start of a new public loan to ease the strain on French finances.
GAZA, Thursday, March 7-- The Gaza Strip went under United Nations administration early today.
For the first time in several months, a decline was reported last week in the nation's gasoline stocks. At the week-end supplies amounted to 203,749,000 barrels.
The Federal Maritime Board was asked formally yesterday to approve the planned purchase by Moore-McCormack Lines of the Seas Shipping Company and its Robin Line fleet.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Secretary of State Dulles departed by air for Australia today on a mission that will shift his attention from the diplomatic quagmire of the Middle East to Communist subversion in Southeast Asia.
Securities of three public utility companies amounting to more than $41,000,000 are being offered today to investors. The offerings are:
CHICAGO, March 6--The Allstate Insurance Company will enter the life insurance field "at an early date," the company announced today.
The tight money market has resulted in a substantial financial windfall for the Transit Authority.
The State of Rhode Island borrowed $13,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of highways and welfare institutions.

Chilean elections are always complicated and last Sunday's was exceptionally so. Even when we have all the returns it will be difficult to analyze it precisely, but we can, as of today, at least note the trends and hazard some guesses.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6--The United States called off a move today to reopen the Hungarian question in the United Nations General Assembly.

BONN, Germany, March 6-- The Social Democratic party has asked for a parliametary investigation of alleged militaristic and nationalistic indoctrination of the officer corps of the new West German Army.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) --A spokesman for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations described today Administration proposals to extend minimum wage coverage as "not only too late, but even worse, they are far too little."
The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to push the city's long-range plan to open the entire length of Rockaway Beach, Queens, as a public waterfront and recreation area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6--Projects centering on earthmoving tractors and airborne Army dogs have been added to the National Broadcasting Company's list of filmed series scheduled for viewing next fall.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 6 (Reuters)--Harold Connolly of Boston, Olympic hammer-throwing champion, and the attractive Czech athlete he hopes to marry are still uncertain whether Government officials will approve their matrimonial plans.
City Councilinan Edward A. Cunningham, Democrat of the Bronx, testified for an hour and a half yesterday before a New York County grand jury investigating his business activities.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6 --Walter F. O'Malley conferred this afternoon with a contingent of Los Angeles city and county officials.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Government departments and agencies have been asked to help Congress cut the Administration's $71,800,000.000 budget for the fiscal year starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, said today that the unification of Germany must come on terms allowing an "unbreakable alliance with the free world."

WASHINGTON, March 6--An effort began in the Senate on Washington's Birthday to shatter a kind of "entangling alliance" other than the one the first President warned the nation against in his Farewell Address.
The St. Joseph Lead Company and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation are studying a joint venture proposal to develop an iron ore deposit in east central Missouri.

MONTREAL, March 6 (U.P.)-- A United Nations "task force" warned today that jetliners might be unable to operate in southern Europe and the Mediterranean by 1959 because of critical deficiencies in communications.
AT Tiffany's, where progress is becoming as much a byword as tradition, the engraved stationery is being "souped up" with a new alphabet.
More than 600 partisans crowded into City Hall yesterday for a public hearing on whether the city's water supply should be fluoridated.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Democrats revived the politically explosive Hell's Canyon issue at a Senate hearing today with a warning that the United States was falling behind the Soviet Union in development of new power-generating capacity.
Possibly because of headlines announcing that Israeli troops had begun their withdrawal from Egyptian territory, the stock market jumped sharply in the final thirty minutes yesterday.

CAIRO, March 6--The statement by Secretary of State Dulles yesterday that Egypt had been slowing clearing operations in the Suez Canal and that he hoped she would cease doing so now that Israel had agreed to withdraw was unfavorably received by Egyptian authorities.
Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts told the Democrats yesterday they needed "new ideas, new policies and new faces" to stay in business.

ALBANY, March 6--The outlook wasn't brilliant for Little League baseball today until Assemblyman Louis Wallach strode to the legislative plate, brandishing a bill. measure, he said, was designed to keep midget baseball alive in the face of a serious threat from a most unlikely opponent, the State Workmen's Compensation Board.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6--Maj. Gen. E.L.M. Burns will "do what he thinks necessary" when United Nations troops occupy the Gaza Strip, a United Nations spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Administration forces in the House set out today to defeat a Democratic bill aimed at helping producers of corn and other livestock feed. Republican spokesmen denounced it as a political monstrosity.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)-- Wheat and soybean futures fell in active dealings on the Board of Trade here today, wiping out part of the gains of the previous session.
IF you need proof of the power of the spoken word, lis ten to the three plays by John Millington Synge that opened last evening at Theatre East, 211 East Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, March 6--The Syrian Government has informed the Iraq Petroleum Company that repair of its pumping stations may begin, and that pumping of oil through the pipelines to the Mediterranean may be resumed.
CHICAGO, March 6--Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today a record volume of business in 1956 and said sales this January were the highest for any month in the company's history.
ALBANY, March 6--The Republican program to expand the state's scholarship system was approved unanimously by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Mareh 6--Manager Casey Stengel has installed a midnight curfew on his Yankees. From other major league training camps comes word that other managers are beginning to toughen up a bit.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Bertschmann of New York and Torremolinos, Spain, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Bertschmann, to Philippe Crokaert. His parents are M. and Mme. Pierre Crokaert of Brussels, Belgium, and San Sebastian, Spain.

With the Middle Eastern situation shifting from the level of force to the level at diplomacy, new efforts are under way to solve the problem of Europe, which involves the North Atlantic alliance and to which the reunification of Germany is the key.
Despite a brilliant performance by Columbia's Chet Forte, Princeton's basketball team turned back the Lions, 88 to 82, in an Ivy League contest last night.

In the next three weeks the antomotive industry will enter what is normally its peak sales period of the year. By that time any major shifts in the relative share each car maker will have in the market should be well established.
LOS ANGELES March 6-- William Cameron Menzies, winner of the first Academy Award for motion picture art direction died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills. His age was 60.
"Good as Gold," a new comedy by John Patrick based on the book of the same title by Alfred Toombs, will have its Broadway premiere at the Belasco Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize postponement of an $81,600,000 interest payment due from Britain last December on the $3,750,000,000 she borrowed in 1945.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 6 (U.P.)--The New York Yankees, in pursuit of a left fielder, are negotiating with the Detroit Tigers for Bill Tuttle.
The British Britannia 310 airplane, designed for trans-Atlantic operations, is scheduled to make its first appearance here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6--Justice Philip Halpern outlined here today United Nations plans to combat discrimination in education.
WASHINGTON, March 6--The House of Representatives arranged today to accept quickly tomorrow the Senate's version of the Administration's Middle East resolution.

MAURICE CHEVALIER made a tour of his beloved Paris in a documentary film shown last night over Channel 4. In some isolated scenes the program managed to convey the magic and charm of the city on the Seine but for the most part it was a very sentimental and ooh-la-la journey.

The twenty-first annual Eastern Golden Gloves amateur boxing championship came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night with a program of contests in all standard divisions from flyweight to heavyweight.
Continuing negotiations and the announcement of a union general membership meeting for tomorrow were the main developments yesterday in the thirtyfour-day-old tugboat strike.

The world will apparently enter the era of large-scale use of atomic allergy at a far faster pace than has ever before seemed possible. This is the clear implication of the British Government's decision to build by 1965 atomic electric power generating capacity of up to 6,000,000 kilowatts.

Futures prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes registered the third largest volume of the year, and the world sugar contract was moderately active. Other commodities were unusually quiet.
Since blouses have smashed all fashion records for spring, it is not a minute too early for women who are connoisseurs of handsome shirts to take stock.

THE fierce tribes of striped bass fishermen, ever restlessly roving the desolate beaches and inlets of this region, are in a state of confusion approaching panic. Morale is at its lowest ebb and brother snarls at brother.

LEAFING through "Samovar," an obscure little Russian cookbook by Elizavetta Dmitrovna, we were struck by the fact that most of the fish recipes called for sour pickles. They were used either in the sauce or garnish.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will sponsor ten ninety-minute television programs during the 1957-58 season over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Some will be dramas and others musical productions --all presumably in the category of special and expensive attractions.
Despite "a hue and cry" to the contrary, the Protestant viewpoint has been well represented recently in Hollywood productions, a church executive maintained yesterday.
A round of price rises in the asphalt building materials field may be under way.

The New York Legislature has now been in session for nearly two months. The accomplishments since Jan. 10 are, as usual at this period, almost invisible. All appeals to reform working methods go unanswered.

Look for a rise in sales of automatic dishwashers this year. More than 100 electric light and power companies and local newspapers are getting behind the 1957 automatic electric dishwasher program sponsored by the household sink units section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
If winter comes, spring can't be far behind, and there is no better proof of that than a seed catalogue.
ALBANY, March 6--Two bills clearing the way for bingo games were introduced today through the Senate and Assembly Rules Committees.
Does anybody know what to do with $1,731,859.81? Members of the New York Stock Exchange have that sum in a fund started in 1952 to retire Exchange seats at not more than $45,000 each.

"PNIN,"* by Vladimir Nabokov, is a comedy of academic manners in a romantically disenchanted world. The central character is our old friend, the absentminded professor, who has appeared in so many other novels, so many plays and waggish, tweedy anecdotes.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- How was the deadlock in the Middle East broken?
Prices received by milk farmers have dropped 11 per cent since 1951, while their costs have climbed 9 per cent, a Federal hearing was told here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 6--A joint legislative committee reported today that the number and circulation of publications exploiting sex were on the increase in New York.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 6 --Leftist groups that have waged a high-pressure campaign in support of President Sukarno's plans for a "guided democracy" appeared to have backed down today.

THE story of Mr. Ki, a timorous merchant whose clum sy search for poetry and romance in a Japanese tea house has amused generations of Japanese readers, is one of many tales illustrated in an exceptional exhibition of Japanese book illustration at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street.
Ten pieces of jewelry insured for $48,300 were reported yesterday to have been stolen from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Knaster at 20 East Sixty-third Street.
A bitter controversy involving alien performers in the legitimate theatre finally has been resolved by Actors Equity and the League of New York Theatres.
BOSTON, March 7--Bud Palmer's natural athletic ability and its competitive experience as a track basketball player today contributed to his most important victory in court tennis.
Commodity prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. With the exception of the world sugar contract and potatoes, the markets were dull and featureless.
Justice John A. Byrnes advised associates on the City Court yesterday that he was not a candidate for re-election as Chief Justice.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) --The Administration again asked Congress today to increase the price of mailing a first class letter from three to four cents.
A stepped-up drive to make "heroes rather than scapegoats" of teen-aged drivers was started here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Congress completed action today on a manifesto by the United States against any Communist aggression in the Middle East. sentatives, by a vote of 350 to 60, adopted the Senate's version of President Eisenhower's resolution.

Station WABC-TV has leased a package of fifty Columbia Pictures feature films at a reported price of $750,000, Effective April 1, the films will be, presented at 11:10 P. M., Mondays through Fridays, and at 11 P. M. on Saturdays and Sundays.

The question has been raised in a recent news story in this paper as to how big is a flag. There is no standard-size American flag. The main criterion is that the flag's width be two-thirds of the length. We think that there are certain general dimensions, however, that should be observed.
PORT SAID, Egypt, March 7 --Egypt's Suez Canal Authority said today that vessels up to 500 tons could pass through the canal in daylight hours starting tomorrow.
Major physical changes essential to the extension of the oneway avenue network to midtown were completed yesterday.
Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, expressed serious doubt yesterday as to the advisability of selling the city's bus lines to private operators.
The housing situation may be a problem for humans, but not for domesticated animals.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks increased $96,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with one of $102,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.
A new settlement was reached last night in the port's longest waterfront walkout, the thirty-five-day-old tugboat strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7--The Security Council, by unanimous vote, recommended today admission to membership in the United Nations of the new state of Ghana. The General Assembly is expected to complete the formalities of admission tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7--The American Broadcasting Company has promoted J. English Smith of its Hollywood office to the position of manager of television network programs. The expected increase of more important programming in the fall prompted the move.
DUBLIN, March 7--After three years as leader of the Opposition, former Prime Minister Eamon de Valera was swept back into power today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7-- The New York Knickerbockers ended their three-night running fight with Syracuse on a winning note tonight, whipping the Nationals, ,99-94, before 5,000 fans in the Arena. The game was the opening one of a National Basketball Association double-header.

New Jersey milk farmers contended yesterday that they would lose money and be outvoted if the northern part of their state were combined with the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area under Federal control.
Two biochemists at the Rockefeller Institute have isolated and identified a new substance-colominic acid--that may play a vital role in helping to resist bacterial viruses.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 7 (AP)--Henry (Babe) Risko, former world middleweight boxing champion, died early today in his sleep at his home. He was 46 years old. At his death Mr. Risko was a sales manager with the U. S. Hoffman Machinery Corporation of New York.
THINGS look promising when the curtain goes up on "Good As Gold" at the Belasco, where the comedy opened last evening.

Italy may get an integrated steel mill costing anywhere from $120,000,000 to three times as much, according to Peter Grimm, New York realtor. He recently returned from Italy where he headed a United States economic mission.
PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., March 7 (AP)--A witness in a recruit maltreatment trial said today he had been told to sign a statement against a drill instructor or go to the brig.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March--7--Once a tourist stops living out of a suitcase and has a chance to settle down with some slight degree of permanence, he becomes aware of events that have taken place during his wanderings.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 7-- Howard Swiggett, an author and historian, died of a heart ailment this morning at the Nassau Hospital. He was 64 years old. His home was in Hewlett.

Ten men aboard a Navy tanker were missing and believed dead in an explosion and fire that followed a crash with a freighter early yesterday. Thirty-five others of the crew of the Mission San Francisco and all twenty-three aboard the freighter Elna II, including two stewardesses, were rescued.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 7-- The special grand jury investigating shakedown charges against certain Nassau County Health Department inspectors named thirteen individuals in twelve indictments today.

Next Tuesday night, a city policeman who is married to an opera singer will import the New York Philharmonic-Symphony to Staten Island. The policeman is Robert Regan, husband of the soprano Eileen Farreli and president of Community Concerts of Staten Island.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the president of the Retail Clerks International Association teamed up yesterday in a dramatic crackdown on racket elements in the 300,000member union.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 7--Army officers in the North Sumatra province of Achin are working to establish a military council independent of the central government, the newspaper Pedoman reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The Director of Defense Mobilization rejected today the request of the cordage industry for protection from imports as an industry essential to defense.

Unless freight business increases on the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway by 10 per cent at once, the railway will have to close down by April 8, Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan said yesterday.

Bond issues rotating $9,467,500 to finance the construction of public school buildings have just been sold by four New York State school districts at interest rates ranging from 3.4 per cent to 4 per cent.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company last year realized a 29 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 17 per cent over 1955, said Gilbert W. Chapman, president. Sales and earnings, he noted, were also the highest in the company's eighty-eight-year history.
Harry Canelstein, realty investor, has purchased from the Moskin Realty Corporation the one-story taxpayer building at 281-83 East 161st Street, east off the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Government officials said today that United States Middle East policy was now entering a phase that would be dominated by the testing of Egyptian good faith.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The United States contributed $1,500,000 today toward wiping out malaria throughout the Americas.
With United Nations flags flying over Gaza the clogged transportation lines of the Middle East are beginning to open up again.

Hugh R. Brown of 1857 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn, former manager and building superintendent of the Metropolitan Opera House, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. His age was 81.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Eisenhower tonight boomed Leonard W. Hall for Governor of New York. He praised the former Republican national chairman highly at a Capitol Hill reception.

LONDON, March 7--A British audience gave a warm welcome to "A Hatful of Rain," which opened at the Princes Theatre tonight. Newspaper critics ware virtually unanimous in holding that the tempo of the direction was too slow.

MILTON HALL, "a short stocky man, worried to death by the prospect of fat," knew that he could rely on his luck. No matter how bleak the future looked, no matter how disgraceful his last outburst of folly, something always turned up.
LONDON, March 7--Industrial stocks were depressed today on news of a threatened strike in shipyards.

ATLANTA, March 7 (AP)--The Third Army headquarters announced today that a ten-man court-martial board would try Col. John C. Nickerson Jr. on charges of laxity "concerning security and the safeguarding of military information."

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP)--Confidential magazine and its distributing company were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of mailing obscene or crime-inciting matter and giving information on abortion.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 7 (AP)--A plastic cap worn by Bill Virdon, the second leading hitter in the National League last season, saved the outfielder from a possible serious head injury today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7--This is the time of year a ballplayer, toiling to put himself in tip-top physical condition, gives more than passing thought to his weight and how to bring it down a bit. Some have to bring it down a lot.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 7-- Israeli troops blew up Egyptian military works at the mouth of the Gulf of Aqaba today in preparation for withdrawal tomorrow.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. realized a net income last year of $383,401,308 on net sales of $1,888,445,757. They were exceeded only by the record highs established in 1955, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, informed 168,675 stockholders in the annual report to be released today.
EAMON DE VALERA remains the dominent politi cal figure in Ireland, despite poor vision and his age--74.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 7--State Senator Thomas F. Campbell, who had been a member of the Senate since 1944, died at his home today. He was 59 years old.
New York University kept alive its hopes of winning the Mythical Subway Circuit basketball title by defeating St. John's last night.

WHITE PLAINS, March 7-- Connecticut advised New York today that it would "never lower its minimum age [of 21] for drinking." It urged, instead, that New York raise from 18 to 21 the minimum age for those who might legally buy liquor.

IT is easy to look down on "La Gioconda." Its drama turgy is old-fashioned, and its music lacks the psychological depth that makes for greatness. But it overflows with good tunes, which are designed affectionately and knowingly for the voice.

President Eisenhower livened the maneuvering for the Republican nomination for Governor next year when he said he would be a "booster" of Leonard W. Hall should Mr. Hall run. The party's two top legislative leaders in Albany are said to be interested in running.
An instrument that astronomers will use to hunt for the center of the Milky Way was described yesterday at the winter meeting of the Optical Society of America.

LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., March 7--The former Tiffany mansion, one of the palatial landmarks on the Long Island North Shore, was destroyed by a fire that started last night and burned until this afternoon.
The 1956 Caldecott Medal for "the most distinguished American picture book for children" has been awarded to Marc Simont for his illustrations in Janice May Udry's "A Tree Is' Nice."
CHICAGO, March 7--Wheat futures opened with a modest show of strength today on the Board of Trade. The gains were followed by a sell-off that more than wiped out most of the advances.
W. R. Grace Co. opened its polymer chemicals division's laboratories and main offices yesterday in Clifton, N. J.

CREATIVE dramatics can be a lot of fun for children--and it can sometimes help mother get the housework done faster too. In fact play-acting can serve a vast variety of purposes, at home, in school and nowadays even at church.

WASHINGTON, March 7--A new fight has broken out in Congress on the civil rights program. It is over the elimination by a House Judiciary subcommittee of the word "religion" from the measure it has approved.

CHICAGO, March 7 (UP)-- Eddie Litzenberger netted his thirtieth goal of the season tonight, but it took a desperation shot by Johnny Wilson with two minutes to play to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-2 tie with the National Hockey League's fourth-place New York Rangers.

The Federal Reserve System purchased $47,500,000 of Government bills in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the first week this year that the system had reported open market purchases.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --The Controller of the Currency opposed today a bill to extend the anti-trust laws to more types of bank mergers. His testimony before a House group touched off a debate on where President Eisenhower's Administration stood.

Secretary of State Dulles is again on a foreign mission. He will begin meetings on Monday with other chief ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization states. This is an annual getting together at the higher levels to discuss the problems of security in the threatened areas.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Eisenhower finds himself in an unusual position today. Instead of being criticized for leaving Washington too much, he is being urged by his associates and even by his critics to go away into the sunshine for his health.
An armored truck delivered to City Hall yesterday the original Flushing Remonstrance. This was believed to be the first declaration of religious tolerance by a group of American settlers.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- House Democrats won today the first major farm fight of the new session of Congress.

Hyman Marcus, president of United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation, admitted yesterday the possibility that outside financial interests were attempting to buy control of the company. But he said: "To date we have not been approached by anyone demanding representation."

WHEN the sun spears through dark palms on Tonga in the Friendly Islands in the South Pacific at dawn today, Queen Salote, who has described herself as "a humble Christian," will lead her people as she has for years in the first link in a global chain of prayer for a better world.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) --Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
ALBANY, March 7--Republicans were reported today to be leaning toward the decontrol of all vacancies in rent-controlled housing outside New York City.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 7 --Alcoholism, sexual promiscuity and suicide were said today to be causing serious problems among Americans working abroad for private business concerns and public agencies.

Two union officials and a former union president were indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury. They were charged with conspiracy and extortion in connection with the alleged shakedown of a lumber company.
Jet planes are still too noisy for New York's major airports, the Port of New York Authority has ruled.
Lysol, a top-selling disinfectant since its introduction in 1891, has undergone its first complete change of costume. Behind the change is a new concept in the marketing of packaged goods.

STOCKHOLM, March 7 (AP)-- Japan's stars romped through three matches today in the team phase of the world table tennis championships. And the unheralded United States men's team won twice in the Swayththling Cup competition.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7-- Spring soreness has struck the Giants. A number of prominent players, headed by Johnny Antonelli and Willie Mays, are affected. No one actually is crippled, but Antonelli, the lefthanded ace of the mound staff, will not work in the Giants' first exhibition game Saturday against the Cleveland Indians at Tucson.
LONDON, March 7--The Conservative party held two seats in the House of Commons today. But the victories were empty ones.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Following is the text of a recommended program for United States aid to underdeveloped countries made by the International Development Advisory Board:

Sales of the Chrysler Corporation in the first quarter of this year may exceed $1,000,000,000 for the best quarter in the company's history. That was disclosed yesterday by F. W. Misch, finance vice president, in a talk before the New York Society of Security Analysts.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The Supreme Court took under advisement today a case involving the extent to which the judiciary might restrict the investigative activities of Congress.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 --Michael Wilson, a controversial Hollywood figure since he declined in 1951 to answer questions of a Congressional committee investigating communism, tonight was honored by the Writers Guild of America, West, for a screen play he wrote in 1946.

John F. Gehan, newly elected president of the American Export Lines, has been named "Waterfront Man of the Year, 1956." He was cited by the Barnacles, an organization of those engaged in maritime activity and allied transportation.
The New York Central ands the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads should be more disappointed than surprised if they do not get anyone to bid today for a long-term lease on 277 Park Avenue.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 2--The winter sun slants down on Wenceslas Square, bestowing a little light but very little warmth on the wind-blown shoppers in the center of Prague.

The Seattle and Bradley basketball teams were ranked No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, yesterday in the draw for the twentieth annual National Invitation Tournament opening March 16 at Madison quare Garden. No other quintets were seeded.
The American Trust Company, 70 Wall Street, announced yesterday plans to make a-subscription offering of 50,000 additional shares of capital stock to present stockholders at $10 a share.

CHICAGO, March 7--Negroes living in racially integrated housing indicate a more positive attitude toward life and seem generally better adjusted than those in unintegrated housing, a psychological study has shown.
PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, March 7 (Reuters)--A dock strike that began here Monday appeared to be over today as hundreds of Negro workers returned.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7--Sir Laurence Olivier and his wife, Vivien Leigh, have withdrawn from the film version of "Separate Tables."

WASHINGTON, March 7-- United States and Canadian officials are still plagued by the "complicating factors" standing in the way of setting tolls for shippers using the St. Lawrence Seaway now under construction.
A student invitation to John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, to speak at Queens College next week was attacked yesterday by administrative officials at the school.

Recreation skiers who hope to head for the northlands this week face a problem. Covers at most of the major areas remain thin and only a fair-sized snowfall can make the terrain suitable for high quality sport.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) --The United States and Mexico reached an understanding today on a new civil aviation agreement after an eleven-year dispute.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7 --A sore arm on another firstline Dodger pitcher developed today during the third intrasquad game of the training stay here.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved somewhat irregularly yesterday. Prices at the close were 8 points lower to 5 points higher (40 cents a bale up to 25 off) than on wednesday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7-- A tall 46-year-old lawyer, who reads history books for relaxation when he is not writing them, is capturing the imagination of Chileans, who are beginning to think about the September, 1958, Presidential elections.

LAKEWOOD, Calif., March 7 (UP)--The world's leading woman diver, Mrs. Patricia K. McCormick, is studying offers preparatory to turning professional, her husband and coach, Glenn McCormick, disclosed today. The date of such a move has not been set.
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 --The most miserable man in India these days is a young editor who decided to write some nasty things about Queen Elizabeth II of Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 7--President Eisenhower stood firm today against trimming the Federal budget by making any substantial cuts in foreign aid or by abandoning other vital projects. He said, however, that the Administration was still trying to slow Government spending to relieve inflationary pressure.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 (AP)--Yale clinched the Ivy League basketball championship tonight as Harvard ended second-place Dartmouth's last hope with a 69-60 victory. A sophomore, George Harrington, paced the Crimson with 28 points.
The Teamsters Joint Council served notice yesterday that it intended to take over the trucking local of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
KIRKUK, Iraq, March 7-- Champagne flowed like oil here last night after Iraq Petroleum Company officials learned of Syria's agreement to permit restoration of the pipeline to the Mediterranean.
DETROIT, March 7--A huge electronic brain in operation here is keeping track of every nut, bolt and spark plug used in any part of the world by the Army's Ordnance Tank-Automotive Command.
Workmen are adding the finishing touches for the public debut in two weeks of Elmhurst General Hospital, the first municipal general hospital built in Queens in twenty-two years.
BEEF is the best buy at meat counters, as it has been for several weeks past. Shoppers in the market for beef steaks will be pleased to find them several pennies a pound cheaper than a week ago.

Motors, steels chemicals, aircrafts, metals and oils all sagged in a lackadaisical stock market yesterday. But a number of specialties moved higher and the over-all loss was small.

It may well be that the results of the general elections in Eire will make little difference to the domestic affairs of the Irish Republic. The opposing sides had much the same economic program, and economics is what counts in Eire today.
In the wake of Wednesday's fourteen-hour public hearing on the subject, fluoridation of the city's water supply appeared yesterday to be unlikely at least for the rest of this year.

MONROVIA, Liberia, March 7--Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived in steaming Liberia today in a top hat, cutaway and striped trousers in accordance with the rigid protocol of Africa's oldest Negro republic.
CHICAGO, March 7--Integration of power facilities to cut costs and assure steady output was advocated here today by Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George John Lynde Griswold, formerly of Morristown, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Griswold, to William Boatner Reily 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reily Jr.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7--Dag Hammarskjold plans to inform the General Assembly tomorrow that Israel has now withdrawn behind the Israeli-Egyptian demarcation line.
LONDON, March 7--Britain's Navy and Air Force are expected to take greater responsibility for protecting British, interests at home and abroad after cuts in defense spending have been made.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7--A pair of lovers, Olympic champions Harold Connolly of Boston and Olga Fikotova of Prague, prepared to part tonight to await the Czechoslovak Government's decision on their request to marry.
A Brooklyn patrolman on school-crossing duty left his post long enough yesterday to capture a car theft suspect after a twenty-block chase.

NEW YORK STATE has started its spring trout stocking program and the score is written in reverberating numbers, as usual. These same numbers illustrate foggily, as only numbers can, just what kind of business this fishing has come to be.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --The United States accused Hungary today of arresting Hungarian citizens after they had visited the United States Legation in Budapest. It requested that this "interference" with United States diplomatic rights be stopped.

HONG KONG, March 7--The Rev. Paul J. Mackensen Jr. of Baltimore, last missionary of the United Lutheran Church in America remaining in Communist China, has been released from a Shanghai prison, the Peiping radio announced.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --Murray Snyder, assistant press secretary to President Eisenhower, and former Representative Dewey Short won unanimous approval today from the Senate Armed Services Committee for appointments to $20,000-a-year Pentagon posts.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Eisenhower's persistent cold has spread and temporarily affected his hearing. His bothersome cough continues.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Mayor Terry D. Schrunk of Portland, Ore., was accused today of having accepted $500 from a gambler as a bribe to call off a raid.
The Federal Government Was criticized yesterday by H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, for reverting to "the taxing and spending philosophy and policies of the past."
LONDON, March 7--Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said tonight that Israel and the Arab states must compromise on differences about their frontiers before there could be peace in the Middle East.
Something is going to have to give in the 123-pound class at the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association's fiftythird annual championships at Penn State next week-end.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The International Development Advisory Board recommended today an immediate major new program of economic aid for underdeveloped countries, whether they are neutral in the "cold war" or not.

The Bargain Box, a thrift shop, will have a new home at 1579 Third Avenue with the aid of the proceeds of a theatre party on April 11. It will take place at the Winter Garden Theatre, where Beatrice Lillie is starring in the "Ziegfeld Follies," with Billy de Wolfe and Harold Lang as her co-stars.

William J. Ahearn of 296 East Broadway, who retired two months ago as Commissioner of Records of the Surrogate's Court, New York County, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. His age was 63.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and two economists said today that the United States could probably cut back military spending by at least 50 per cent without long-range damage to the economy.

Last month an economic tool developed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics saw use for the first time.
NEW DELHI, India, March 8 --Indian voters are returning Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party to power quickly in most states of the union.

The disabled luxury liner Ile de France left Fort de France, Martinique, yesterday for Newport News, Va., in tow of two ocean-going tugboats.
Futures prices on New York exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday. Volume continued light in all markets except potatoes and world sugar.
CHICAGO, March 8--Trading volume in grains was comparatively light today on the Board of Trade. Rallies were small generally, with little follow-through.
STRATFORD, Conn., March 8--Dr. Ira Cohen, a New York brain surgeon who retired several years ago, was found dead on the side porch of his home here today. He was 69 years old.
DIVERSITY OF WORLDS,"* by Raymond Aron and August Heckscher, is a stimulating and provocative dia logue between France and America.
ALBANY, March 8--The Court of Appeals, in a 4 to 3 decision, today set aside a $50,000 libel verdict that W. Kingsland Macy had obtained against the New York World-Telegram Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) --The Department of Justice announced today that it had negotiated a compromise settlement of its civil claims against Pillsbury Mills, Inc., and the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, both of Minneapolis, Minn.
The teacher shortage in the city's public high schools has reached the point where substitutes now outnumber regular teachers in some subjects.

Walter Byars reduced Garnet (Sugar) Hart to a mere grain at Madison Square Garden last night. The Boston welterweight pounded his way to a unanimous decision over the heavily favored Hart in the main bout of ten rounds.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) --President Eisenhower today reaffirmed the validity of operating certificates held by three domestic airlines for routes between the United States and Mexico.
The Second Avenue subway, envisioned long ago and promised in 1951, probably never will be built.
Cotton futures market moved 9 points (45 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday. Volume was small.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8--The National Broadcasting Company is considering giving a new look to its Tuesday evening television schedule.
Sergei Yakovlevich Zhuk, chief engineer of the vast Soviet slave labor empire, is dead at the age of 65.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 8 --The Dodgers punctuated the end of sixteen days' training here today by being punctured. The puncturing came when twenty-eight of the forty-three athletes received Salk polio shots.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8--Yugoslav troops would be withdrawn from the United Nations Emergency Force if Egypt ordered the international militia off her soil.

WASHINGTON, March 8--A young Turkish-born scientist received a patent this week for an electric gun.

Lehigh's swimmers assumed the lead in the opening half of the Eastern Collegiate Swim ming Association championships last night.
Columbia College's inter-fraternity council has cleared the way for its member groups to fight discriminatory clauses in the constitutions of national chapters.

Eleven inmates of the City Penitentiary boarded a ferryboat at Rikers Island yesterday and landed on a Bronx pier as free men.
Unrest among dairy farmers is serious and growing, an upstate economist testified yesterday at a public hearing on the extension of Federal milk price controls into northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) --Spokesmen for banking and savings institutions asked Congress today to approve a flexible interest rate on Governmentbacked home loans.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 8-- Lieut. Gen. Chiang Ching-kuo acknowledged here today that short-wave broadcasts concerning peace talks had been addressed to him from Peiping recently.

John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, will be permitted to speak next Wednesday during the Academic Week Program of Queens College.
ALBANY; March 8--In a 4-to-3 decision, the Court of Appeals held today that the $25,000,000 Grumman aircraft plant near Riverhead, L. I., was exempt from local real estate taxes.
A 492-foot freighter, anchored in Upper New York Bay, was struck in the side early last evening by a coastwise tanker, 155 feet long.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 8 (UP)--Joe Adcock of the Milwaukee Braves, the big first baseman whose bat often terrorizes Brooklyn pitchers, will be sidelined by a sore back muscle when the Braves open their exhibition season against the Dodgers at Miami tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) --Bankers showed today that they, like Government departments, disagree as to whether the Attorney General or the agencies directly concerned with banking should have the major responsibility for regulating bank mergers.
Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna said yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate to authorize him to buy forty-four pumping engines for the Fire Department without public bidding.

After thirty years at 109 Debevoise Street in the William burg area of Brooklyn, the Bushwick Glass Company has been forced to seek new quarters to make way for Bushwick Houses, an apartment development.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 8-- Thirteen present and former inspectors in the Nassau County Health Department pleaded innocent today to indictments charging shakedowns of building and plumbing contractors.

Having completed one of the most difficult and important tasks it has ever undertaken, the General Assembly of the United Nations has recessed its present session.

WASHINGTON; March 8-- Members of the House Agriculural Committee were summoned today to an unusual Saturday meeting. They will strive to break a partisan stalemate on in emergency bill to aid Midwest corn farmers.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 8 (UP)--Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., shot a 4-under-par 68 today ao tie Australia's Peter Thomson, three-time winner of the British open, for the secondround lead in the $15,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.
THE proposal to license saltwater anglers has brought a strong letter of protest from William J. McKernan of 1760 Seward Avenue, Clason Point, the Bronx.

Two six-story apartment houses at 7 and 9 Prince Street have been sold by Irving Rothstein and Howard K. Rothenberg to investing clients of Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., brokers. The buildings contain thirty-seven apartments and five stores. They occupy a plot 61 by 91 feet.

CHICAGO, March 8--The General Electric Company's volume of business in January and February topped that in the corresponding period a year ago, and its unfilled orders for industrial and defense items were at a record high.

TOKYO, March 8--Premier Nobusuke Kishi proposed today that Japan's Emperor be restored to his old position as "Head of State," but without change in his present complete divorcement from any but the most nominal governing functions.

BUENOS AIRES, March 8-- One of the gravest inner Cabinet crises of Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu's Provisional Government was solved temporarily tonight when the Under Secretary of the Navy, Rear Admiral Arturo H. Rial, was sentenced to thirty days' arrest.

The Human Relations Area Files of New Haven, Conn., is preparing a group of volumes to be known as the Country Survey Series that will represent the working papers of more than 400 specialists and scholars on regions of the world.

PARIS, March 8--The premiers and foreign ministers of France and Britain, will meet here tomorrow and Sunday. Their series of talks are expected to deal with the Middle East, but more especially with the deadlock over Britain's association with the planned European common market.
UTICA, N.Y., March 8 (AP)-- A Federal grand jury indicted today a former Syracuse hotel owner on charges that he had failed to report more than $630,000 income for two corporations for 1950.

LONDON, March 8--Wyndham Lewis, author, artist and critic, died here last night at the age of 72.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 8-- The president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development advised the United States today to be cautious in the way it encouraged change in the under-developed areas of the world.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8-- The first phase of the Giants' spring training ended today.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 8 (AP) --Michigan State, mustering superb team balance in the face of record-breaking performances by Michigan's Dick Hanley and Cy Hopkins, took the lead in the Big Ten Conference swimming meet tonight.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 8 --The Indonesian Government kept a wary eye on Borneo today to see whether that big island would join the growing revolt against the country's central administration.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 8 --Arthur N. Pierson of 237 Kimball Avenue, a former State Senator, Assemblyman and Union County treasurer, died tonight at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, after an illness of several weeks. His age was 89.
CINCINNATI, March 8--Prof. Bradley Jones, who established the cooperative program in aeronautical engineering at the University of Cincinnati, died here today at the age of 67.

LONDON, March 8--Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, challenged the Conservative Government today to drop its "reactionary social policies" or resign from office.

The spotlight will be on Ron Delany and Tom Courtney tonight as the track-and-field set staves its final 1957 rendezvous at Madison Square Garden in the thirty-eighth annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- President Eisenhower hopes to fly to southern Florida the middle of next week for about a week of sun rest and exercise before the Bermuda conference.
BOSTON, March 8--Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L.I., will seek his ninth amateur court tennis championship of the United States tomorrow.

It was the Tar Heels' twentysixth consecutive victory.
PARIS, March 8--Robert Lacoste, French Minister Residing in Algeria, was reported today to have told the Cabinet that the rebellion-torn North African area would be pacified in three months.

Leopold Avakian, a Persianborn violinist of Russian-Armenian descent, made his debut last night in Carnegie Hall. He had studied at the Juilliard School and in recent years has given recitals in American cities. Thus he has had some experience, and it stood him well last night.
A physically handicapped student seeking admittance to college should be tested on his functional abilities, Dr. Howard A. Rusk said last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8--The new state of Ghana was admitted to the United Nations today by unanimous vote of the General Assembly.

Besides Charles Van Doren, a television quiz show star; Chet Forte, an all-America basketball player, and Gorki, the baby alligator recently adopted by three coeds, another Columbia University personality is achieving a measure of fame.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- Wholesale prices on the primary market level declined 0.1 per cent to 116.8 per cent of their 1847-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today a twenty-day postponement of the date on which the Government will open bids on its major stock holdings in the General Aniline Film Corporation, valued at more than $100,000,000.
SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt, March 8--The blue and white flag of Israel was lowered at Sharm el Sheikh this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 8--The Navy indicated today that its atomic submarine, the Nautilus, got about 60,000 miles to a little more than eight pounds of uranium before it docked at Groton, Connecticut, for refueling. That was calculated, in fuel-oil equivalents as two-tenths of a mile to a gallon.

HARTFORD, March 9--The pay of members of the Connecticut Legislature is only $300 a year, but a concerted drive is underway to increase the rate.
