The Navy is testing a new device that substitutes buttons and dials for a pilot's verse report: "Over Cleveland at 20,000 feet." The development is designed to crack a major bottleneck in the control of air traffic.
PARIS, March 13--The discussion by the North Atlantic Council of Britain's plan to reduce her troops in West Germany ended without agreement today.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Eisenhower gave little encouragement today to proposals for a major new program of economic aid to under-developed countries.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 13-- Britain's military and economic links with Jordan were finally severed here tonight amid waves of oratory, tumultuous street demonstrations and the crackle of jubilant gunfire.
ALBANY, March 13--Differerences on rent control between the Harriman administration and the Republican majorities in the Legislature were reported to have been narrowed substantially today.

For most of last night's game the New York Rangers were "in" as regards the National Hockey League's post-season play offs. They had a one-goal lead over the Boston Bruins until well in the third period at Madison Square Garden.

AN ebullient exhibition of paintings by younger art ists of the so-called New York school commemorates the 10th year for the Jewish Museum in its present quarters at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

The latest hearings on the admission of Alaska to the Union got off to a good start this week with an unequivocal declaration that "the Administration's position is that all of the Territory of Alaska should become the State of Alaska."

Commodity futures moved irregularly here yesterday in dull and featureless trading. Sugar, copper, hides and cottonseed oil declined; coffee, potatoes and cocoa rose, and price movements for rubber and wool were mixed.
Additional waterfront labor troubles may be in prospect for this port as it struggles back from a thirty-six-day tugboat strike.
Robert Morse Jr., president of Fairbanks, Morse Co., said yesterday that Leopold D. Silberstein, chairman and preside of Penn-Texas Corporation, would never gain
The Hamburg South American Line announced yesterday the establishment of a new service from East Canadian and United States Atlantic Coast ports to Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina.
PARIS, March 13--A major test of the Government's strength will begin tomorrow with the start of a debate in the National Assembly on general policy.
HANOVER, N.H., March 13 --Sweeping changes in the academic program of Dartmouth College have been recommended by the faculty.

CHICAGO, March 13--A weak tone dominated the grain markets in early trading today on the Board of Trade, but the market steadied when commission buying appeared in all pits. This started some short covering, causing a partial recovery.
Ski Sketch: Fred H. Harris, founder of the Dartmouth Outing Club, put on his first pair of skis in 1905.

Public school financing was the center of interest in the municipal bond market yesterday. Issues of bonds totaling $10,016,000 were sold in six states and issues totaling $3,737,000 were posted for sale this month and next by districts in three states.
WASHINGTON, March 13--A Senate committee delved today into the "why" of missing union records and an unexplained $5,000 paid by the union to the lawyer of an indicted district attorney.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Public Health Service reported today that the supply of Salk polio vaccine had "tightened considerably," but that it has no plans for rationing.

A Lincoln Square clergyman whose church has been excluded from plans for the $228,000,000 redevelopment of the area yesterday charged discrimination by the city's Committee on Slum Clearance. The committee, of which Robert Moses is chairman, denied there was any discrimination.
WARSAW, March 13--The Soviet Union has consigned all its purchases of Polish coal to East Germany to relieve a fuel crisis there.
LONDON, March 13--John Middleton Murry, author, editor and critic, died today at the age of 67.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The United States passed back to the United Nations today responsibility for keeping the peace between Egypt and Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The House killed emergency aid to Midwest corn farmers today. It acted decisively despite warnings from the Administration that corn and livestock prices might collapse.
ALBANY, March 13--The State Senate divided along party lines today to pass a bill giving the Attorney General $100,000 to prosecute civil rights violations. The vote was 37 to 20.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- A Government report indicated today that the boom in expansion of plant and equipment was leveling off at the record pace it reached at the beginning of the year.
JERUSALEM, March 13--Premier David Ben-Gurion declared today that Israel still reserved the right to take action if the Egyptians returned to the Gaza Strip.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested James R. Hoffa, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on bribery charges tonight.
A distillery union put a supervisor in charge of its principal New York local yesterday in a move to avert its ouster from the united labor movement.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 13--Casey Stengel, who has been concentrating mostly on the Yankee pitching so far, is beginning to show concern about the batting. It hasn't been so hot of late.
Retail grocers are going back to school--this time to learn the techniques that make advertising productive.

"The Big Surprise," a television quiz show with a comparatively modest jackpot of $100,000, has been renewed by one of its sponsors for the remainder of the season. For several weeks it had appeared that the program would be terminated early this spring.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Dr. Miron Burgin, chief of the Division of Research for American Republics, Department of State, died here today in George Washington University Hospital. He was 56 years old.
Walter F. Tellier, 55-year-old Jersey City stock broker, was convicted last night of mail fraud and violations of the Securities Act.
QUALITY is the least expensive thing one can buy, according to Henri Bendel, president of Belgium Shoes, Inc., 60 East Fifty-sixth Street.
The picture of William R. Rose, former bank president, as the benign benefactor of Ellenville, N.Y., business men was sharply challenged in two Federal indictments returned here yesterday.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 13--Billy Pierce, the slender 20game winner of the Chicago White Sox, learned today why so few National League southpaws start against the Brooklyn Dodgers. In two innings, Pierce was belabored for seven hits and six runs and the Dodgers were riding toward a 9-to-4 victory.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13--Paul Gregory, the producer, will return to television next fall with a trio of ninety-minute spectaculars.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation last year lifted its sales and earnings to new records, according to the annual report of John M. Olin, chairman, and Thomas S. Nichols, president, released today.
FOR forty of his fifty-one years Howard E. Schrader has assembled electron tubes. Now he owns, mounted in the order in which they came into being, more than 8,000 kinds.
MESA, Ariz,, March 11--How good a catcher might Charlie Silvera have been if he had not "wasted" nine years with the Yankees? How good a catcher is he now that he is here with the Chicago Cubs?
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14--The Yankees, loaded with so much talent that they should win the American League pennant in a breeze, have added perseverence to their many virtues.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., March 14 --An airport lighting system designed to make night landings about as foolproof as possible was demonstrated tonight at the March Air Force Base near here.
PARIS, March 14--The Ministry of Defense announced today it had decided to prosecute those responsible for "a campaign of systematic disparagement" of the army's behavior in Algeria.
NORFOLK, Va., March 14-- President Eisenhower sailed for Bermuda tonight aboard the cruiser Canberra.

Quebec Natural Gas Corporation has announced plans to register today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $25,000,000 of twenty-three-year first mortgage bonds, $15,000,000 of twenty-eight-year subordinated debentures and 750,000 common shares.

Varsity sports enthusiasts of diversified taste will find it difficult to decide where to go to see what this week-end. The calendar is more crowded than it has been, or will be, through the whole college year.
KUWAIT, March 14--In the last few days the Egyptians have stepped up their anti-Western radio propaganda directed to Persian Gulf countries.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 14 --This was a day the Dodgers would rather forget. A 12-to-9 blasting by the Miliwaukee Braves was the least of their woes, and certainly not the most painful.

JERSEY CITY, March 14--The principal political group seeking to end John V. Kenny's control of City Hall gained strong support today when State Senator James F. Murray Jr. announced that he would become the fourth member of a five-man "victory ticket."

The American Tramp Shipowners Association has asked the Maritime Administration to delay any further breakouts of Government-owned vessels from reserve fleets. The association contends that overtonnage is contributing to the present plight of privately owned tramp vessels.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 14-- Leaders of the National Organization of Cypriote Fighters, known as E.O.K.A., offered today to suspend operations as soon as Archbishop Makarios was released from British exile in the Seychelles Islands.
Two office buildings occupying a triangular block in the downtown insurance district here have been purchased by realty investors. They plan to modernize the structures.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- Louisiana dropped another surprise today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points off to 17 points up yesterday in moderate business.
More than $4,000,000 in equipment trust certificates of two railroads will be offered to investors today. The offerings will be:
BERKELEY, Calif., March 14 (AP)--Carol Heiss, the 17-year-old world champion, from Ozone Park, Queens, today captured a commanding lead in her quest for the United States figure skating title.

The public uproar over the size of the $72-billion budget--largest peacetime spending program in the nation's history--has led to a remarkable example of buck-passing between President Eisenhower and the United States Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 14--A Federal grand jury began looking today into the bribery charge against James R. Hoffa. This came as another swift stroke by the Government to bring to trial one of the country's most powerful labor leaders.
Shipments of refined copper to fabricators in this country dropped sharply last month. Producers' stocks of the metal rose to the highest level in more than seven years.
A Federal Court trial of a $19,000,000 suit on behalf of thirty-eight Puerto Rican veterans of the Korean war who were killed or injured in a plane crash began here yesterday.
MONTREAL, March 14 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens celebrated Floyd Curry Night by eliminating Toronto from the Stanley Cup play-offs with an 8-4 victory over the Maple Leafs tonight.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 14 (AP)--Governor Harriman asserted today that a special housing project here for the elderly "exposed" Republican statements against his proposed bond issue ...

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation had a record net income in 1956 of $50,000,000, a gain of 13.4 per cent over, the $44,000,000 earned the year before. A.B. Layton, presi dent, described the year as "the most successful in the company's 86-year-history."
Here is the latest word concerning the contemplated return of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce to the ranks of Broadway playwrights:

IT would be blarney to say that Robert Briscoe wears the map of Ireland on his face. But the first Jewish Lord Nlayor of Dublin has Ireland's essence in his bones and her musical accent on his tongue.

A Harlem warehouse being torn down burst into flame yesterday after sparks from an acetylene torch ignited rubbish. The fire spread swiftly to twelve tenement buildings, eight of them partly occupied.
The "Old Woman's" funeral, deferred for almost an indecent length of time, finally has been set for March 29 at midnight.
GULFPORT, Miss., March 14 (AP)--Dick Metz of Pike Road, Ala., shattered the course record with a 62 today to take the first-round lead in the $5,000 Gulf Coast Invitation golf tournament.

DETROIT, March 14 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings gained a three-goal lead but had to stave off a desperation rally by the Chicago Black Hawks tonight for a 3-2 victory. The triumph moved the Wings a step closer to their eighth National Hockey League championship in nine years.

Because of the mild temperatures that have prevailed in the East, the season may be over for most skiers. But for the seventy-three men and twenty-nine women competing in the American International Races at Stowe, Vt., starting today, the winter is at its height.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 14--The Milwaukee Braves have played no golf this spring. It isn't that Manager Fred... Haney has ruled out the divot-digging pastime. He has done nothing of the sort. But he has worked his heroes into such states of total exhaustion that they blanch at the idea of taking even one needless step on the links.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The United States moved today toward restoration of economic aid to Israel.

The Newspaper Guild of New York made its annual Page One Awards yesterday for achievements in journalism, public affairs, labor, science and entertainment. They will be presented at the union's Page One Ball in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel April 26.
Lee Tracy will star in a new film series titled "New York Confidential," which is scheduled to make ita debut in the fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Administration is actively considering a constitutional amendment that would authorize the Vice President to exercise temporarily the powers and duties of the President during any disabling illness of the latter.
More firepower and more cost per unit but smaller numbers are basically the order of the day for he armed forces in the foreseeable future.
ALBANY, March 14--The Senate gave final approval today to a bill creating a nonprofit corporation to make loans to college students.
VIENNA, March 14-Gyula Kallai, Hungarian Minister of Education, said tonight that "Hungarian workers have taken the Soviet soldier to their heart for all eternity," the Budapest radio reported.

Three six-story buildings containing six stores and fifty-four apartments at 188 to 192 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), near Spring Street, have been sold by Harry Klein, realty oper ator, to Jacob Mark.
The new man-made fiber Darlan has been revealed to be a product of ammonia and natural gas.

GEOFFREY COTTERELL'S "The Strange Enchantment" is so competent a novel that it is distressing to report that it is dull. Mr. Cotterell is one of the ablest of the younger English novelists. He can write as smooth, lively and pleasantly readable prose as Somerset Maugham.
ALBANY, March 14--Almost half the rent-controlled dwelling units outside New York City would be decontrolled during the next two years under a Republican program disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Senate leaders criticized a former Presidential assistant and an aide now on the White House staff today for recent statements concerning the Middle East crisis and the possible admission of Red China to the United Nations.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14--President Sukarno told Indonesia tonight that his proclamation of martial law throughout the archipelago "implies a matter of life and death for the state."
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 14The State Legislature is shaping Minnesota's industrial development program for this year.

LONDON, March 14--Stock market prices showed no decided trend today. In general, most industrials advanced slightly. Government funds had scattered falls of 1 shilling 3 pence (17 cents) on the 100 unit.
The International Longshoremen's Association has decided to drown its financial troubles in a sea of pennies.
With most of Indonesia's major islands in revolt against the central Government, President Sukarno has proclaimed a "state of war and siege" and imposed martial law.
OTTAWA, March 14--The budget for 1957, presented tonight by Walter Harris, Minister of Finance, contained few crumbs for Canadian taxpayers even though this is an election year.

THIS city is blessed in the number of skillful and sen sitive young musicians it has who love to play fine music, regardless of financial return. Those who have banded together under the name of the Knickerbocker Chamber ...
TWO artists whose work reveals quite remarkable fa cility are represented in the one-man shows of the week. One is Henry Koerner whose recent paintings at the Midtown.
Taxpayers have about a month to file their Federal income tax returns, but now is the time to prepare data that must be listed in the reports, if last minute troubles are to be avoided.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- William M. Langley, a District Attorney facing criminal prosecution in his own county of Multnomah, Ore., refused today to help a Senate committee investigating labor racketeering and political corruption in Portland.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, famed explorer of the polar regions, was buried today in Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors.
Net income of the American Sugar Refining Company last year rose to $9,885,784, or $15.05 a common share, from $8,329,852 or $11.59 a share, in 1955.
A strike that would cut off much of the city's meat supply was threatened yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14--William Faulkner's novel "The Hamlet," published by Random House in 1940, has been acquired for filming by Jerry Wald.

Commodity futures moved irregularly here yesterday in dull trading. Rubber, cocoa and potatoes declined; hides, copper and wool rose, and price movements for coffee, sugar and cottonseed oil were mixed.
LONDON, March 14--Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd today advocated administration of the Gaza Strip by the United Nations until a permanent settlement could be negotiated.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Two Senate Democrats urged today that the proposed new omnibus banking law include a ban on political contributions by banks and other financial institutions and their officers, directors and employes.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made it clear today that he would retire from his post when his second two-year term expired in August.
IRISH household linen is traditionally as durable and rugged as that other favorite Manhattan Erinism--the Irish policeman.

A CHARMING living room is the setting for Giulietta d'Alessandro's new boutique, called Giulietta di Roma, at 31 East Sixty-first Street. The silk upholstered Venetian couch, the gilt baroque chandelier, the black Venetian gondolier statue clad in gold, sedately guarding

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced today that the next sale of housing authority bonds would be held on April 10. The sale will be limited to six issues maturing serially in thirty-five to forty years. The bonds to be issued are as follows:

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 7 --In three rooms off a dusty compound in Saigon an American woman and three Vietnamese assistants are trying to make some ideas come to life. They have a host of volunteer Vietnamese aides.
Norman Thomas, long a Socialist leader, told the students of Queens College yesterday afternoon that they had been right in inviting John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, to speak on their campus.

The engagement of Miss Mary Birge Bonbright to Marshall Dexter Hendrian has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mrs. Chamberlain Bonbright of Englewood, N. J., and New York, and I. Wayland ...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14--Dag Hammarskjold may postpone his trip to Cairo unless the United States makes known this week its views on the future of the Gaza Strip and other acute Middle Eastern problems.
The Rev. James Martin Gillis of the Paulist Fathers, internationally known author, radio preacher and editor of The Catholic World, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Treasury reopened two existing issues today to raise $3,000,000,000 in new cash.
GEORG SOLTI'S New York debut as a conductor with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony at Carnegie Hall last night was an impressive affair. Of course, one concert does not provide the measure ...
"PLAYHOUSE 90" and Jack Palance scored again last night over Channel 2 with a fine production of F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel, "The Last Tycoon."
PARIS, March 14--The Government approved today a program of economic and financial austerity. At the same time it gave assurances that it would push for constitutional reform.

The award to Prof. Niels Bohr of Denmark of the first $75,000 Atoms for Peace Award, established by the Ford Motor Company Fund as a memorial to Henry and Edsel Ford, will meet with the universal approval not only of scientists--the world over but of freedom-loving peoples everywhere.

TRIPOLI, Libya, March 14-- Vice President Nixon's plane was forced to return to Khartoum today because of engine trouble. The plane, an Air Force DC-6, was forced to turn back an hour and a half after it left the Sudan's capital.
New cargo operations and new construction at the Port of New York Authority's Port Newark terminal were announced yesterday.
The Government sought yesterday to punish an American couple living in Mexico City for contempt after they failed to appear before a Federal grand jury investigating a Russian espionage ring.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Interior Department is about to award two contracts for turbines to a domestic manufacturer despite foreign bids lower by 20 per cent and 70 per cent.
WARSAW, March 14-A sudden change in Polish regulations has in effect halted the first numerically significant emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union to Israel.

Stocks enjoyed a somnolent session yesterday, with volume the smallest since Feb. 26 and the market the narrowest in a week. Prices opened a little higher, lost all their gains and then slowly edged back up.
Newspapers rallied to make the 1957 Advertising Week the most successful ever held, according to the Advertising Federation of America, sponsor of the annual event.
Subscribers to two theatre parties for the benefit of the Vocational Advisory Service, have been announced.
The Bronx, which takes pride in being "The Borough of Universities," soon may be able to boast a new college.

MANCHESTER, England, March 14 (AP)--A Viscount airliner plowed into a housing development today and burst into flame, killing all twenty persons aboard. The turbo-prop plane was coming in for a landing when it crashed.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -John Cye Cheasty, who is accredited with a key role in the arrest of James R. Hoffa, has been a Secret Service agent and an Internal Revenue agent. He was also a Navy officer for twelve years.

Sometimes there's economy in smallness. For instance, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reports that the cost of borrowing by small business has gone up less rapidly since mid-1955 than interest rates on loans to large concerns.
WASHINGTON, March 14--A study released by a Senate committee said today that "economic aid to satellite nations, as a counter-offensive against the Soviet Union, stands little prospect of success."
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had added an electronic "brain" to its operations. It expects to realize an annual saving of at least $1,000,000 from the device's "thinking."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--A business leader said today that the Senate's disclosures of rackets might lead to "corrective legislation" against labor such as followed certain "sins" of industry in the Nineteen Twenties.
This is the day that is known in Hungary as "Freedom Day." The Kadar Government cannot honestly celebrate it, for under Kadar Hungary is not free.

An official of the American Friends of the Middle East proposed yesterday that a buffer zone, manned by United Nations troops, be created on both sides of the borders separating Israel from her four Arab neighbors.
CAIRO, March 14--Egyptian civil administrators entered Gaza late today to enforce President Gamal Abdel Nasser's demand for immediate cessation of United Nations rule over the controversial strip.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Eisenhower Administration began cutting its budget today.

SHOPPERS will not find many drastic price changes on meats this week-end. Loin veal chops have dropped 6 cents to 99 a pound and smoked calis are down 4 cents to 39 a pound. But beef, which has been so plentiful
ALBANY, March 14--Governor Harriman approved today continuation this year of the personal income tax reduction granted last year.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $223,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase reflected in large part borrowings to pay Federal income taxes due today.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat of Arkansas, urged political courage today if economy pressures against a "fundamental" school construction bill became too great.
A clergyman whose church has been marked for destruction in the proposed Lincoln Square redevelopment said last night that he intended to "call the bluff" of the city's Committee on Slum Clearance.

Eight executives of four foreign-language periodicals here refused yesterday to tell a Congressional inquiry whether they were Communists. Another witness formerly linked to a--fifth such publication likewise balked.
The Sapphire Streak, a Staten Island type of ferryboat is equipped with almost everything that a ferryboat needs. It has a light, a horn, a bell and a wheel.

The city took a step yesterday toward setting up the Morningside Heights superblock that will be the site for Columbia University's new $17,000,000 East Campus. The Board of Estimate unanimously voted to close West 117th--Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Defense Department has halted construction bids on new military housing projects.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 14A major Presbyterian church body charged today that recent arrests of pastors and other leaders of the Reformed Church in Hungary represented an effort by the Hungarian Government to put "pressure" on the church.

The New York Central Railroad, which in the past year or so has turned heavily to automation to reduce its labor bills and to speed traffic, unveiled in Buffalo yesterday its newest electronic device--a $10,500,000 push-button freight classification center.
HAVANA, March 14--Havana recovered quickly today from yesterday's unsuccessful uprising by youths against the regime of President Fulgencio Batista.

The dramatic and desperate at-- tack of the Cuban youths on the Presidential Palace in Havana Wednesday served to throw a lurid light on a dark and unhappy situation. It was meant to do just that, and in this limited sense it cannot be said to have failed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14-- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy called tonight for increased production of plutonium for atomic weapons and accelerated development of atomic power for civilian use. He also called for greater effort in producing a nuclear airplane.
Newspaper men should be permitted to get the story of Communist China first hand, an editor declared yesterday.
THERE is no reason for strong, hardy outdoors men to get overly excited about this, but the fact is that prospects now for the opening of the trout season April 13 scarcely could be better.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The South made temporary gains against civil rights legislation today.

ST. LOUIS, March 14 (AP)-- The St. Louis Hawks, scoring 45 points in a rousing second quarter, deefated the Fort Wayne Pistons, 115--103, today in the first play-off game to decide first place in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association.

Once again New York State is "forgiving" its income--tax payers $40,000,000 by reducing the "normal" rate of collection. Thus the folly of last year is repeated, the only difference being that the irresponsibility is completed earlier in the legislative session.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- House members put up token resistance to high taxes and the Federal budget today. Then they cast the expected overwhelming vote to keep corporation tax rates where they are for another year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14--The American Broadcasting Company has appointed Robert Adams as executive producer of its Hollywood television program department, effective March 22. Mr. Adams is currently assistant to the producer of "Playhouse 90" on the Columbia Broadcast ing System.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) --The State Department rever sed itself today and decided it would be "undesirable" to provide a $5,000,000 Federal grant for the Pan-American games in Cleveland in 1959.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 14 --The country's top advertisers were told today that they should pay less attention to the "mechanics" of advertising and more to the content.
The arrest of James R. Hoffa came as a committee of union leaders was busy passing the hat for a life-size portrait of the Midwest teamster official.
The novelty at last night's performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" was the conductor. Tibor Kozma had never before directed the work at the ...
A lively overseas visitor with a ready wit and a gracious manner raised a glass of Irish whisky yesterday and offered the traditional Hebrew drinking toast, "L'Chayim."
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 14--The Giants, beaten by the Baltimore Orioles, 7--6, today, may have lost more than an exhibition baseball game.

CHICAGO, March 14--Wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade were generally lower today. The July and more forward positions lost more ground than the March. Declines of 1 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel were recorded.
CAIRO, March 15--President Gamal Abdel Nasser has decided to deny passage to Israeli shipping through the Suez Canal when it reopens, an official Egyptian source said today.
The dramatic struggle for control of Fairbanks, Morse Co. has taken a new twist.
LONG BEACH, L.I., March 15--Herbert B. Mayer, former newspaper reporter, editor and magazine publisher, died here today in his home at 15 May Walk. His age was 69.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15--Bette Davis, one of Hollywood's last major hold-outs from live television, has agreed to take a co-starring role with her husband, Gary Merrill, in a "Playhouse 90" drama to be presented April 11.

The National Invitation Tournament, one of college basketball's outstanding post-season events, will open its twentieth annual stand at Madison Square Garden today with afternoon and evening double-headers.

ONE day, perhaps, there will be a star for an Antarctic state in the American flag. The death this week of Admiral Byrd reminds us all how great a part the United States under his leadership played in the exploration of what Walter Hayward called the last continent of adventure. Yet many other nations have staked their claims in those white, mysterious wastes.

A member of Congress charged yesterday that some foreign-language press writings here during the Korean war represented "treason." He demanded denaturalization and deportation of "active Communist" editors.

A public borrowing of $35,000,000 is about to be undertaken in the United States in behalf of the coal and steel enterprises of six Western European nations that share the common market of the European Coal and Steel Community.
LONDON, March 15--Bjarne Braatoy, secretary of the Socialist International since last March, died in a London hospital today. He was 57 years old.

The Consolidated Edison Company's petition for meter-reading changes that would bring in about $9,000,000 a year in additional revenue was subjected yesterday to a searching "need's test" before the Public Service Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15-- Navy scientists have produced tons of "synthetic radioactive fall-out" as part of an experiment in protecting populations against an atomic attack.
PARIS, March 15 (AP)--Moshe Pijade, president of the Yugoslav Federal Assembly and one of President Tito's top lieutenants, died here today of a heart attack. His age was 67.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP)--Jackie Burke Jr., a Texan, fired a 3-under-par 68 today and led by one stroke at the midway mark of the St. Petersburg open golf tournament.
CHICAGO, March 15 (AP)--A poultry dealer, testifying at the United States District Court trial of five men charged with labor racketeering, told of "contributing" $400 to Joey Glimco, a labor leader.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 15--Miss Miriam Elaine Seligman and Andrew L. Ageloff, graduate students at the University of Virginia, will be married in June.

WITH Easter Sunday thirtysix days away, it is just about time to take the children shopping. Prescribed, along with the chocolate bunnies and jelly beans is a new Easter outfit, which traditionally should include a flower-brimming bonnet and shiny Mary-Janes, at the least.

The Louserge Realty Corporation, representing East Side restaurateurs, bought the four-story business and apartment building on lot 35 by 100 feet at 139-41 East Fifty-third Street, where they plan a restaurant on the ground floor.
An immense growth of knowledge of the world will result from the scientific efforts to be coordinated in the International Geophysical Year, a scientist told the Explorers Club last night.
By the margin of a bout, Navy retained the epee team honors yesterday in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships.
PARIS, Saturday, March 16 (Reuters)--Constantin Brancusi, world-famous sculptor, died here early today. His age was 81. He had been in failing health for some time and fell into a coma Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 15--A wave of selling hit the wheat market today on the Board of Trade, resulting in sharp declines. Corn and soybeans held firm for a time but sold off in late trading. Rye and oats fell in sympathy with wheat.
LONDON, March 15--Britain's booming shipyards are to be shut down at noon tomorrow by a strike.
LOS ALAMOS, N.M., March 15 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission, in a belated announcement, disclosed today that an atomic device used in weapons research had blown apart Feb. 12.
Yvette Souviron, Argentineborn soprano of French parentage, gave a recital entitled "Songs From Many Lands in Costume" last night in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) --A three-stage wage increase that would become 26 cents an hour after three years was recommended today by an emergency board for 160,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
Two officials of a garment center trucking union were charged yesterday with attempting to extort $800 from a dress company on threat of physical violence and labor trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 15-- Frank W. Brewster, leader of the Western Conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, swore today that accusations made against him in the last three weeks were "absolutely fantastic and completely untrue."
AMMAN, Jordan, March 15-- Jordan's armed forces would be a decisive factor in a showdown between the Conservative movement and the Leftist-dominated Government.

This is the week when spring begins by the calendar. The vernal equinox occurs Wednesday afternoon. PITTSBURGH, March 17-- The steel rate is headed down but a sharp and sustained drop is not expected.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP)--A Senate Commerce Subcommittee will open hearings tomorrow to determine whether automobile "finance-insurance combines" have engaged in unethical practices.

Ramon Caro and his wife were making a comfortable living from their restaurant when the city acquired the building, on, Second Avenue near 109th Street, as part of a six-block site for public housing and a new junior high school.
A strike-battered "Queen of the World's Ports" will adjust her walkout-wearied royal raiment tomorrow morning and put up a bold front, as she accept her annual salute.

KATMANDU, Nepal, March 17 --Nepal desires to be the neutral country par excellence. It has no territorial claims on other nations.

The tragic death of President Ramon Magsaysay has taken from the Philippines, and the Filipino people, a great leader. His greatness lay, in part, in the very fact that he was so much of those people.

MANILA, Monday, March 18 --President Ramon Magsaysay's charred, burned body was found today by rescuers in the wreckage of his plane on Cebu Island.

Large space on the second floor of the Bank of New York building, the new office structure at 530 Fifth Avenue at Forty-fourth Street, has been leased by the Hat Corporation of America. The concern manufactures men's hats, including the Dobbs, Knox and Cavanagh brands.
WASHINGTON, March 17--Three of every five veterans' widows entitled to increased dependents' compensation payments have failed to apply for them, the Veterans Administration said today.

A FIFTEEN-MINUTE religious education program for children made an impressive debut yesterday at noon over Channel 11. Entitled "0ff to Adventure," it was presented in cooperation with the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican leader, said yesterday that Governor Harriman would be "duck soup for any Republican" in the 1958 election.

Contemporary American music, to judge by the programs of Max Pollikoff's series, "Music in Our Times: 1900-1957," must be bursting with vitality, variety and imagination.

ONLY a major opera house like the Meropolitan has the resources for Verdi's "Don Carlo." It is one of the highest marks of distinction of Rudolf Bing's consulship that it has given this great and still relatively unappreciated opera a production worthy of its quality.

A MODERNIZED version of Robert E. Sherwood's "There Shall Be No Night," tailored to fit recent events in Hungary as opposed to the late playwright's original concern with the Soviet invasion of Finland in 1939, was offered last night on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (U.P.) --Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today he would introduce a bill tomorrow requiring the Secretary of State to grant passports to accredited newsmen to enter any country, including Red China.

ABOARD U. S. S. WILLIAM M. WOOD, March 17--President Eisenhower broke his sun-and-rest routine at sea today for a briefing on the tense Middle Eastern situation.

LACKING those enormous pots of meat and chicken stock, common in restaurant kitchens, the knowing home cook keeps handy small tins of bouillon. On these she relies as a professional chef does on his stocks; she uses bouillon to flavor soups, sauces, pot roasts, vegetables and so on.
ALBANY, March 17--Decisions are due this week on most of the key issues facing this year's session of the Legislature.

No great fanfare has accompanied the signing of the contract to build the Karnafuli dam and power plant in East Pakistan. The project is under the aegis of the International Cooperation Administration.
MADISON, N.J., March 17-- Herbert A. Lafler, chief engineer of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, died last night of a heart attack at his home here, 55 West Lane. His age was 55.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- Secretary of State Dulles and Mrs. Golda Meir, Israeli Foreign Minister, arrived here this afternoon. They plan to meet tomorrow on the renewed crisis over the Gaza Strip.

LIMA, Peru, March 17--The $31,000,000 Paucartambo hydroelectric project of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation was dedicated today. The new plant will provide power for the copper, lead and zinc refineries of the corporation at La Oroya in the Central Andes and for mining activities.

LONDON, March 17--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan stressed today that his talks this week President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada would have a vital bearing on the future of the Middle East and on Britain's oil supply.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Members of the House of Representatives are expected to make their annual show of definance this week against the Senate, which has a, habit of restoring budget cuts made by the lower chamber.

DETROIT, March l7 (UP)--Alex Delvecchio returned after a firstperiod injury tonight to fire the goal chat enabled the Detroit Red Wings to gain their eighth National Hockey League title in the last nine seasons. The goal beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2--1.
BUFFALO, March 17 (AP)--An assistant professor died today in an apartment house fire that forced the occupants of thirtyseven other apartments in the building to the street in their nightclothes.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 17 (AP)--Philadelphia defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4--1, today as three Phillies' pitchers--Jim Hearn, Jack Sanford and Gene Snyder--doled out five hits.

A five-story walk-up building at 362 East 156th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Henry J. Frees to an investing client of Herman Pollack, attorneys. Robert E. Hill, Inc., was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $52,000. The building contains twenty-five apartments. It occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.

LONDON, March 17--In the critical days of the British campaign in North Africa in World War II, Winston Churchill, then Prime Minister, directed the Army of the Nile "to fight with no thought of retreat or withdrawal."
LONDON, March 18--Dr. John Bodkin Adams, family physician accused of murdering an aged widow with narcotic prescriptions to obtain a legacy, went on trial here today at Old Bailey.

It appeared almost certain yesterday that George Gobel and Eddie Fisher will be teamed next fall as the stars of a Tuesday night (8 to 9 o'clock) variety program over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

New York is making ready to open its fourth Summer Festival. Some of the attractions that the hundreds of thousands of visitors will find here were listed yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, chairman of the board of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 --The social planner was challenged today to "come on out and fight's instead of leaving American community decisions to "the political primitives and the hatchet men of the intellect."

ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 18 (UP)--Two confessed murderers were convicted today of killing two United States tourists and sinking their bodies into Acapulco Bay.

AS stimulating as a tall, frosty Planter's Punch was a chat we had recently with Col. A.R. Woolley, managing director of Lemon Hart Rum Ltd., of London. The subject was, of course, rum--how to drink it and how to use it to advantage in cooking.

A solemn requiem mass, presided over by Cardinal Spellman, was offered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral for the Rev. James Martin Gillis. The internationally known author, radio preacher and former editor of The Catholic World died on Thursday at the age of 80.

WASHINGTON, March 18-- Secretary of State Dulles, in a joint statement with Mrs. Golda Meir, Israeli Foreign Minister, reaffirmed today that the United States stands "firmly by [its] hopes and expectations" on developments in the Middle East.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 18 --Percy H. Thomas, a retired electrical engineer, died today at his home in the Marlboro Inn, 334 Grove Street. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 18-- About 250 clergymen, Government officials, educators and community leaders began an intensive examination here tonight of the barriers confronting man in his search for peace with justice.

DETROIT, March 18 (AP)--New car stocks in retailers' hands have increased further. Automotive News reported today that dealers held 729,040 new cars on March 1, compared with 629,400 on Feb. 1 and 903,789 on March 1, 1956.

LONDON, March 18--The nation-wide shipbuilding strike and the possibility of further labor unrest depressed almost all sections of the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers' planting intentions for 1957 indicated the smallest crop acreage under cultivation in forty years.

The fact that Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain gave an unsolicited statement in the form of an interview to this newspaper's bureau chief in Madrid and also answered some questions is of considerable interest. One cannot recall the Spanish dictator having done anything of the sort before.
William Lombardy of New York gained his second victory in the international chess tournament yesterday, according to a report received from Buenos Aires.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman joined with Mayor Wagner yesterday in asking wide support for the Urban League of Greater New York. The organization is devoted to promoting equality for all in jobs, housing and schooling.

Sales and earnings of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation last year exceeded all previous records, according to the annual report to be released today.

WASHINGTON, March 18-- Better Business Bureau officials charged today that some leading automobile insurance concerns had defrauded policyholders of millions of dollars through overcharges.

Bloomingdale's Green Room is name-dropping like mad this spring. And with good reason, Hundreds of handsome styles from Seventh Avenue's name designers now cram the Green Room's racks, selected with loving care by Mrs. Margaret K. Carroll.

Ways of making mountain peaks serve as radio booster stations were described yesterday at the national convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers. The phenomenon that makes this possible is now known as "obstacle gain."

"The Duchess of Malfi" arrives at 7:45 o'clock tonight at the Phoenix Theatre, where it will continue through April 14.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., March 18--The way to catch bass around here is to work along a bayou bank with a sculling machine, find a lizard headdown on a cypress tree, and cast a plug at the lizard.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The House Judiciary Committee approved a civil rights bill today. Except for a few modifications, it follows the program sought by President Eisenhower.
Cotton futures advanced 11 to 18 points (55 to 90 cents a bale) here yesterday in very limited trading.

Transamerica Corporation, largest bank holding company in the nation, increased its profits and the extent of its banking interests last year, F. N. Belgrano Jr., president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

A blueprint for the development of district-wide schoolcommunity groups was outlined yesterday by the United Parents Associations and school officials.
ALBANY, March 18--Republican leaders agreed today at a conference with Governor Harriman to reconsider their position on raising the gasoline and Diesel fuel taxes.

ALBANY, March 18--An Assembly bill expected to save utility companies $80,000,000 in the next few years was approved by a divided vote in the Senate tonight. The measure now goes to Governor Harriman.
ALBANY, March 18--A behind-the-scenes dispute between Republicans and Democrats over the closing of the Mount McGregor Veterans Rest Home at Saratoga appeared on its way to settlement tonight.
The burden of carrying large inventories during a slow selling period is reflected in the annual report of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, sent to shareholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 18--The two top problems confronting automobile dealers are the black eyes given the trade by an unscrupulous minority and dangerously low dealer net profits, the president of the National Automobile Dealers Association said today.

ANOTHER Western hero rode across television screens last night as "Tales of Wells Fargo" made its debut on Channel 4. The leading man in the new series, based on the history of the enterprising express company, is Dale Robertson.
ALBANY, March 18--The prospects for the passage of legislation to help finance the construction of the proposed "supertrack" at Aqueduct soared today.

ROME, March 18--Religious minorities won an important legal victory here today. The Constitutional High Court, Italy's supreme tribunal, ruled that public religious gatherings may be held without previous notice to the police.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 19 --A compromise settlement was reached early today on differences over Britain's decision to cut her armed forces in Europe.

An investing group represented by Roy Berlin, attorney, has disposed of all its holdings in this city. In separate transactions it sold the eighteenstory and penthouse apartment building at 275 Central Park West and four walk-up apartment houses in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, March 18--Long liquidation in grains was heavy again today on the Board of Trade, especially in the March deliveries. March wheat led the declines. But trading was slow during much of the session.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18--"Raintree County" will go back before the cameras at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for additional filming that is expected to require a week to complete.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., March 18 (AP)--A Methodist minister shot and killed a fleeing bank robber today after the robber had slain a state policeman at a roadblock. The dead... were Sgt. Marvin E. Walts, 49 years old, of the State Police and William Hasset, 25, of Louisville.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 18-- The successful demonstration to the Civil Aeronautics Administration of a "picture transformer" that carries radar information to television screens was announced today by the Intercontinental Electronics Corporation.

Stefan Redl, a Hungarian welterweight who now lives in Passaic, knocked out Al (Rocky) Milone of Coney Island at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The fight, scheduled for ten rounds, was halted at 2:04 of the eighth by Referee Barney Felix.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18-- When the Kansas City Athletics, the poor relations of the New York Yankees, visited St. Pete the other day for a game with the Cardinals, it was like old home week for approximately a dozen of them.
ALBANY, March 18--A split among Democrats delayed final legislative action tonight on new and tougher New York-New Jersey waterfront controls.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18--World exports rose 11 per cent in value last year to a new high of $91,000,000,000, the United Nations reported today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 18-- Bill Rigney, manager of the Giants, today warned Daryl Spencer to "learn to hit to right --or else."
The worst year for icebergs in a half century forced the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth to steer forty miles south of her normal course.
Brokers' earnings have been suffering in recent weeks. The big houses, by rule of thumb, say they just break even when trading on the New York Stock Exchange runs 1,600,000 to 1,700,000 shares a day.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. has started a fascinating and possibly historic debate by recommending action to remove what is perhaps the most serious flaw in the Constitution.
TUNIS, Tunisia, March 18-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon received the biggest welcome here today that he has had anywhere during his tour of eight African countries.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The National Council of Jewish Women declined today George M. Humphrey's invitation to join the drive for economy in Government.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18--Almost every day something develops to make the outlook more discouraging than ever for clubs hopeful of bringing a little grief to the Yankees.

LEICESTER, England, March 18--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared tonight that the object of his forthcoming talks with President Eisenhower was to clear up any differences between Britain and the United States.

THE first network experiment in sustained educational television--conducted by the National Broadcasting Company and the Educational Television and Radio Center of Ann Arbor Mich.--entered its second week last night. As with all new marriages, it is going to take time to see how this union works out.

A registration statement covering the first public offering in the United States of securities of the European Coal and Steel Community was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved unanimously today the nomination of Judge Charles Evans Whittaker to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
Lassitude continued to rule the stock market yesterday. Transactions fell to the smallest figure since Oct. 23, only 1,450,000 shares. On Friday turnover had been 1,604,310.

Safety experts heard the auto branded as "a weapon like a pistol or a machine gun" yesterday. And like firearms, declared Frederick J. Gassert Jr., Director of Motor Vehicles in New Jersey, its use should be regarded as a privilege and not as a right.

THE Little Orchestra Society concluded its tenth season last night at Town Hall. Its program consisted of a repetition of Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," the opera that it used in March, 1949, to begin its successful series of operas in concert form.
Sam Berger, for twelve years the top official in the major garment trucking union, was charged yesterday with conspiracy and extortion.
The existing real estate tax of $4.02 for each $100 of assessed valuation will be held at its present level in fiscal 1957-58, Mayor Wagner forecast yesterday.

A report by an interfaith committee that inquired into a racket-tainted Long Island local of the Operating Engineers Union is being studied by Senate investigators. They represent the Senate's Select Committee on Labor and Management Practices.
Two of New York's afternoon newspapers are increasing their newsstand prices from 5 to 10 cents.
A tour of homes and gardens in Greenwich, Conn., and Armonk, N.Y., on May 23 will aid the Patients Special Project Fund of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

With new tension rising in the Middle East, Secretary Dulles has issued a joint declaration with Israel's Foreign Minister to the effect that the United States stands firmly by the "hopes and expectations" it has expressed regarding a settlement of the conflict between Egypt and Israel.

Tony Jackson a 6-foot 4-inch forward who says he "would rather pass off than make points," did both extremely well yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 18--Israel sailed a freighter down the Gulf of Aqaba to the Red Sea today to force the issue of free navigation in the contested waterway.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today Congress must increase postal rates on a broad scale, or "nullify" much of its efforts to reduce the Federal budget.

ALBANY, March 19--An allocation of $600,000 more in education aid for a special class of school districts received final approval from the Assembly today. Most of the districts are in Westchester and Nassau Counties.

WASHINGTON, March 19--A strong Senate attack upon John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, is being prepared for loosing if the renewed Israeli-Arab crisis should bring fresh hostilities or new Egyptian actions against Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 19--A spokesman for the Better Business Bureaus today condemned auto insurance practices that he said had cost some buyers as much as 600 per cent interest on time contracts paid in advance of due dates.
LONDON, March 19--The British Government postponed at the last minute today a scheduled statement in the House of Commons on the truce offer made by Cypriote terrorists.
VIENNA, March 19--Even without further action by the United States Congress the Hungarian refugee problem appears headed for early "solution."
PORTLAND, Ore.. March 19 (AP)--In a copyrighted story today. The Oregon Journal produced two affidavits that called a bribe accusation against Mayor Terry Schrunk a frame-up.

Philip H. Reisman of 118 Robins Road, New Rochelle, N.Y., president of the Fugazy Shipping Corporation, who had been a motion-picture executive for more than thirty years, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 66.

MOSCOW, March 19--The Soviet Union has adopted new rules that will give priority in gaining admission to universities and higher schools to those who have had work experience on farms and in factories.
ALBANY, March 19--The creation of a state air pollution control board with power to enforce atmospheric sanitary standards in any area was approved today by the Senate.

PEMATANGSIANTARA, Indonesia, March 17--A choir of fifty young men and women, descendants of savage Batak tribes that practiced cannibalism less than a century ago, sang the Hallelujah chorus from Handel's "Messiah" today in a temperature of 100 degrees.
Following are excerpts from the text of Mayor Wagner's address yesterday to the City Council upon presenting his Annual Report for 1956:

A Pennsylvania dairy farmer warned here yesterday that the flow of milk to the New York metropolitan area would be cut off by a boycott unless the entire region wet a brought under uniform Federal control.
The Council of Western European Union met on the evening of 18th March at the London headquarters of the organization, 9 Grovesnor Place.
A $314,000,000 ship--the most costly, the most powerful and probably the largest vessel in the world--leads the Navy's list of new construction in the next fiscal year, beginning July 1.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., March 19--Capt. Eugene T. Osborn of Atlantic Avenue, who before his retirement in 1946 was Long Island commander of the United States Coast Guard, died today at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue after a brief illness. His age was 68.
Three major airlines in the New York area that operate the turbo-propeller Viscount airliners are conducting precautionary inspections of the wingflap attachment bolts on the British-built planes.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19--The Dodgers got tangled in their first overtime game here today with the Athletics and lost it.

New York State's 2,000,000 women workers may be considerably less sure-footed than men, but on the whole they are believed no more prone to accidents. Dr. Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner, reported these findings yesterday to specialists attending the twentyseventh annual Safety Convention and Exposition.

MESA, Ariz., March 19--Bob Lennon delivered the key blow in today's 9-4 victory by the Giants over the Chicago Cubs. Lennon, is possibly the leastmentioned player in the New York camp. He slammed a pinch, three-run homer against Tom Poholsky in the fourth inning.
MANILA, March 19--Hysteria overcame Filipino mourners as Ramon Magsaysay's body was flown from Cebu to Manila today.

CHICAGO, March 19--Fairbanks, Morse Co. today filed suit in Federal District Court here to prevent Leopold D. Silberstein and his Penn-Texas Corporation from voting ... Fairbanks shares at the annual meeting March 27.

Premier David Ben-Gurion has warned that Israel will go to war if peaceful efforts fail to bring "freedom from terror" at the Gaza border and freedom of passage through the Suez Canal and the Strait of Tiran.
ALBANY, March 19--Republican Senators decided today at a closed party conference to reject this year any increase in the gasoline and Diesel fuel taxes.
The United Artists Corporation, last of the privately held major motion-picture companies in the nation, will make its first offering of securities to the public next month.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 --A British planning expert suggested today two-tier governments for metropolitan areas like New York.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Money is "tight" today. It's harder, or more expensive, to get a loan now than it used to be, and the Federal Reserve Board has helped to make it so.
The intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament in Chicago last week was overshadowed by a number of other events on the college front, but the outcome deserved attention.

The premiere of "Hotel Paradiso" at Henry Miller's has been changed from April 3 to April 11. There's nothing radically wrong with Peter Glenville's farce, the complement of which includes five stars headed by Bert Lahr.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Secretary, ordered today a 12 per cent cut in military and civilian manpower in the capital area.

At 4:17 this afternoon the season of spring will arrive. To all appearances the one second which comes after 4:17 will not seem any different than the one second which came before. Neither will one minute, nor one hour and certainly not one day mark a visible barrier between the ...

WASHINGTON, March 19-- The use of military force as a deterrent to Communist aggression was unqualifiedly endorsed tonight by Lord Pakenham, British religious leader and former First Lord of the Admiralty.

The Estate Securities Company, a realty operating concern with Alvin A. Levy and Irbing Magot as executive officers, has bought the four-story building on a plot 17 by 100 feet at 1440 Lexington Avenue, near Ninetyfourth Street.
There is a definite danger that inflation will become a "permanent feature of American life," the United States Steel Corporation warned in its annual report issued today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points (60 cents a bale) up to 2 points (10 cents a bale) off yesterday, with the near months showing the most strength.

Mayor Wagner's third annual message to the City Council, presenting also a handsome 122-page illustrated report for 1956, finds that the most significant point to be made about New York City is that "it is prosperous and getting more prosperous." This is true, and we believe the Wagner administration can fairly lay claim to credit for creating a climate encouraging to business and industry.
An electronic device that gives a patient in an iron lung control over his breathing was described yesterday at the national convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
WARSAW, March 19--Poland's Communist leaders have rejected pressure within the party to modify the terms of the agreement reached with the Roman Catholic Church last year.

LONDON, March 19--The stock markets here were buoyant today, owing to a slackening of selling. Some shares recovered part of yesterday's losses caused by the initial impact of the nation-wide shipbuilding strike.

More drinking by New Yorkers added nearly $3,000,000 to state funds last year. The State Liquor Authority said in its annual report yesterday that $78,730,980 was realized ... from taxes on alcoholic beverages, license and permit fees, bond claims and miscellaneous collections. That was an increase of $2,810,880 in the year.

IF you think you deserve a medal, no one has a wider col lection to pin on you than Gimbels. The only act of heroism you must perform to achieve one is the safe crossing of Broadway and Thirty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- William Joseph Brennan Jr. of New Jersey and Charles Evans Whittaker of Missouri were confirmed today as Associate Justices of the Supreme Court.
ALBANY, March 19--The chief obstacle to money-saving changes in the Permanent Personal Registration Law was removed today.

WASHINGTON, March 19--A Federal grand jury today indicted James Riddle Hoffa, a vice president of the Teamsters Union, and Hyman I. Fischbach, an attorney. They were charged on three counts of attempting to obtain information from the files of a Senate committee.

Sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation last year were the largest in the company's thirty-threeyear history, E.E. Stewart, president, disclosed in the annual report to be issued today.

The Kroger Company, large food chain, is manufacturing its own instant coffee in a new $1,000,000 plant in Cincinnati. It thus becomes the first food chain to produce its own private label instant coffee.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, March 19--The doubt that always overcomes camp followers at international conferences before their start is endemic in Bermuda tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Israel pressed the United States again today to live up to its "moral commitments."

Peter Collins, an Englishman who is rated as one of the first five drivers in the world in sports and Grand Prix cars, is only 25 years old. He started his racing career at the age of 17. His rise to prominence in the racing world parallels that of Sterling Moss, his fellow countryman.
Another money rate receded yesterday from recent record levels. In line with declining yields on Government bills, the going rate on bankers' acceptances was cut one-quarter percentage point.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 19--Former Vice Premier Suwirjo, struggling since Friday to assemble a new Cabinet, still was unable tonight to announce Indonesia's seventeenth Government in eleven years.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 19 --The Yankees, who have been bringing nothing except grief to their American League rivals for a long time, are not helping the morale of National Leaguers, either.

Mayor Wagner took a long official look at the city yesterday and found it good. He told the City Council that business, industry and employment were at a peak, and that municipal administration was efficient, prudently managed and forward-looking.
LONDON, March 19--The Western European Union announced today it had agreed that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should review Britain's plan to reduce her forces on the mainland of Europe.
THREE new works, two of them of this century, were presented last night in Carnegie Hall by the National Orchestral Association and its guest conductor, Newell Jenkins.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- A civil rights bill embodying President Eisenhower's program was voted today by the Senate subcommittee on Constitutional Rights.

Having ousted the United Nations from control of non-Egyptian Gaza, President Nasser has offered a new challenge to the United Nations. He has sent the maritime powers a memorandum outlining the terms under which he will permit the ships of other nations to pass through the Suez Canal.

Vassily Smyslov defeated the champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, in the sixth game of their world title match at the Tschaikowsky Music Hall, in Moscow yesterday, according to a report received, through, Moscow news channels.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- High school students touring the Capitol turned expert witnesses today on why parents and children don't always get along and why some boys and girls become delinquent.
LONDON, March 19--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said tonight that he was confident a "great deal will be gained" through his talks with President Eisenhower in Bermuda.

The age of the trolley car here was one clang nearer its end yesterday. A Public Service Commission examiner heard argument by the Queensboro Bridge Railway Company, Inc., to substitute buses for trolley service across the East River span.

THERE'S no business like shoe business. The sliver-thin heel--one of the biggest headaches ever to plague the industry--has reached dizzying heights in fashion in the past few years and gives no evidence of tottering.

Trading was dull and featureless yesterday in most commodity markets on the New York exchanges. Wool, hides, copper and tin rose; sugar, cocoa, rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined, and price movements for coffee, potatoes and zinc were mixed.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Following is the text of the memorandum sent by the Egyptian Government to foreign diplomatic missions in Cairo as released here today by the Egyptian Embassys
ALBANY, March 19--The Assembly Rules Committee reported out to the floor tonight a compromise bill to plug loopholes in the compulsory insurance law.

WHEN Dorothy Charques was a child she lived within eight miles of the site of the battle of Worcester, the last important battle in England in the civil war between the parliamentary and royalist forces. From Worcester Charles II fled to exile and Cromwell emerged triumphant.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., March 19--The Leaf and the Chickasawhay Rivers join to make the Pascagoula River about 115 miles from its mouth on Mississippi Sound (about, sixty miles as the jet flies). But only a cartographer or a bass fisherman can make any sense out of what happens between those points.
TUNIS, Tunisia, March 19-- A new crisis in French-Tunisian relations appeared to be developing tonight with Vice President Richard M. Nixon in the middle of things.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 --The Chilean Government ordered today the preventive arrest of six Peronist leaders who fled to Chile yesterday from a prison in Argentina.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19--Twentieth Century-Fox' unique position as the only oilbearing motion-picture studio will not go unchallenged for long. Columbia Pictures today disclosed that it has joined with Paramount and R.K.O. in leasing oil rights on their properties to the Union Oil Company of California.
WASHINGTON, March 19--In the current constitutional debate over who runs the Administration when a President is disabled, President Eisenhower has played a responsible and disinterested role.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 19 (U.P.)--Vice President E.J. (Buzzie) Bavasi of the Dodgers tonight rejected the Cincinnati Redlegs' seven-player offer for Brooklyn's twenty-seven-game winner, Don Newcombe, as "silly."

At the request of Secretary Dulles Chairman Green of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has introduced a joint resolution (S.J. Res. 73) to increase the ceiling on United States contributions to the International Labor Organization from $1,750,000 to $3,000,000. The need ...
Stocks crawled quietly upward yesterday in an exceedingly inactive market. Metals, steels, oils, chemicals and rails shared in what strength there was.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- U.S. officials welcomed Egypt's unexpected proposal for running the Suez Canal today as an indication that President Nasser wanted the tension over the canal and the Gaza Strip to simmer down.

In New York, Mr. Silberstein commented: "Mr. Robert Morse has now publicly conceded defeat. This latest court action is simply another attempt to publicize unwarranted insinuations. He merely seeks to postpone the inevitable.

OF fascinating gadgetry there is no end at the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers, now in the Coliseum. But one exhibit-- the stardust-detector--excites romantic imagination. It is a strip two inches long and a half-inch wide devised to gauge the erosive force of meteoric dust in outer space. Daystrom...

ALBANY, March 19--Legislation that virtually would mandate an election to determine collective bargaining representation for New York City transit employes will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow.
LONDON, March 19--The frailty of human memory became an issue today in the murder trial of Dr. John Bodkin Adams.
The Garden State Plaza Shopping Center, being built in Paramus, N.J., will open on May 1, it was announced yesterday. The center will be the largest in the state.
PARIS, March 19--Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France warned the National Assembly tonight that the country was heading toward a war economy if peace was not established quickly in Algeria.

The Pennsylvania Railroad's working capital fell by $12,000,000 last year to $122,374,699. In the annual report, sent to stockholders yesterday, James M. Symes, president, described the road's year-end working capital as the "minimum required for the conduct of our business."

Kim Stanley, who attained stardom on Broadway in a play titled "The Traveling Lady" in 1954, will star in a television adaptation of the drama on "Studio One." It will be televised on April 22 from 10 to 11 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
The new British Ambassador to Israel, a New Yorker, will leave here this morning by sea en route to his assignment.
Two airline companies yesterday accepted liability for a plane crash in which twentytwo Puerto Rican veterans of the Korean war were killed and sixteen others seriously injured.
NEW DELHI, India, March 18 --India's Communists have come forward today with a strange victory slogan for the southern state of Kerala: "We are not going to do anything wonderful."

The twenty-ninth annual Eastern States Regional Championships continued last night with sixteen contract bridge teams out of a starting field of thirtysix remaining in the Reisinger Cup team of four championship.

A two-year investigation into Communist influences in the City Housing Authority has resulted so far in three dismissals and four resignations among the agency's 5,800 employes. Fifteen other cases remain under active study, it was reported yesterday by Charles H. Tenney, Commissioner of Investigation.

President Eisenhower's civil rights bill has now been approved with some modifications by the House Judiciary Committee, more than a month earlier than a comparable measure last year, which was delayed until April, when the Administration finally got around to sending its proposals to Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- The Federal Reserve Board published today its long-awaited staff study on consumer installment credit.

The Mayflower Development Corporation, Marcus Retter, president, has purchased for investment the Sixteen-story apartment house for 174 families at 425 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 115th Street.
Voters in substantial numbers ballotted yesterday in spite of bad weather in the annual spring elections of eighty-eight villages in the four metropolitan counties.

ABOARD U.S.S. WILLIAM M. WOOD, March 19--Targets near President Eisenhower and the U.S.S. Canberra came under a simulated atomic bomb attack today by Navy planes of the aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt.
"Salvage" is due April 9 at the Actors Playhouse. John Seven and Clifford Kraus are the authors of the new melodrama, which was put through its paces four years ago in Wilmington, Del.
CAIRO, March 19--Egypt has sent a memorandum to the United States and other maritime powers describing how she intends to operate the Suez Canal once it is reopened to navigation.
THERE were repeated collisions by two of Bergdorf Goodman's favorite designers yesterday. They were the most fortunate of accidents.

In response to years of agitation for an open tournament, the United States Lawn Tennis Association has appointed a committee to conduct an exhaustive study of the question of holding one and make its recommendations to the executive committee.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 19 (AP) --A heavy cut in the April permissive oil flow from Texas fields was ordered today by the State Railroad commission after oil men said they did not want continued high production.

Burton Rascoe, author, editor and former drama and literary critic, was found dead last evening by his wife, Mrs. Hazel Luke Rascoe, in their home at 525 East Eighty-ninth Street. His age was 64. Death apparently was the result of a heart attack.
The State of Massachusetts returned to the market yesterday to borrow $20,160,000 on serial bonds to finance capital outlays.

Representative Paul A. Fino, top Republican vote-getter in the Bronx, threw his support yesterday behind Herman Winner for election as Bronx County Republican leader.
Yesterday was Port of New York Day. But bleak, rainy weather combined with a restriction by the Office of Civil Defense to make it one of the quietest observances in the twenty-three-year series.

CHICAGO, March 19--March wheat slumped again today on the Board of Trade. Further long liquidation put a damper on buying of other wheat deliveries. Tomorrow will be the final day for trading in the March future, and there was considerable evening up in the pit, although trading was not particularly active during much of the session.

Bradley University's team set three National Inviation Tournament and Madison square Garden collegiate scoring records as it crushed Xavier of Cincinnati, 116 to 81, last night. The Braves from Peoria, Ill., moved into the semi-final round of the twentieth annual basketball competition.

The successful flight of some of the most notorious Peronist prisoners from Argentina to Chile is a disturbing development. This spells more trouble for the Aramburu Government, which is struggling so hard to bring the nation back to a state of normality and democracy after the eleven-year nightmare of Juan Peron's military dictatorship.

The master of a small tanker involved in a crash on March 8 with an anchored freighter said yesterday he had no recollection of the accident. The pilot of a water taxi, crushed between the two vessels, lost his life in the crash.
Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney insisted yesterday that Councilman Robert E. Barnes submit to questioning in private on his outside business activities.
MILWAUKEE, March 19-- Protracted "steady dating" among the nation's youth threatens the Christian concept of marriage, the twenty fifth National Catholic Family Life Convention was heard today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 (UP)--Sam Snead fought threatening skies and a brisk offshore wind today for a threeunder-par 69 and a three-way tie at the halfway point of the $10,000 Seminole golf tournament.

SINCE John Webster's "The Duchess of Malfi" is a horror play, a studied production ill becomes it. Jack Landau's stage version, which opened at the Phoenix last evening, dissipates most of its raw emotion.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- The National Council of Jewish Women urged the United States today to use immediately "the full weight of its power, prestige and authority to prevent withdrawal of the United Nations from the Gaza Strip."
ALBANY, March 20--Two major changes in the Tweed court reform program were made today in an effort to overcome formidable political objections to its approval.
Reporting pressure from veterans' and other groups, the Martinique Hotel canceled arrangements yesterday for a meeting that was to have been addressed by John Gates, Communist leader.
WASHINGT0N, March 20-- Economic talks with Poland are awaiting top-level United States decisions on Poland's request for $300,000,000 in aid.
ALBANY, March 20--The Legislature completed today the task of putting new teeth into the laws controlling labor on the New York-New Jersey waterfront.

Five walk-up apartment houses on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 306 to 314 West Forty-fourth Street have been purchased by Harry Horwitz, realty operator, in a deal negotiated by John J. Fitter and Raymond Murphy brokers.

Jacob Neinken of 1523 Fiftythird Street, Brooklyn, founder and president of the Champion Pants Manufacturing Company, died yesterday in Miami, Fla. His age was 83.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- The House of Representatives cut budget requests made by eighteen independent agencies by 9 per cent today. Action was taken by a voice vote. The bill now goes to the Senate.

MANILA, March 20--President Carlos P. Garcia was assured today of a free hand in selecting his Cabinet. He also received an unofficial vote of confidence in his ability to lead the Philippines in continued proUnited States and anti-Communist policies.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Secretary of State Dulles took a tranquil view today of developments in the Middle East.
