A master plan to reorganize Manhattan's high school system has been approved by the Board of Education.

TOMORROW, 4 P.M.: A free musical story hour will be presented at the New York Public Library's Wakefield Branch, 4100 Lowerre Place, the Bronx. Recordings of "Blue Tail Fly," "Shoo Fly" and "Way. Down Yonder in the Paw-Paw Patch" will be played and folk tales told.

GLYNDON, Md., March 20-- For most television stars, the fan mail ends when the performer leaves the screen. Not so with Native Dancer, a star of Alfred Gywnne. Vanderbilt's 582-acre Sagamore Farm here.

The nation's known reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids were at a record high of 36,336,981,000 barrels. at the close of last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was 886,246,000 barrels above the 35,450,735,000 on Dec. 31, 1955.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20--The Columbia Broadcasting System is instituting a major production change in "Climax!", weekly dramatic program.

Sixteen remaining contract bridge teams played the thirdround knockout matches last night for the Reisinger cup. This is the most important team event in the annual play for the Eastern States Regional Championships.
CHICAGO, March 20--Sharp rallies followed initial dips for grain and soybean futures prices today on the Board of Trade.
LONDON, Thursday, March 21--Britain was threatened yesterday with the most serious industrial strife since the general strike of 1926.
BASKING RIDGE, N. J., March 20--Allen Lewis, artist, died today at Morristown Memorial Hospital at the age of 83. He lived at 97 North Maple Avenue here.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Dave Beck agreed today to appear before a Senate investigating committee with his personal financial records. He did not say whether he would release the records.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 20 --Youths' rebellion against authority stems from a void in their lives that could be filled by parental guidance in creative activity, the twenty-fifth national Catholic Family Life Convention was told here today.

Airlines operating Viscount turbo-propeller transports out of New York announced yesterday that the examinations of the planes would be completed by today. Full schedules will be resumed tomorrow, they reported.

Stirred by budget cuts that have hampered badly needed improvements in the supply of information about the economy, business men yesterday opened a membership campaign for the Federal Statistics Users' Conference.

LONDON, March 20--Rallies in many of the industrial stocks that were hit hardest on Monday by the strike in the shipbuilding industry lent a more cheerful tone to the stock markets today.
MIAMI BEACH, March 20 (AP) --Don Candy of Australia defeated Mike Green of Miami Beach in the third round of the Good Neighbor tennis championships today, 4--6, 9--7, 6--4.
The New York University Medal, awarded periodically to distinguished individuals, will be presented today to Admiral Ernani do Amaral Peixoto, the Brazilian Ambassador.
Bowerbirds and the elaborate courtship displays they build have inspired a spring exhibition that opens today at the American Museum of Natural History.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda., March 20--President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan expressed hope today that their four-day conference would strengthen United States-British friendship and the free world. The conference opens tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 --Gov. Goodwin J. Knight said today that he had "no record" that the Teamsters Union had contributed to his last election campaign.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 20 --The Constituent Assembly was convoked suddenly today, swore in twenty-five additional Government-appointed members, elected a new chairman and resolved to study a motion to dissolve itself next month.
LONDON, March 20--The defense of Dr. John Bodkin Adams struck hard again today at the reliability of three key prosecution witnesses in his trial for murder.
Ski Sketch: Sverre Engen, former national jumping champion, captured his first ski trophy as a 6-year-old. He won it in a Nordic combined event for grammar school students at Drammen, Norway.

ALBANY, March 20--A Republican agreement on bank holding company legislation was reached today. It provides for continuing the existing "freeze" on bank holding companies in New York until May 1, 1958.

CINCINNATI, March 20-- Only 4 per cent of the nation's physicians are working exclusively on the prime health problem of mental illness, the president-elect of the American Med-' ical Association said here today.

An agreement for the sale of radio station WNEW to the Du Mont Broadcasting Corporation for approximately $7,500,000 was officially announced yesterday. The transaction had been anticipated for several weeks.
MOSCOW, March 20--Premier Janos Kadar led a Hungarian delegation here today for talks with Soviet rulers.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 20 --The police switchboard here was deluged this evening with calls from commuters reporting their automobiles stolen from a parking area near the railroad station.

Ship designers might do well to emulate the automobile industry, which has provided increased visibility in cars, and do the same for ship bridges. The suggestion was made by Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, Atlantic Coast director of the Maritime Administration.
TUNIS, Tunisia, March 20-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon left Tunis tonight by air for Washington after having participated involuntarily in a new crisis in French-Tunisian affairs.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) --The Navy merged its major defensive tasks in the Atlantic area today in one new command and gave it to Vice Admiral Frank Watkins.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 20--The second Festival of Latin-American Music, which began here last night, has to be observed to be believed. It could be brought into being on this scale only by people who combine pioneering spirit with respect for civilized values.

CAIRO, March 20--The outlook for settlement of the Suez Canal and Palestine disputes has never been bleaker than on the eve of Dag Hammarskjold's fourth mission to the Middle East. The United Nations Secretary General will find President Gamal Abdel Nasser inflexibly determined to reject any plan that would weaken Egyptian control over the canal.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20--Don Larsen put his perfect game arm on exhibition today for the first time this spring. But the magic spell that enabled the big right-hander to snuff out twenty-seven Dodgers in a row last October for the first World series no-hitter in history endured for only two batters.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation last year had a record gross operating income of $1,180,101,830, compared with $1,110,066,902 in 1955, P. C. Spencer, president, said in the pamphlet report.
LINDEN, N. J., March. 20-- Three men were killed and eleven injured when an explosion wrecked a steel vat 4 feet wide and 23 feet long in a pharmaceutical plant here early today.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20--The Phillies have twenty-four pitchers in camp, a disproportionately large number. But when the Phils beat the Yankees in twelve innings a week ago, the winning pitcher was Granny Hammer. And when they turned back. the Braves in thirteen innings a few days later, the winning pitcher was Bob Bowman.

Harry Lev, the former cap manufacturer who once told Senate investigators he "deserved a Congressional medal," went on trial in Federal Court yesterday. He is charged with conspiring to defraud the Government on military contracts.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)--Charles E. Whittaker was sworn today as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. He took oaths to support the Constitution and to "administer justice without respect to persons and do equal right to the poor and to the rich."

WASHINGTON, March 25-- President Eisenhower and British Prime Minister Harold MacMillan reached broad agreements in principle at Bermuda, but left open many practical questions of detail and of tactics, diplomatic sources said today.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- Dave Beck apparently reached Washington today and assured a Senate committee that he would appear tomorrow as promised.

The formation of the Keystone Realty Company at 8 West Fortieth Street has been announced by Sidney Freidberg, attorney who is president of the new concern.

The annual soiree of the New York women's division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews will be held in the main ballroom of the Plaza on April 4.

N.B.C. may exercise an option for a second year.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 25--The question of stationing the United Nations Emergency Force on Israel's side of the armistice line is entirely irrelevant at this time, a Foreign Ministry official said tonight.

ALTHOUGH James Brooks, whose recent paintings are exhibited at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, is not a naturalistic painter, his canvases with their coursing rhythms and soaring colors are unmistakable analogues of nature. Alexander Kotov, one of the two Russians in the international chess masters tournament at the Casino in Mar del Plata, Argentina, played to an adjournment in the seventh round with Raul Sanguinetti of Argentina.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25--Twelve qualified experts reminded neutral Sweden today that she had very little chance of staying out of any new world war, whatever the Government and people might prefer.

DETROIT, March 25 (UP)-- Archie Moore, weighing 210 pounds, signed for a June 7 title defense of his light heavyweight championship today. Archie said he would open training with a month in Europe.

"It Happened in the Park," an Italian-French production starring Vittorio De Sica, Micheline Presle and Gerard Philipe, has been acquired by Ellis Films for release this spring. The feature was directed by Gianni Franciolini.

Trading in commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday in most markets here. Prices moved irregularly. Cottonseed oil, coffee, wool and copper rose; potatoes, sugar, hides and rubber declined, and price movements for cocoa were mixed.
The Reisinger Cup knockout team-of-four championship, concluding event of the annual Eastern States regional bridge championships, was narrowed down to four semi-finalist teams last night.
BONN, Germany, March 25-- A piquant footnote to the history of Germany's ancient princely tradition is being written in a Lower Saxony court.

WASHINGTON, March 25--It may be five years or more before the United States will be able to give Britain the 1,500mile ballistics missiles that were discussed at the Bermuda conference. That was the consensus of available sources at the Pentagon and among members of the Armed Services Committee in Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) The United States was told today that its vital interests in Central America and the Caribbean "are in danger of being overlooked" in its concentration on events elsewhere in the world.

TORONTO, March 25 (Canadian Press)--Clarence (Hap) Day, the general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, today ended his thirty-year career with the National Hockey League club.
KANSAS CITY, March 25 (AP)--Gary Thompson, an All-America from Iowa State, ignited the West to a 64-60 upset victory over the East in the annual Shriners' East-West basketball game tonight.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, March 25--A difference between Canadian and British views on the role of the United Nations in international affairs developed today within minutes of the opening of the second half of the Bermuda conference.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., March 25--Just about everybody at Bridgehampton High admired Carl Yastrzemski for his competitive spirit. But they believed the 5-foot 9-inch athlete would never become a good basketball player--much less a recordbreaking one.
Hank Bloomgarden, 29-yearold administrative consultant in medical research, reached the $21,000 prize mark on the television quiz program "TwentyOne" last night.
LONDON, March 25--A lawyer testified under cross-examination today that Dr. John Bodkin Adams was not a beneficiary of the will of Mrs. Edith Alice Morrell at the time of her death Nov. 13, 1950.

TOKYO, March 25 (Reuters) --Japanese shipbuilders have been selling themselves short and face the threat of a depression within three years, a major shipbuilding company said in a report issued here today.

A mediation effort to find a peace formula in the dispute between the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and five unions failed last night. This development led Emanuel Dannett, counsel for the line, to say: "I think a strike looks fairly certain."
BUFFALO, March 26 (AP)-- The Schine theatre interests today were fined a total of $73,000 in Federal District Court in a criminal contempt action that charged violation of a 1949 court order.

Economists are batting around an interesting question these days: Should commercial banks be required to separate savings from checking deposits and invest the savings in mortgages and other long-term securities?
MOSCOW, March 26--The Soviet Union proposed today that nations with nuclear weapons agree to stop testing them at least temporarily.
ALBANY, March 26--The administration of rent controls since Governor Harriman took office came under Republican attack today.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Official advisers to the Department of Agriculture voted without dissent today against any transfer of the department's broad authority over meat packers.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has canceled plans to present a television play titled "The Commentator." The play would have dealt with the question of whether a news commentator and a network should editorialize.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States was considering a project to give "international status" to a new Middle Eastern oil pipeline running from Iraq through Turkey to the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Manpower recommendations to save up to $5,000,000,000 by 1962 were announced today by Ralph J. Cordiner, head of a Defense Department advisory committee.
CERRO CASTILLO, Chile, March 16--The ruddy-cheeked ranch manager picked up a handful of grass and held it up proudly.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the indictment of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, six other corporations and three individuals on charges they illegally conspired to fix sales prices of mirrors produced for installation in furniture.
The city's police force has staged a remarkable comeback but still is a distance from deserving its title of "the finest," an expert on police systems said here last night.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The possibility of Congressional action this session on a tax reduction bill arose today as a byproduct of the current economy drive.
The Appellate Division affirmed yesterday a Supreme Court ban on the practice of law in this state by Lorenzo J. Roel, a Mexican divorce lawyer. He has had a law office here for many years.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) --Gen. Nathan Twining, nominee as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today the "timing" was right for granting statehood to Alaska.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 26-- A collision between an Erie Railroad train and an automobile at River Edge, N.J., caused delays of up to twenty minutes during the morning rush at the ErieLackawanna terminal here today.
A second deep-draft channel for the Port of New York was urged here yesterday by state, city and Port of New York Authority officials.
CONCORD, N.H., March 26 (AP)--The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today that public school teachers did not have the right to strike for higher pay.
WHEREVER the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell moves these days, he jots lit tle notes. He writes on envelopes, on invitations, on cards. He writes in subways, on buses, on his walks.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 26--The flood of immigrants to Israel in 1957 has begun to exceed the original estimates.
Theodore Koch of 48 Westervelt Avenue, St. George, S.I., an architect for more than fifty years, died on Saturday at his home after a brief illness. His age was 72.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Organized labor's high command was called today to an extraordinary session on Friday to consider the case of Dave Beck.

It is with the greatest satisfaction that I and my colleagues of the Soviet Government recall the meetings we had with you and Minister [Arne] Skaug in Moscow over a year ago, when in a friendly and straightforward manner we discussed many questions in connection with mutual relations between the Soviet Union and Norway and exchanged views on international problems in which both parties were interested.
Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that the city would be able to keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn despite "cold war" threats by Walter O'Malley, president of the baseball club, to move to Los Angeles.
Mrs. Albert C. Santy, who has worked on committees for several past events sponsored by the Junior League of New York, has been appointed chairman of the organization's ninth annual Debutante Ball.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --A Japanese economics professor who is a visiting lecturer at Harvard University swore to Senate investigators today he never had been a Communist. But he said he had made some mistakes in his associations as a student here years ago.
Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, a Democrat, and Councilman Robert E. Barnes, a Republican, squared off on the City Council floor yesterday but they never quite came to blows.
ALBANY, March 26--The potential share of state pari-mutuel revenue that the Legislature is readying for the flat track operators was reduced today from $100,000,000 to $40,000,000.
The Reisinger Cup team-offour bridge championship, final event of the Eastern States Regional Championships, was won early this morning by the defending champions.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26--Sources within the Seafarers International Union predicted today that the union's convention would call later this week for the resignation of Joseph Curran of New York from a committee of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market here yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of bonds maturing serially from 1958 to 1977.

Three entertainers who refused to answer questions before the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1955 were indicted here yesterday for contempt of Congress. The committee was then investigating Communist infiltration in the entertainment field in New York.

The American BroadcastingParamount Theatres, Inc., completed its seventh full year in business with a new high income of $206,915,705 in 1956, compared with $198,350,068 in 1955, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP)--Cohansey, owned by the East Acres Farm of Eugene Mori, gained a nose decision in the $11,400 Gulfstream Park Dinner Stakes today.

The twelve-hour endurance race for sports cars at Sebring on the past week-end was international in many respects. While the crowd in the stands and at the various vantage points on the many curves of the 5.2-mile course was almost solidly American, the European type of pit and paddock areas were filled with representatives of eleven nations.
LONDON, March 26--The shipbuilding and engineering strikes continued today despite Government efforts to settle them.
ALBANY, March 26--A Republican bill to raise the pay of state employes by an estimated total of $18,000,000 was approved unanimously in the Assembly today.
Mrs. James V. O'Sullivan of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Mattituck, L.I., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Catherine O'Sullivan, to Edward Julian Brennan Jr. of Towson, Md.

THE Symphony of the Air last night presented "An Evening of French Music for the Theatre" at Carnegie Hall. Robert Lawrence conducted, with Licia Albanese, soprano, and Cesare Valletti, tenor, as soloists.
A visitation millions of years ago in what is now the Grand Canyon is of immediate import to American farmers.
DUBLIN, March 26--Ernie O'Malley, one of the most colorful fighters in the Irish war for independence, died yesterday at Howth, County Dublin. He was 59 years old.
RICHMOND, Va,, March 26-- Virginia's Pupil Placement Law became today the state's new line of defense in school segregation. It was indicated that the line would hold off desegregation for some time.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26--The Dodgers staged their greatest hitting attack of the spring today, teeing off against Harvey Haddix, a stylish southpaw, for seven runs in the third inning, the Brooks went on to beat the Phils, 8--3.
Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen yesterday revoked the citizenship of James J. Matles, a labor leader, on the ground that he had lied about his Communist party affiliation in seeking naturalization.
PARIS, March 26--Edouard Herriot, French statesman, party leader, scholar and author who had become a symbol of the premier Third Republic, died today at the age of 84.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company raised $250,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of bonds due in twenty-eight years. The borrowing cost the company an interest charge of about 4.34 per cent.
A MAN remarked the other day that he found Boeuf A La Mode a strange name for a new restaurant that had appeared in his neighborhood.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 26--Members of the Western Petroleum Refiners Association meeting here today were told by their president, Reid Brazell, that they must speak out to their Representative in Congress on legislation that will affect the oil industry.

PARIS, March 26--In spite of reservations, compromises and blanks yet to be filled in the treaties signed yesterday in Rome for a common European market and a nuclear pool, they may be rated as representing the greatest step yet taken toward European union.
BONN, Germany, March 26-- West Germany's Constitutional Court held today that the Federal Government could not force individual states to comply with educational provisions of a Vatican concordat.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company will "stretch out" expansion plans to counter temporary overcapacity largely responsible for leveling off in its industry, stockholders were told at a meeting yesterday.

Sales of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., last year rose 3.22 per cent to $250,489,010 from $242,680,892 in 1955. But earnings dropped 15 per cent, according to the annual report of J.M. Kennedy, chairman, and C.A. Macfie, president.
A leveling off of prices this year and increased prospects for curbing inflation were envisaged yesterday by Dr. Per Jacobsson, managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

IF "Never So Few,"* an extraordinary first novel about guerrilla warfare behind the Japanese lines in Burma by Tom T. Cha males, had been published ten years ago, it would undoubtedly have caused an immense sensation and have made its author famous. It still may. But today many readers feel that they have had enough of the horror's of...
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26--This is the time of season tension grows in a baseball spring training camp. Especially for the youngster.
When a company goes bankrupt, what happens to the claims of employes who have a stake in its pension fund? The final answer probably will have to come from the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Seymour Peck, a desk man on the Sunday magazine of The New York Times, was convicted today of contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) --Following are excerpts from today's testimony of Dave Beck, president of the Teamsters Union, before the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field.

From 1:30 to 1:55 P.M. yesterday, the stock market made a sharp rally. Then it returned to the lassitude that had marked the first 3 hours on the New York Stock Exchange. The result for the day was a moderate gain in the price average.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 26 --Winthrop Merton Rice, president of Gielow, Inc., naval architects and engineers at 114 Liberty Street, New York, died today in Stamford Hospital after a short illness.

Elmwood Gardens and Elmwood Knolls, two garden apartment developments housing 666 families at The Boulevard and Route 4, in East Paterson, N.J., have been sold by Pamco Associates, Inc., representing Peter A. and Roy Miller.
Newspaper advertising for February and for January and February combined fell behind the 1956 figures.

"Brigadoon," which arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center, will be on hand there only until April 7. Declared the best of its type by the Critics Circle for the 1946-47 term, the Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical was revived at the Center previously in 1950.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 26--There are said to be upwards of 600 artificial ponds of various sizes in Montgomery County for a citizenry that is notably vigorous in the pursuit of black bass and bream. In most of them an angler can fish for a small fee--50 cents to $1.50.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26--While final commitments have yet to be made, it is understood that "Sally," a situationcomedy series created by Frank Ross, the director-producer, will be seen on the National Broadcasting Company network next fall.

LONDON, March 26--Detective Superintendent Herbert Hannam of Scotland Yard, chief investigator in the murder prosecution of Dr. John Bodkin Adams, was portrayed today as an overzealous sleuth who put damaging words in the mouth of his quarry.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The General Electric Company's chief atomic official told Congress today he would have to recommend that his company sharply curtail its private atomic power work if Congress failed to pass insurance legislation this session.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of John Clifford Folger to be Ambassador to Belgium. It acted after questioning him at length about his business holdings and Republican campaign contributions.

With the passing of Edouard Herriot, the world of the living loses another link with that portentous period of the Twenties and the Thirties when Europe was hopefully Struggling to emerge from the chaos of the first World War only to falter and slip back into the cataclysm of the second. It was the era of Poincare and Briand and Blum; it was also the era of Herriot.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- Secretary of State Dulles took a slightly sterner attitude today toward Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of Egypt, but denied any United States-British "agreement" for dealing with him.

West Point Cadet Jerome Lee Gibbons, missing from the Military Academy since March 17, was found yesterday in a sealed freight car in Jersey City. Weakened from hunger, he was returned to the academy where he was placed in the Army Hospital.

With a unanimous vote in the Senate final legislative approval is assured to put before New York voters next fall $250,000,000 in bond issue borrowing power for State University expansion. Thus two separately elected Legislatures have endorsed the need for new construction as advised by the university's trustees and "strongly" urged by the Board of Regents.
Romeyn Berry was one of the most famous figures in intercollegiate athletics in the years following the first World War, when football had its greatest boom and became the autumnal madness.
Held on even terms by the surprisingly skillful Rangers for two periods, the Canadiens of Montreal broke through in the final period to defeat the New Yorkers at Madison Square Garden last night.

NEWARK, March 26--State Senator Wayne Dumont's charge that his rival for the Republican nomination for Governor had accepted campaign support from associates of Joseph Fay, convicted labor racketeer, appeared as a possible political boomerang tonight.

TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, March 26 (AP)--The text of a communique issued today at the conclusion of conferences between Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain and Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada:
MESA, Ariz., March 26--Don Mueller, the fellow they call Mandrake the Magician, because of his uncanny knack of spraying hits, mostly well-placed singles, went for the long ball today.
Hungary is returning letters from this country in protest against an official United States postmark urging support of the Crusade for Freedom.

ROME, March 26--At a time when many indications seemed to show that they were in decline, the Communists did unexpectedly well in the municipal elections held last Sunday and yesterday in the northern city of Cremona. They polled more votes than in the previous elections last May 27.
Cliff Roberts has never forgotten how he and thousands of other spectators were jostled whenever they wanted to watch Bob Jones play golf.
WHITE PLAINS, March 26-- A suit to invalidate a building permit restriction adopted by suburban New Castle went to trial in Supreme Court here today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 26 (AP)--Gov. Goodwin J. Knight was informed today that vital information indicating the approach of war with Japan was withheld for a year before Pearl Harbor by the California State Banking Department.
Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison, president of Lafayette College, Easton, Pa., questioned yesterday the wisdom of educating foreign undergraduate students in this country.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26--Mickey Mantle may find himself plagued with a series of minor mishaps this spring. But The Switcher seems suddenly to have acquired a faculty for making swift recoveries.
AMMAN, Jordan, March 26 (Reuters)--Premier Suleiman Nabulsi said today that the United States had "lifted its mask" by joining the military committee of the Baghdad Pact.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Many Americans abroad feel that United States foreign aid suffers in some areas because "anti-United States or Communist-inspired propaganda spreads an erroneous impression" of America's motives.

LONDON, March 26--Dissatisfaction within the Conservative party over the Government's rent bill was dramatized in the House of Commons tonight when about a dozen Conservatives declined to vote on a controversial clause.

MANAMA, Bahrein, March 26--It is a paradox of this anti-colonial era that if Britain's empire were suddenly to relinquish its appanages in the Persian Gulf, NATO and the free world might collapse. From sun-scorched Bahrein Island London protects an odd batch of sand spits on the fringes of Arabia. There, under the feudal administration of autocratic princes, dwell less than a million Arabs.

NEW MUSIC CONCERTS, which offered two pro grams of contemporary chamber music last season, last night presented the first of the two it is giving this season. It was at the Carl Fischer Concert Hall, and nearly all of the selections were new to New York.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26-- A Quaker committee on civil rights deplored today the "automatic and unthinking assumptions of guilt" on the use of the Fifth Amendment. The amendment protects a witness against self-incrimination.
CAIRO, March 26--Dag Hammarskjold was reported today to have gained some concessions from President Gamal Abdel Nasser on proposals for operation of the Suez Canal.
ALBANY, March 26--A revised savings bank branch bill was submitted to the Legislature today with a strong likelihood of passage.

CHICAGO, March 26--The annual meeting of Fairbanks, Morse Co. will be convened tomorrow morning and proxies held by the management and the dissident group headed by Leopold Silberstein will be given to election judges.

ALBANY, March 26--Governor Harriman approved today legislation extending the state's security risk law another year. The law, first enacted in 1951 during the Korean war, applies to state or local agencies classified by the Civil Service Commission as security agencies. It permits the summary dismissal or suspension of employes of questionable loyalty.
A textile industry spokesman yesterday urged vigilance on the part of American companies to make certain the quota arrangement made with Japan is not bypassed by means of imports from Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The United States and Britain reached a "procedural" agreement in Bermuda for bringing up to date their system of intelligence alerts against Soviet attack. Secretary of State Dulles disclosed today.
SEOUL, Korea, March 26-- President Syngman Rhee today celebrated his eighty-second birthday by adopting a 20-yearold son of an old friend and political associate as his legal heir.

WASHINGTON, March 26--"My cloak of anonymity is now gone," the Air Force Secretary complained when he assumed his post in August, 1955. Until then, as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Research and Development, Donald Aubrey Quarles had served quietly and efficiently behind...
Commodity futures generally advanced here yesterday. Hides registered the best volume of the year and rubber volume improved. But most other markets were dull and featureless.

As the New York Legislature moves into its final days there is one piece of unfinished business that must not be lost. It is legislation to plug the loopholes in compulsory automobile liability insurance and it has been passed unanimously by the Assembly.
GAZA, March 25--The Gaza Strip seems to be as isolated as a South Sea island.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, charged today that the Eisenhower Administration's money and credit policies had failed to check inflationary price increases. He said they opened "a veritable Pandora's box of problems."
SEATTLE, March 26 (AP)-- With the paint hardly dry on his radically new, untested Thriftway Too, Ted Jones is turning to the design of a jetpowered speedboat with a 300miles-per-hour potential.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 26 --A spokesman for the Panama Canal Company said today that "normal measures for safe transit" would apply to the passage of the Soviet freighter Babushkin through the fifty-one-mile waterway.
American Zionists were urged last night to accelerate their efforts in strengthening AmericanIsraeli friendship and to consolidate the spiritual ties between American Jews and the people of Israel.
Mayor Wagner's executive budget for the fiscal year 19571958 is slated to provide salary increases for more than 75,000 of the city's 200,000 employes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26--A temporary injunction to restrain the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences from making a special award for sound effects in the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer movie, "Forbidden Planet," was sought today in Log Angeles Federal Court.
ALBANY, March 26--The heretofore undisputed leadership of Carmine G. De Sapio over the New York City Democratic organization was challenged today.

ALBANY, March 26--Democratic resentment over the Republican decision to abandon the plan to increase the "lulus" of legislators by $1,500 boiled over in the Senate today. A "lulu" is an expense allowance that does not have to be accounted for.

Frank McGuire, the coach of the University of North Carolina's undefeated basketball team, will be honored by the City of New York at the eleventh annual East-West College All-Star game at Madison Square Garden Saturday afternoon.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, March 26--The Bermuda talks ended tonight with the new world and the old in closer harmony than at any time since the British-French intervention in Egypt.

CHICAGO, March 26--A 7.53 per cent increase in net sales and a 3.81 per cent gain in net income in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 established record highs for Sears, Roebuck Co. the annual report to stockholders disclosed today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 26 (AP)--Olympic champions Harold Connolly and Olga Fikotova spent their wedding eve in seclusion with relatives of the bride-to-be in the country tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The eyes got rounder, the face got redder, the voice got louder --and from the spectators' seats, it almost seemed that the man got smaller.

DETROIT, March 26 (UP)-- The Boston Bruins scored in every period tonight to defeat the National Hockey League's champion Detroit Red Wings, 3--1, and take a one-game lead in their semi-final four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup play-offs.
The New York Madrigal Society presented winners of its annual Town Hall Debut Award competition at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. They were Janet Wheeler, soprano, and Wolfgang Granat, violist.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Eisenhower nominated Gen. Nathan F. Twining today for a two-year term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The President also named Donald A. Quarles, Secretary of the Air Force, to be Deputy Secretary of Defense.
PARIS, March 26--Robert Lacoste, the French Minister Residing in Algeria, indicated today that rebel suspects were held in Algiers by the Army for as long as the Government wished.

Frederic E. Schluter, former board chairman and president of the Thermoid Company, received a seven-year suspended sentence yesterday for allegedly juggling financial records. He also was fined $40,000 and placed on probation for five years by Federal Judge Alexander Bicks.
AN exhibition of paintings by competitors for the first biennial Guggenheim International Award will go on view today at the Guggenheim Museum in its temporary quarters, 7 East Seventy-second Street.
CAMERON F. HOPPER lives a double life. From Monday through Thursday he is a secondyear law student at Yale University. Friday through Sunday he is a New York importer of Japanese screens.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- There was something reminiscent in the Senate Caucus Room today of the famous inquisition of the Wall Street titans in the early Nineteen Thirties.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26--Art Ditmar lost more games last season than any other pitcher in the big leagues. twenty-two. But when the Yankees had a chance to get him in a trade from the Kansas City Athletics, they didn't recoil in distaste and say, "Oh, no, not him." They latched on to him with unrestrained eagerness.
OSLO, Norway, March 26-- The Soviet Union has warned Norway she would pay dearly if she allowed her territory to be used as a base against the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Dave Beck refused to tell a Senate committee today about his financial relations with the union he heads.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Following is the record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today, as released by the State Department:
The Police Department regrouped and reinforced its ranks yesterday against what Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy called "the growing lawlessness of the youth of our city."

The winners of the annual Frederik Lunning Prizes have not been resting on their laurels. The awards, two a year --established in 1951 by the late Mr. Lunning, founder of Georg Jensen--were to provide Scandinavian designers of home furnishings with a period of study outside their own countries.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 27 (UP)--The battered old auto that worked so well as a goodluck charm for North Carolina's basketball team was put up for sale today by Pete Brennan.

RADIO Station WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System displayed alertness and initiative yesterday afternoon in doing an extensive live broadcast of the Senate Select Committee's investigation of the Teamsters Union and its president, Dave Beck.

When the tugboat Edgar Bonnet was lifted out of the bottom of the Suez Canal on Monday, thus clearing that waterway for the passage of ships up to 20,000 tons, her bridge bore the strange device "Kilroy Was Here." As nearly as one can figure Kilroy must have gone down to the bottom of the canal in a diver's suit to paint this inscription. But there it was. Kilroy had been there.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 26 (AP) --Fresh hope for state help was held out today for the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad, under Federal Court order to cease operations on Friday at midnight.
ST. LOUIS, March 26--Mental patients should be freely admitted to and treated in general hospitals, a psychiatrist said today.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., March 26 (AP)--The toll of damage and death left across the snow-choked Great Plains by a three-day spring blizzard over the weekend mounted today as the storm moved eastward with diminished force.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Ira Elbert Bennett, writer and former editor in chief of The Washington Post, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 88 years old.
LONDON, March 26--The British Foreign Office made public today its latest reply to Japan's appeals that forthcoming British hydrogen bomb tests at Christmas Island in the Pacific Ocean be suspended.
Sixty-five ancient Greek vases have been put on special exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They are the fruits of a recent purchase after years of negotiation.
LONDON, March 26--Stock market prices, depressed at the outset today by continuance of the shipyard and engineering strikes, later recovered part of their losses.

Although the United Nations disarmament talks proceed in London on a note of cautious Western optimism the real Soviet attitude toward armament limitation and control is demonstrated again by the Soviet response to the Bermuda conference proposal for the limitation, notification and observation of hydrogen bomb tests.
ALBANY, March 27 (AP)--Governor Harriman said today he had freed from lifetime parole restrictions a convicted murderer who had received a church pastorate while studying for the ministry.
George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, was charged yesterday with a "continuing lack of understanding of the basic issues involved" in the dispute between two seamen's unions.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27 --Col. Arthur E. Fox, U.S.A. retired, since 1945 assistant to Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, died today in Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.
TORONTO, Ont., March 27--Spokesmen for several of Canada's leading uranium producers today criticized the arrangement by which $115,000,000 of concentrates of the atomic metal...
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 27--Things are tough all over. It was noted the other day after a New York concert that composers rarely had any fun anymore.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday the election of Otto N. Frenzel as a director, effective April 16. Mr. Frenzel is president of the Merchants National Bank of Indianapolis and is active in civic affairs of his city and state.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, retired, now president of the Free Europe Committee, Inc., declared yesterday that his group had never encouraged "bloody uprisings" nor "promised military aid" to rebel forces in the Communist satellite nations of Europe.

LONDON, March 27--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan returned today to London from Bermuda. He expressed satisfaction over his talks with President Eisenhower and Louis St. Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada.

Ski Sketch: Otto Schniebs, referred to by many as "The Father of American Skiing," is retiring from coaching at St. Lawrence University. He has been teaching the sport for thirty year's, and now, at 65, feels it's time to take it easy.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) --The Communist party organized a steering committee in 1946 to influence the policies of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, the Subversive Activities Control Board was told today.
NEWARK, March 27--State Senators Malcolm S. Forbes and Wayne Dumont Jr. centered their campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor today here in Essex, the state's most populous county.
Carmine G. De Sapio predicted last night that the Democrats would win the 1960 Presidential election by adhering to the liberal tradition of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman.
The six-story apartment house on plot 100 by 125 feet at 3505 Bruckner Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by Louis Sperling to Morris A. Adler, Maurice Eppinger and Robert E. and Albert M. Weiss.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 27--As an angler, hunter and farmer, J. Ed Livingston collects fishing and hunting stories as other men collect game trophies or hotel ashtrays. As Chief Justice of Alabama's Supreme Court, he collects legal fishing and hunting stories.

Commodity futures trading was dull but prices generally rose in New York markets yesterday. Potatoes, cocoa, copper, rubber and soybean oil advanced, coffee declined, and price movements for sugar, cottonseed oil, wool and hides were mixed.
CAIRO, March 27--President Gamai Abdel Nasser was reported today to have made a "gentleman's agreement" to do nothing that would upset the present calm in the Gaza Strip and on the Gulf of Aqaba.
Philip Morris, Inc., manufacturer of cigarettes, announced yesterday it was planning to acquire Milprint, Inc., a leader in the flexible packaging field.

KANSAS CITY, March 27 (AP) --Willie Vaughn of Hollywood, Calif., gained a split decision over Joey Giardello, a 5-to-1 favorite, in a ten-round nationally televised bout before 4,500 fans tonight. Vaughn weighed 160 pounds and Giardello 159 .

CHICAGO, March 27--Relief of the corn surplus problem through development of potential new markets for starch and other corn products was advocated today by Floyd J. Hosking, executive vice president of...

Miss Mary Alice Currier, who had been director of the food services at Barnard College for the last eight years, died in her sleep yesterday morning in her apartment in Brooks Hall on the Barnard campus. Her age was 60.
WASHINGTON, March 27--A Senate committee piled new accusations of "theft" on Dave Beck today.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The President, again reminding his news conference today that he is not a lawyer, made one of those capsule comments on the law that demonstrate his common-sense understanding of its fundamentals.
Mr. and Mrs. Karl Pierce Herzer of 993 Park Avenue have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Pierce Herrer, to Second Lieut. Richard Nason of the Army Transportation Corps.

Consolidated net earnings of the Gillette Company are estimated at $6,750,000, or 73 cents a share, for the first quarter this year, Carl J. Gilbert, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.
ROME, March 27--Italy is bidding for a substantial share in the oil of Iran. The move has stirred up international and domestic controversies.
MANILA, March 27--An outbreak of Hukbalahap terrorism in outlying areas caused President Carlos P. Garcia to order a renewed "policy of force" against Communist guerrillas today.

The New York Communist party state committee said yesterday that Harry Schwartz of The New York Times staff had used "deliberate and malicious falsehoods" in describing discord within the Communist party.

As the final cultural dividend of the season, the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy gave a concert reading yesterday of "Candida" at the Theatre de Lys.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 28 (UP)--President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla decreed today the creation of a new National Constituent Assembly of ninety delegates, thirty of whom will be named by the President.

CHICAGO, March 28--Grain futures prices generally declined today on the Board of Trade after opening with mostly small gains. Wheat, corn and soybeans showed the largest declines while oats and rye held relatively firm.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28--There always are complaints to be noted and examined after the Academy Awards. Last night's presentation ceremony was no exception.
AINTREE, England, March 28 (AP)--The odds against Goosander's winning tomorrow's Grand National Steeplechase shortened sensationally to 9-2 as a wave of "mystery money" flooded the market tonight.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., March 28 --Dr. Elwell F. Kimball, Dean Emeritus of Fairleigh Dickinson University, Rutherford and Teaneck, died here yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, 71 Andover Terrace. His age was 84.
The combination of high intelligence and humor is an irresistible one not always found among educators. It had capti-...
PARIS, Friday, March 29-- Premier Guy Mollet's Government won a precarious victory in the National Assembly early today.
Connecticut has set April 2 for the sale of its next issue of bonds to further the construction of the Greenwich-Killingly expressway.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) --Jefferson Caffery, a career diplomat, urged tonight that the United States help maintain the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's "maximum retaliatory strength."
The addition of a second size for a product usually produces additional sales to consumers for whom the original size was not convenient or economical. Here's a report on what more it can do.
With the mid-March bulge in demand for money to meet Federal tax payments past, the Federal Reserve System began withdrawing funds from the credit stream again last week.

The head of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York asserted yesterday that increased financial support from city and state governments was urgently needed to reduce the waiting lists at voluntary medical and social service agencies.

The Government of Egypt are pleased to announce that the Suez Canal will be open for normal traffic by mid-April, and will thus once again serve as a link between the nations of the world in the cause of peace and prosperity.
CHICAGO, March 28--The toll of prolonged illness is heavy. Yet the facts about it "leave no doubt that action can be taken to meet the problem."

Two hundred students representing eighteen Eastern colleges and universities will participate in an undergraduate drama festival at Yale University. The festival starts tonight at 8 o'clock and ends Sunday.
LONDON, March 28--Industrial shares turned dull today, although losses in most cases were in pennies.
Investors have lost $16,000,000 in the last month in the purchase of fraudulent securities, United States Attorney Paul W. Williams told the Federal Bar Association yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28-- Spoilers, that's what the Baltimore Orioles figure to be in the American League this year and that's what they were today.

The New York Telephone Company continued to show gains in gross revenues and net income for the first two months of this year. Gross revenues totaled $142,256,277, against $132,014,939 a year earlier. Net income was $14,713,223, against $13,067,306.

Representatives of the major teacher groups in New York said yesterday they were "stunned" by the salary increases proposed in the Mayor's budget. There were warnings that the teachers were near revolt.
BIG and active striped bass have moved into the Connecticut surf unaccountably early. Shore fishermen have been scoring heavily for several days.
LOS ANGELES, March 28--Dr. Henry Raup Wagner, noted bibliographer and authority on early explorations of the West, died today at his suburban San Marino home at the age of 94.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., March 28 (UP)--A general court-martial was ordered today for a Mairine Corps lieutenant from New York who allegedly attacked a private with his fists.

A Broadway haven is being sought for the transfer of "Brigadoon," which opened Wednesday night at the City Center. The revival of the Alan Jay LernerFrederick Loewe musical, which was enthusiastically received despite a rehearsal period of only two week, must close April 7 after a fortnight's stand.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 28 (UP) --The American League player representative, Eddie Yost, disclosed today that major league players were "cooperating with the owners to decide whether we should back the reserve clause" when organized baseball defends itself before Congress.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28--The American Broadcasting Company has added still another filmed series to its burgeoning fall schedule.
Dave Beck, in absentia, will be his own chief accuser today before the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP)--President Eisenhower's civil rights bill ran into a snag today.

The resolution of the United Nations calling for a resumption of negotiations for a peaceful democratic and just solution of the Cyprus problem in accordance with the principles of the United Natibns Charter is a starting point toward a final settlement of the issue.
The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for a midApril start on the $20,000,000 Lenox Terrace middle-income housing project in Harlem.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 28--When Frank Lary was pitching for Buffalo under Jack Tighe in 1953, he selwed up a knuckleball pitch to an enemy batter. The batter promptly hit it out of sight.
FORT WORTH, March 28 (UP) --Dick Weber of the St. Louis Budweisers took first place in the all-events at the American Bowling Congress tournament today with 1,992.
A City Court judge ruled yesterday that a restaurant patron could collect $3,000 in damages for a broken tooth even though someone else had paid the diner's check.
A top union leader said yesterday that Dave Beck, in his concern about not incriminating himself before a Senate investigating committee, did not "mind incriminating the labor movement."
A man and a woman with marginal vision read printed matter yesterday with the aid of special lens inserts fitted into ordinary eyeglasses.

Scheduled airlines flying the North Atlantic have requested permission to increase trans-Atlantic passenger fares by 5 per cent beginning May 1.
James T. Ryan, a former patrolman, was arrested by the police in Queens yesterday after he had been described by District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor as "the mastermind of a band of criminals."

New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service has instituted a training and research program for correction personnel. The City Department of Correction is cooperating in the undertaking.

LONDON, March 28--A medical expert maintained today that Dr. John Bodkin Adams had used narcotics with murderous intent on an aged widow but he also conceded, paradoxically, that withdrawal of the drugs would have been fatal.
New York savings bankers voiced strong opposition yesterday to a bill passed Wednesday by the Legislature. The measure would set a ceiling on savings bank dividends.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased to 88.7 on Wednesday from 88.6 on Tuesday. The figure for March 28, 1956. was 90.3.
MOSCOW, March 28 (AP)--Premier Janos Kadar of Hungary signed two agreements tonight binding Hungary to the Soviet Union even more closely than before without any promise of Soviet withdrawal.
ALBANY, March 28--When Joseph Zaretzki first ran for the State Senate in 1947, he viewed the upper house of the Legislature as a chamber remote, austere and at all costs dignified.

The United States Committee for German Corporate Dollar bonds gave approval yesterday to an offer of settlement covering four issues of defaulted prewar bonds of the German Central Bank for Agriculture (Deutsche Rentenbank-Kreditanstalt).

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The memorandun sent by Egypt to the United States on the Suez Canal proposes that it "be operated and managed by the autonomous Suez Canal Authority" established by the Egyptian Government July 26, 1956.
CHICAGO, March 28--The Penn-Texas Corporation claimed victory today in its proxy fight for control of Fairbanks, Morse Co.
Plastics will provide the nation with new construction materials as resources of natural materials become depleted, a group of plastic suppliers and fabricators was told yesterday.

ALBANY, March 28--A bill authorizing savings banks to open limited branches was approved tonight by the Assembly Rules Committee. It thus will be on the calendar of the lower house tomorrow, ready for a vote.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The United States Savings and Loan League unveiled a plan today to "expand home ownership, bolster the home building industry and enlarge the usefulness of the savings and loan business."

WASHINGTON, March 28--Senatorial labor racket hunters, their staff trebled in recent weeks, are running down scores of valuable tips, a spokesman said today. Among them at a few more leads pointing to Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, his friends and some employers.

After six days of "informal and exploratory" talks with President Nasser, Secretary General Hammarskjold has returned to United Nations headquarters with Nasser's terms for a "settlement" of the Middle Eastern problems.
A subscription season of special events has been planned for the fiftieth Anniversary Drive of the Girls Service League.
ALBANY, March 28--With a view of winding up the 1957 session of the Legislature on Saturday, the Senate and Assembly plowed through heavy calendars today, disposing of more than 200 bills.
TOKYO, Friday, March 29 (AP) --Communist China announced the release yesterday of another of the United States civilians jailed during the Korean war on spy charges.
CAIRO, March 28--Egypt probably will agree to impose surcharges on Suez Canal tolls so the United Nations can repay more than $15,000,000 advanced for clearance of the canal.
The Navy is marshaling its forces for another summer dash into the chill waters of the Arctic to supply bases maintaining the northern radar warning network.

The British Government took a positive step toward ultimate solution of the Cyprus problem yesterday by releasing , Archbishop Makarios from his island exile following his appeal to the Cypriote underground for a "cessation of all operations."

TRENTON, March 28--A three-story semi-detached house collapsed here today five minutes after its occupants had fled. The side wall of the building toppled into an excavation on adjoining property. The police arrived at 11:25 A.M., just before the structure fell, and roped off the area.

Miss Elizabeth Higgins Zuill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cummings Vail Zuill of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, was married there yesterday to Theodore Whaley Cart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Cart of Harbourton, N.J., and Warwick, Bermuda.
The burning question of "museum feet" has been brought out into the open at the American Museum of Natural History.

ATHENS, March 28--Premier Constantine Karamanlis called the British offer to release Makarios from exile "a decisive step" toward solution of the Cyprus question. Mr. Karamanlis issued a statement tonight following a three-hour Cabinet meeting.

Robert Moses, Commissioners of Parks, thinks a zoo for Queens would be a good idea, but he does not see how the borough can get one unless there is a depression or somebody contributes the necessary funds.
ALBANY, March 28--The bipartisan deal to give the State Commission Against Discrimination power to issue industry-wide orders exploded today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28--Sweden's free press strongly countered today the "Soviet scare offensive" in Scandinavia.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 28--Mayor Terry Schrunk of Portland and District Attorney William Langley were arrested tonight on indictments returned by the Multnomah County Grand Jury.
Andy Hebenton made a hero of himself to the followers of the New York Rangers last night.
KANSAS CITY, March 28 (AP) --For the performance record about all Joey Giardello and Willie Vaughn got out of the nationally televised fight last night Were ten rounds of experience.

A five-story building containing fifty apartments and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1380-86 Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Delta Investors Corporation, David B. Solove, president. Aaron Steinberg was the seller.
Two developments that may have far-reaching, effects on the lagging textile industry were announced here yesterday by the Amerotron Corporation, a division of Textron, Inc.

MOSCOW, March 28--A Soviet statement warned France and Israel today that a new attack on Egypt "would create the direct threat of a broad military conflict, with heavy consequences for the cause of peace."

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (AP)--The Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Philadelphia Phillies by 5-2 today on the strength of southpaw Joe Nuxhall's routegoing four-hit pitching performance.

CHICAGO, March 28--Dr. Charles H. Phifer, Professor of Surgery at the University of Illinois for forty years and a past president of the Chicago and Illinois Medical Societies, died yesterday at Illinois Research Hospital. He was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Administration took two steps today to bolster the faltering home building industry.

The backlog of new corporate financing declined slightly during the last week, but offerings are continuing to come to market at a lively pace.

Miguel Najdorf of Argentina gained sole possession of first place last night in the international masters' tournament at Mar Del Plata, Argentina, according to a report received through South American news sources.

ALBANY, March 29--The Harriman Administration today endorsed a proposal to increase the membership of the state Harness Racing Commission from one to three.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday "I just don't give a damn" about strained relations between him and President Eisenhower.
The piano recital of Frederick Marvin last night in Town Hall was a brilliant one on two counts.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 29--A plan for building a mined fence along the entire border of the Gaza Strip has again been suggested by the United Nations.
LONDON, March 29--Joyce Cary, novelist, essayist, poet and former painter, died today at his home in Oxford after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --The Americans for Democratic Action opened their tenth birthday convention today by attacking a "leadership coalition of conservative Republicans and Southern Democrats."
A FEW French and Italian restaurants here follow the European custom of not serving water at the table when wine is ordered. Is that proper?
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 29--Sir Anthony Eden will leave New Zealand, probably about the end of April, and proceed to Boston for a medical examination.

Barry Enright, the producing company whose "TwentyOne" quiz show has helped to boost the National Broadcasting Company's television ratings this season, will add another of its shows to the network's evening schedule starting in September.
ALBANY, March 29--The question of approach routes for the proposed Narrows and Throgs Neck Bridges in New York City was suddenly reopened tonight on the eve of the Legislature's adjournment.
The Japanese all-star wrestling team defeated a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union squad, 7 to 2, last night at the New York Athletic Club gymnasium.
NOW that the beastly weather is about to subside, Shop Talk makes the rounds of the beauty spots.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29--Jawaharlal Nehru was elected today leader of the Congress party in India's Parliament. He thus becomes Prime Minister for another five years.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)-- Two steamship concerns were accused today of applying for surplus freighters "in bad faith" to block out competition for Great Lakes shipping business.
ALBANY, March 29--Legislation to permit savings banks to open additional branches in the suburbs was defeated today by the Assembly.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Labor's high command suspended Dave Beck from two key posts today and started an investigation of his International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

LONDON, March 28--The Marquess of Salisbury, one of the most influential men in the British Government, resigned today from the Cabinet in a disagreement over the release from detention of Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus.
AINTREE, England, March 29 --Sundew, a 20-to-1 shot won the grueling Grand National Steeplechase race today after severely shaking the nerves of his backers.

MAHE, Seychelles Islands, March 29 (AP)--Archbishop Makarios, religious and political leader of the Greek Cypriotes, balked today at entering any negotiations with Britain until he was allowed to return to Cyprus.

Chiefly as a result of the largest public utility bond financing since October, 1945, new bonds offered publicly here in March rose to $1,539,657,000, for 211 issues from $1,313,899,000 for 223 issues in February. The total compared with $894,673,000 for 169 issues in March, 1956.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) --Oklahoma's Dan Hodge and Gene Roesler, and Pitt's Ed Peery--all three defending champions--reached the semifinals of the National Collegiate wrestling championships tonight.

Prompt enlargement of the police force of the New York City Housing Authority to give adequate protection to the agency's tenants and property was recommended yesterday by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Agriculture Department unlimbered its spray guns today. It aims to wipe out the voracious gypsy moth from nearly 3,000,000 acres of forest land in parts of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
OTTAWA, March 28--An extensive rush into the sub-arctic barren land in northern Quebec in search of mineral riches will get under way within the next few weeks.
ALBANY, March 29--The Legislature completed passage today of a bill regulating all sales on the installment payment plan.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, March 29--This is the time of year when the people of Srinagar sit cracking nuts in the blossoming pink orchards, wait for the tourists and listen to the politicians.

Representatives of opera-producing organizations from twenty-four states and the District of Columbia gathered yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel for the opening of a two-day conference under the auspices of the Central Opera Service.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --Col. Charles Ross Greening, U.S.A.F., a survivor of the Doolittle raid on Tokyo during World War II, died today at the Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 42 years old.
The bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway was laid to rest last evening.

LONDON, March 29--The stock markets finished the week on a dull note because of the breakdown of negotiations in labor disputes. Government funds had losses ranging up to 7s 6d ($1.05) on the 100 unit.

OSLO, Norway, March 29 (AP) A powerful Soviet military machine close to the northern flank of the North Atlantic alliance is supported by recently built-up industrial areas, authoritative Norwegian sources said today.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29 (AP)--Robin Roberts gave a three-run home run to Sherman Lollar of the Chicago White Sox today but bore down to gain a 5-4 victory for the Philadelphia Phillies. Robin faced only eighteen men in the last five inning's.

A nine-run outburst in the fifth inning enabled Fairleigh Dickinson's baseball team to post a 9-6 victory over New York University at Ohio Field yesterday. The Knights rallied from six runs behind to record their second triumph in as many days.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- A pet Congressional project-- Federal aid for rural libraries-- threw the economy drive for a temporary loss today in the House of Representatives.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29--Jess Oppenheimer, creative programing executive for the National Broadcasting Company, has found his "Baby Snooks" in the person of Martha Raye.
ALBANY, March 29--The Legislature approved today a twoyear extension, until June 30, 1959, of residential rent controls.
Stocks opened a little higher yesterday, held steady for the first hour, slid in the second hour and then held for the remainder of the New York Stock Exchange session.

Nine months of hearings by the Department of Agriculture ended yesterday on whether farmers' milk prices in metropolitan New York, northern New Jersey and some of upstate. New York should be regulated by the Federal Government.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 28--Britain is preparing a tethered constitutional experiment in the uneasy political atmosphere of Tanganyika.
The long-range future of cancer treatment lies with the development of chemicals for the regulation and control of cancerous growth, a British scientist suggested yesterday.
ALBANY, March 29--Roger W. Straus of New York was elected today as Chancellor of the Board of Regents, governing body of education in the state.

All his life Christopher Morley had a severe case of bibliomania. His death inspires a sense of personal loss in the hearts of thousands of others who loved books, too, among them many of Mr. Morley's.
The perennial question of whether Latin America is being neglected or not by the American Government came up again in Secretary Dulles' latest press conference. Mr. Dulles,
MANILA, March 29--President Carlos P. Garcia rejected today the Japanese wartime slogan "Asia for the Asians" as an element of Philippine foreign policy.
Spring will move inside the Coliseum tomorrow for the opening of the New York International Flower Show.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --The Army cut sharply today the length of time that Reservists must continue military training and be ready for immediate calls to active duty.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) --A Government accountant told incredulous members of Congress today that it sometimes was easier for a company to make $5,000,000 on a Federal contract than to get the Air Force to accept a refund.

RABAT, Morocco, March 29-- Henri Pierre Perrin, a French army lieutenant, was returned unharmed today to French authorities here, after having been held captive for nearly six months by irregular troops in southwest Morocco.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Harriman today signed a bill giving New York City a $9,600,000 share of the state's motor vehicle fees.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 29 (AP)--Yale's Tim Jecko and Rex Aubrey staged a couple of come-from-behind performances to win the last two events on the program and give Yale a slender lead over Michigan in the team race at the thirtyfourth National Collegiate swimming championships tonight.

SNOW BASIN, Utah, March 29 (UP)--Mack Miller of Western State skimmed over the ninemile cross-country course today in 55 minutes, 54.4 seconds to capture the first title in the National Collegiate ski champion ships.

Last night at the Metropolitan Opera was something special. The opera was Verdi's "Don Carlo," which played to a soldout house. Antonietta Stella sang her first Elizabeth at the house, and did it beautifully. The other singers were in grand voice.

Cocoa futures climbed sharply yesterday in the fourth busiest day of the year on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by a tight supply of actuals for immediate delivery and increased interest in cocoa beans.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- James R. Hoffa, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to an indictment charging violation of the bribery statutes.
ALTHOUGH General Sherman knew war was hell, he did not run from a nomina tion to fight in it and he served his country well as a soldier. Honest regional opinions notwithstanding.

BOWIE, Md., March 29 (UP)-- Mrs. Jan Burke's Dedicate, a three-time stakes winner last year, headed a field of ten entered today for tomorrow's running of the $100,000 added John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--If, perchance, the Dodgers meet the Yankees in another world series next fall, by that time they may have learned how to lay restraining hands on Yogi Berra. But they haven't acquired the knack yet.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 29--President Sukarno made a whistle-stop tour of West Java today in a special train. He spoke three times.
Three Broadway projects have fallen by the wayside for reasons ranging from lack of interest to casting difficulties.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 29--Back home the Cactus League championship may not carry much weight. But here in the desert country it's a big deal --big enough to make the four Arizona-based major league clubs strive for the title. So the Giants took special pride today in defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 4--2, and clinching the trophy.
Janos Kadar, the Soviet-imposed puppet Premier of Hungary, has sold out his country for the second time by signing two agreements in Moscow which further tighten Soviet control of it.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today farm product prices increased 1 per cent between mid-February and midMarch. This upturn partly offset a 2 per cent decline in the previous month.
ALBANY, March 29--A proposal to bar labor union picketing for organizational purposes was withdrawn today by its sponsor in the Senate.
New York's "mad bomber," George P. Metesky, yesterday was directed to go to trial by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen.
IN the campaign of 1912 Theodore Roosevelt's con vention office boy was a young Princeton University student and family friend named Roger Williams Straus.
LONDON, March 29--Representatives of Britain and Singapore have agreed on a new constitution for Singapore.
The Very Rev. John B. Harney, former Superior General of the Paulist Fathers, died yesterday in the Mother House of the order, 415 West Fifty-ninth Street, after a, long illness. His age was 81.

ALBANY, March 29 (AP)--Governor Harriman accused Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today of "utter disregard" for dairy farmers' needs in refusing their request to freeze the fluid-milk price at the March level.
ALBANY, March 29--Court reform is facing defeat in the Assembly because of uprisings against the Republican and Democratic leaderships.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 29--President Eisenhower's speeding motorcade was intercepted by the police in Maryland today.
CHICAGO, March 29--May wheat rose sharply today on the Board of Trade. This future moved up on backspreading between it and new-crop futures. At one time it sold at 8 cents above the July option.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold proposed today a five-year plan for United Nations aid to community development projects.
NEW HAVEN, March 29-- The study of communism is a major responsibility of the American secondary school, Dr. George S. Counts told a teachers' group today at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Eisenhower recommended today that the Constitution be amended to permit the Cabinet to determine when the Vice President should assume the duties of a disabled President.

WASHINGTON, March 29--A Baltimore news correspondent who visited Communist China in defiance of a United States ban, testified today that the State Department had put pressure on his editor to order him home.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 30 --Nikita S. Khrushchev made public today the blueprints of a sweeping overhaul of the Soviet Union's industrial organization. Government agencies concerned with production were included.

THE exhibition of Alfred Russell's most recent pic tures at the Duveen-Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, is bound to surprise those who remember his abstract work. For he has become a painter of the female nude in the most traditional sense, making specific reference to the scenes of writhing, posturing bathers by Ingres.

Isaac Logart of Camaguey, Cuba, still is Gil Turner's master in the ring. At Madison Square Garden last night the Cuban scored his second consecutive triumph over the Philadelphian in a ten-round welterweight bout.
The 1,500,000 Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York will be asked, beginning tomorrow, to contribute to the thirtyeighth annual fund-raising appeal of New York Catholic Charities.
CHINA LAKE, Calif., March 29 (AP)--The Navy announced today a new rocket-propelled missile named Zuni, and said the $150 weapon can overtake a jet plane.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) --Senator Henry C. Dworshak suggested today that the United States Information Agency rely more on established private wire services.

LONDON, March 29--The judge in the trial of Dr. John Bodkins Adams tried to clarify "certain divergencies" and apparent contradictions in the "design of murder" outlined by a prosecution medical expert.

OPPOSITION to and resentment against new restric tions on the ownership and use of firearms are growing into a national swell, especially among hunters. Fresh restrictive proposals are offered in many state legislatures every year.
The intelligence quotient of pupils entering New York City's vocational schools has reached its lowest point thus far.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Justice Department and Maritime Board officials assured a Congressional committee today that they regarded the 1955 ships settlement with Aristotle Onassis a good one.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29--The American public spent more money on motion-picture entertainment during 1956 than in any of the preceding three years.

MONTREAL, March 29 (UP)--Coach Phil Watson today led his upset-minded New York Rangers into Montreal, where they faced the almost impossible task of beating the Canadiens three times here in order to advance to the final of the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs.
Final approval of a new twoyear contract for deck scow captains was announced yesterday. The agreement, effective Monday, raises all wages about 15 per cent.

JUFAIR, Bahrein, March 29--"Her Majesty's Ship" Jufair is actually a sandy peninsula on the eastern shore of Bahrein. British naval custom gives this spit a seagoing label. And, in fact, its importance far transcends the territory of this little island.
WILMINGTON, N.C., March 29 (UP)--Dow Finsterwald of Jupiter, Fla., cut two strokes off par today and led by one stroke at the halfway point of the $12,500 Azalea open golf tournament.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 29 (AP)--The smallest but what is generally considered the best field ever to compete in the Florida Derby was named today for the $100,000 added mile and an eighth feature at Gulfstream Park tomorrow.

Twenty-four organizations, including the state's leading civil rights groups, appealed to Governor Harriman yesterday to veto a Republican-sponsored measure that would create a civil rights bureau in the State Attorney General's office.

The largest loss in terms of points for any first quarter since 1926 was suffered by The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks in the last three months. As March bowed out, the average stood at 316.06, a dip of 19.33 points.
LONDON, Saturday, March 30 --Iain Macleod, Minister of Labor, appealed today to the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions to call off its strike in the engineering industry.

PARIS, March 29--The Foreign Ministry denied today an assertion by two French journalists that Premier Guy Mollet and Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel, had met secretly in France in October to concert their attack on Egypt.

In the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary yesterday afternoon, Miss Florance Parmelee Lamont was married to Ralph Lauder Antonides. The Rev. Stewart Meacham performed the Methodist ceremony.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --A Hungarian refugee told Senate investigators today that in ten years spent in Soviet prison camps he had seen men and women political prisoners herded and living like animals.
