A ranking union leader called yesterday for machinery to permit the merged labor federation to remove corrupt officials of international unions without throwing out the entire union.
ALBANY, April 1--A State Tax Department ruling will give most persons who were ill during the last year substantial relief on their state income taxes this year.

The After Dinner Opera Company, a troupe of sev en young Americans who took its portable productions to the Edinburgh Festival last fall, and then toured on the Continent, last night gave its first bill here since its return.

In a special six-page section this newspaper presents today a detailed and authoritative report on the turbulent Middle East. Like the Balkans of a past era, the Middle East has become a powder keg that could explode into a new world war.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1-Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies announced today that the Government had decided to permit additional imports valued at 75,000,000 (Australian) ($166,000,000) a year, thus raising the ceiling for imports in the financial year beginning July 1 to 775,000,000 ($1,735,000,000).
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)Senator John L. McClellan said today that two witnesses for civil rights legislation had been accused of lying under oath.

THE vast oil resources of the Middle East are at stake in the diplomatic negotiations now going on in many capitals. Developed over the last fifty years, these known resources are estimated at two-thirds of the world's total.
WASHINGTON, April 1--A Supreme Court today blunted the "whipsaw," a tool sometimes used by a union when it is bargaining with more than one employer for a common contract.
Local government housing authoirities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are planning to borrow $90,643,000 in the public market next week.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP)-The Kansas City Athletics and the Pittsburgh Pirates engaged in the longest scoreless duel of the exhibition baseball season today-eighteen innings. The game was called by agreement at the end of the eighteenth.

The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had purchased a seven-story building at 125 West End Avenue from the Chrysler New York Company, Inc. The property runs from Sixty-fifth to Sixty-sixth Street on the west side of the avenue.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- Vast sections of the Middle East are desert. Water could make them bloom and ease the poverty of millions.

BUENOS AIRES, April 1Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu faced a "pasgive rebellion" by the Air Force today. The President was unable to find a candidate to take over command of the Air Ministry.
WASHINGTON, April 1--Public power advocates lost in the Supreme Court today their legal fight to keep private enterprise from developing the hydroelectric resources of Hell's Canyon.

CHICAGO, April 1--Further rainfall in the Southwest and through the main winter wheat belt caused free selling of newcrop wheat months today on the Board of Trade. The September and December futures set lows for the crop season to date.

Beatrice Lillie, star of "The Ziegfeld Follies," and dancer Ray Bolger will join stars of French films, stage and opera as entertainers at the "April in Paris Ball" on April 11 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

WASHINGTON, April 1--The Eisenhower Administration considers the Vice President himself to be the sole judge at present as to when he should succeed lawfully to the powers of a disabled President.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United State's announced yesterday that James F. Oates Jr., former chairman of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, Chicago, had been named chief executive officer of the insurance company.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1-Carl Erskine, the hero of two world series games and a spinner of two no-hitters, may have reached the end of the baseball trail.
Sales of New York City's major department stores were considerably lower in March than they were a year earlier, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

THE voice of the turtle is being drowned out this week by the sound of spring cleaning. While housewives beat rugs, re-paper drawers and throw blankets into the washing machine, New York stores have been equally embroiled with spring projects.

AMMAN, Jordan--The problem of Jordan is whether to continue independent existence.
Willi Besmanoff, a German heavyweight, took a long stride in his bid for recognition in the division by winning a unanimous decision over Bob Baker of Pittsburgh at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The Administration declined to give assurances today that the granting of statehood to Hawaii would reduce the danger of Communist infiltration in the islands.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon joined with many other persons today in paying tribute to the late Richard W. Slocum.
The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation has an order backlog of $586,000,000, up from $530,000,000 at the start of the year, Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.
YONKERS, April 1-Despite threatening skies, a crowd of 26,536 turned out at Yonkers Raceway tonight for the start of the metropolitan harness racing season.

PARIS, Apiril 1 (AP)-Undefeated Alphonse Halimi of France tonight wrested the world bantamweight championship from Italy's Mario D'Agata, a 30-year-old deaf-mute.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 1The Yankees, swinging into their final week of exhibition campaigning in the Grapefruit Belt, ran into a squall today that not even Casey Stengel could circumvent.

A PROLIFIC artist, Byron Browne, whose current work is on view at the Grand Central Moderns Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, has been able to produce an exhibition each year fox the last decade. This year, in addition to the abstractions and semi-abstractions in oil, Browne shows seven sculptures in terra cotta and metal.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1-- King Hussein of Jordan was reported today to be prepartng a showdown with leftist elements over the question of the Eisenhower Doctrine for aid to and defense of the Middle East.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 1-In a move that surprised no one, the Giants today promoted Andre Rodgers, the precocious shortstop from the Bahamas, to the roster of the New York club.
Three men and a woman were arrested yesterday on usury indictments that grew out of an investigation of loan shark activities on the Hudson River waterfront.
PARIS, Ky., April 1 (AP)-- Arthur B. Hancock Sr., for years one of the nation's best-known horse breeders, died today after a long illness. His age was 81

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, said today he might have to end Saturday mail deliveries and postal money order services if Congress did not restore a $58,000,000 House-approved cut in the postal budget.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- Robert C. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Affairs, will become Ambassador to Mexico, Congressional sources disclosed today.
Touchy issues in inter-American relations were skirted yesterday as the New York Times Youth Forum was filmed at the DuMont Telecentre, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- Senator Harry F. Byrd reported today that the Federal payroll climbed to $1,000,000,000 a month in January.

MONTREAL, April 1--The New York Rangers had their scheduled workout this morning under the direction of their coach, Phil Watson. The Broadway Blues are in reasonably good shape for the game tomorrow night with the Canadiens of Montreal.
ALBANY, April 1-Arthur Levitt, the State Controller, assailed Republican legislators today for rejecting a proposed state school financing authority.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)Federal officials told Congress today the low-rent public housing program did not need to be expanded from 35,000 units to a level of 200,000 units a year.
The Stadium Symphony Orchestra will open its fortieth summer season of open-air concerts on June 24 in the Lewisohn Stadium of City College.
WASHINGTON, April 1-The Supreme Court rejected today appeals from judgments ordering desegregation at a Florida swimming pool and a Texas courthouse cafeteria.

CAIRO, April 1--President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to be seeking a loan through United Nations auspices to pay for the new tugs, dredgers and navigational equipment necessary to put the Suez Canal in top operating condition.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, announced yesterday the approval of contracts for the sale of St. Lawrence Power to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation and to the village of Rouses Point.
ARAB nationalism has achieved independence for most of the Arab world without uniting it.

With the acquisition of title to 118-126 William Street and 79-81 John Street, the 110 William Street Corporation has assembled a plot of more than 32,000 square feet for the completion of the thirty-one-story structure it is erecting on the downtown site.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- President Eisenhower received a preliminary report today on possible reductions in the $4,400,000,000 foreign aid program for the next fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)-- --Over protests by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, the Senate voted 70--2 today to confirm the promotion of Brig Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker.

PADANG, Indonesia, April 21 --The military commander of the province of Central Sumatra called today for the setting up of a "benevolent dictatorship" in Indonesia in the event that President Sukarno failed to form a Presidential Cabinet.
YONKERS, April 2--Stanley Dancer, the leading driver here last year, gained a thrilling victory in the $4,500 White Plains trot tonight with Grand Slam.
MAHE, Seychelle Islands, April 2 (AP)--Archbishop Makarios today rejected participation of the Turkish minority in negotiations on the future Cyprus.
FORT MYERS, Fla., April 2-- The Dodgers broke their threegame losing streak today by beating the Pirates, 11--5, in a rather untidy game at Terry Field.

BELLMORE, L.I., April 2-- Two Nassau County detectives drove to Fairfield, Conn., this afternoon to ask a youth to try on a battered shoe. It fit. They arrested him for burglary.
The Halldale Building corporation, consisting of Joseph and David Halpern, has purchased 1660 to 1672 Flatbush Avenue, a blockfront between Aurelia Court and Avenue I, in Brooklyn.
Shirley Temple, who won renown as a curly-haired moppet of motion pictures in the Nineteen Thirties, has been signed as hostess and narrator for a proposed television series of onehour fairy tales.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 2--As long as President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and the other Arab leaders remain in power, Israel cannot expect to achieve peace, Premier David Ben-Gurion declared tonight.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 2 --A restoration of Sunnyside, the home of Washington Irving, to the contour it had when the Sleepy Hollow author died there in 1859 is under intensive study.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission may crack down this month on several of the nation's biggest trading stamp companies, it was learned today.
LONDON, April 2--Prices in the stock markets had rallied today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 2--Israeli officials switched today from pleas to plans as word reached here that the ban on travel to the Middle East by United States citizens had been lifted.
EUGENE ORMANDY led the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in the tenth and final concert of its New York season.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) --The House Judiciary Committee asked Congress today to bolster civil rights enforcement by enacting its version of the Administration's four-point program.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, April 2--Provisional President Franck Sylvain submitted his resignation today to the Haitian Army. He was Haiti's third interim President since December.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Wednesday, April 3--One of the worst riots in many years swept this city yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 2 --Chairman Suwirjo of the Nationalist party gave up today his. attempt to form a government for Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The economy drive was resumed in the House of Representatives today with a $1,682,000 blow to the United States Office of Education.
